author: {'steamid': '76561199467574983', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 292, 'last_played': 1708559432}
review:
It is good detachment from reality: do you want the Statue of Liberty in Buffalo or Atlanta? ; ) New Orleans celebrate their love for the despot. ; ) 

The algorithm promotes religion. I did a lot of Confucianism for example (after Aztecs turned my towns with Judaism) and made good progress, got fission & fiber optics in 1929. What is wrong, Confucian monasteries expire with the Scientific Method. Buddhists are OK, and Christianity can build too: and why should any religion lose monasteries? Plus, both Montezuma and the Chinese would say Confucianism is ‚Äúheathen‚Äù. ; )

To look to the Declaration of Independence or Thoreau alike, the algorithm probably should not promote barracks within cities, ‚Äúamong the people, a standing army‚Äù as king George did, but it was not a good example.

I haven‚Äôt really played the VI, only tried the demo, so I don‚Äôt know how things are there, but the IV is too much history, for civilization as a process: historically, there have been slavery or feudalism among people, but never among all people, and they couldn‚Äôt be requirement for corporation and other good economy. In reality, slave power to purchase goods is zero, and history is not always the best picture for progress. The game would yet make one discover, though I skip most despotisms and ‚Äújump‚Äù to free religion and free speech: when slavery is offered, I click to keep the old ways and don‚Äôt change (Montezuma offers slave slaughter to celebrate!).

Money is not rewarded enough. Montezuma could be making a few pieces of gold and try trading tribalism and fish; my Therebabba making more than a hundred gold per turn and being free speech, is still lower in the ranking. Vast territory, though important, is not the same as advanced civilization; my Therebabba would rather expand when it‚Äôs affordable. 

The screenshot here is a development without slavery, feudalism, monarchy, and state property for a form of government (only discovered, because the game forces it, but not implemented; mostly after time, like Feudalism, one turn after Corporation); it's free religion, free speech and corporation, one turn of anarchy for each. Towns are  on their default auto or autarchy, I tweaked only two or three I believe, for more food. Industrialism may be quite important to get, to keep up with the progress ‚Äî The Manhattan Project is one of the wonders, it takes from town economy, not the research; I'd be tweaking for more happiness right after I get the industrial cash, got Broadway and Hollywood already. ; )

Broadway and Stonehenge in New York; the Sistine Chapel, Kremlin, Statue of Liberty, and Hollywood in Washington; the Eiffel Tower in Boston; the Great Library, Hanging Gardens, and Notre Dame in Atlanta.

The civic upkeep is 78, income 973, so industry is really necessary. All have Constitution, of course.

For civilization as a process, landmark establishments might look better coming with a timeline, rather than as the Oxford University in Boston for example, or the Manhattan Project as well as Kremlin in Washington. 

Anyway, the game is absolutely detachment from reality, so it is good, when you need some "time off life and everything". : )

For reality, feel welcome to read a real fable, about philosopher Honeybee. : )
https://teresapelka.com/2023/01/16/philosopher-honeybee/

author: {'steamid': '76561198142592490', 'num_games_owned': 441, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 333, 'last_played': 1527194838}
review: When I found out that Civilization IV had been out for a couple of years, I was still playing its predecessor. And if it weren't for the dozens or even hundreds of hours I've spent playing Civ3, coupled with fatigue from its limitations and dumb AI ‚Äî Civ4 could, potentially, became my favourite instalment in the whole series. Looking back, the fourth part seems to be the most polished and competent iteration of the iconic franchise. Especially if you compare the basic versions, without the paid DLC and add-ons, which the creators of the series are so like to abuse nowadays. Sid Meier's Civilization IV inherited the best features of its predecessors, polished its mechanics and made a lot of small changes and improvements to the well-established formula. Thanks to a much more user-friendly and informative interface, fancier graphics, mature stylistics (hello to cartoonish Civ6 and Revolution) and FullHD resolution support ‚Äî the project looks and plays pleasantly to this day. And the amount of starting content, old and new civilizations, as well as the presence of alternative leaders are surprising. Of the drawbacks, I could mention the traditionally inadequate behaviour of the AI (especially when playing at marathon speed on huge maps with the maximum number of opponents), as well as the "unfair" difficulty, which increases not via the "cunning" AI, but through a system of bonuses for computer opponents and penalties for the player. But both of these problems are the scourge of the entire series, which the developers have successfully ignored for over two decades. Despite its solid age, Sid Meier's Civilization IV is a great starting point for getting to know the series, especially if you're not interested in online multiplayer. Unlike the newer instalments, Sid Meier's IV is much less demanding in terms of hardware and finances but is just as addictive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198320806237', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1016, 'last_played': 1508648194}
review:
5 dropped the ball on so much in regards to complexity and diplomatic options, and 6 did even worse. Unfortunately 5 will always be my preferred option due to combat alone. Seriously, combat in 4 (BTS) is awful, and significantly holds the game back in my opinion. I come back every once in a while, but I never stay long. Recommend if you're looking for a cheap/ low spec entry to the franchise or prefer background complexity over proper turn based combat. This game blows the whole franchise out of the water until a war starts, which depending on your playstyle might not even be a large portion of the game. God combat fucking sucks though, whose idea was it to make air power useless at a certain strength % against ships?

-Most people have their hours in BTS, disregard mine. I don't have a ton on for 4 anyways but it was the first I got not counting Revolution, so the rose tinted glasses hit hard.

Also Take Two is a genuinely shitty company, and you'll have to agree to their privacy policy to get in. I don't hate valve, but you could probably just pirate a copy without all that jazz. Beyond that, I genuinely don't think Firaxis or 2k have earned your money anymore, seeing what they spent it on for 6. The game is practically live service at this point, and civilization 7 probably will be. If you're really committed to doing things the legal way I'd work through GoG and minimize the profit made off of you, they also have Alpha Centauri which is quite probably the best IP with Sids name on it. Even if you have plenty to spare, respect your dollar more; it's the only power you have in the digital marketplace.

Blue thumb instead of red thumb because it's definitely a good game, and I generally agree with the arguments that the franchise started going downhill from here (5 is still my favorite, but that's after modding it to be more like 4). I just promise that unless you're one of the old spergs high off of Adderall and nostalgia you're going to hate combat and wish it were skippable. Good scenarios, dated modding scene but like morrowind there are die-hards still around keeping the ship afloat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073383843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1462, 'last_played': 1646777870}

author: {'steamid': '76561198010089574', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1059, 'last_played': 1703900938}
review:
This is the best Civilization game. I love being able to stack units and I like the grid map over the hex map.  With hex maps you can only move 6 different directions instead of 8 with the grid map.  Also hex maps just don't look as good as grid maps.  Although modern Civ games do look better with their updated graphics.

Civ 4 is still the most fun to play.  I also think Civ 4 is the most challenging of all the Civ games as the AI in modern Civ games just can't handle moving units around effectively without being able to stack them in like they can in Civ 4.

author: {'steamid': '76561199163812762', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1705948337}
review:
LOVED this game when it was originally released and spent YEARS playing it. My Win98 machine finally died a while ago so I lost the original.

Unfortunately this version on Steam is buggy as hell - Populations don't increase despite having HUGE food surplus (doesn't show there is any food production in city view), improvements you have researched (Mining, Pasture, Irrigation etc) become unavailable at random points in the game and both these issues last for random amounts of time - sometimes one turn sometimes 20 turns or more. 

Game is unplayable when you are hamstrung by random bugs in the games coding. The original was never like this. Forget buying this game and just stick to reminiscing about the old days without trying to relive them, its a waste of money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198115339020', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 3524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3524, 'last_played': 1428865893}
review:
Fun civilization building game where you start in ancient times, found cities, research everything from pottery to writing to nuclear weapons and end up just beyond modern times. Build and manage your military while keeping an eye on the cost. You'll manage relations with other nations and you may even go to war.

The game can get a little tedious on a large map with many cities and somehow you'll find yourself playing for many hours without realizing it.

Overall it's a very fun game with good DLC to add to it.

Es ist zwar alt aber ein sehr gutes Civ. wenn nicht sogar mit der Erweiterung BTS das beste Civ. meiner Meinung nach. Mich sprach der 6 Teil nicht so wirklich an auch wenngleich es ebenfalls kein schlechtes Civ ist aber ich spiele lieber die klassischen Civ Spiele 1,2, Test of TIme, 3 und eben 4. 5 und 6 hab ich zwar auch etwas gespielt aber die konnten mich nicht so ganz √ºberzeugen, wobei mir Civ 5 zwar besser als 6 gefiel aber die Oberfl√§che von beiden teilen eher mittelm√§√üig gefiel. Vom Civ 6 wirkte es mir zu √ºberladen, besonders die Strategische Map, nee, Civ 4 und BTS, Warlords finde ich pers√∂nlich auch ganz gut (Erweiterung von Civ 4) ich kann es nur empfehlen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104478057', 'num_games_owned': 693, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 6948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6948, 'last_played': 1669898771}
review: "The best part of the game is not the tanks or legionnaires or frigates (although those are definitely cool), but the way the game reflects the values you bring to it as you lead your civilization through 6000 years of history. If you want to be a war-mongering despot, crushing your rivals under your iron-shod boots, you can do that. If you want to be a peaceful aesthete, using your advances in art and culture to assimilate other civilizations, you can do that. If you want to be a focused research, striving to unlock the secrets of nuclear power and interstellar travel, you can do that too. Civilization asks you how you want to conquer the world and then turns you loose to pursue that goal in a world where every decision results in a tradeoff or consequence that adds layers and layers of meaning to your story." - IGN, 2015

author: {'steamid': '76561197986781352', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2467, 'last_played': 1690577965}
review: Sid Meier‚Äôs Civilization IV is an addicting 4X strategy game. As a leader of one of the eighteen civilizations of the base game (that can become even more with the two expansions, Warlords and Beyond the Sword) the player is expected to explore the surrounding lands (in a potentially procedurally generated map) and expand their city borders, found new cities or conquer others to gradually become an empire and eventually win a campaign that spans from the stone age to the near future of 2050. Victory can be achieved in many ways, from being the first civilization to reach outer space, to remaining the only civilization that is left on the map. The most interesting and addicting factor of Civilization IV are the choices the player takes, each one leading their civilization‚Äôs progress in a different direction. The technology tree is interesting and varied, allowing to focus on military prowess in one game or scientific progress in another; each choice could be the better one, depending on the map, the adversaries and the success in building world wonders or founding religions. Accompanying these potentially endless games are decent graphics that are clear to understand despite the complexity of the system and an incredibly (and award winning!) soundtrack. The Warlord expansion adds six more civilizations, more leaders and unique scenarios to the main game, but is otherwise unremarkable. The Beyond the Sword expansions is a lot better, adding ten more civilizations, more leaders, more unique scenarios and late game buildings; it also adds natural disasters and expanded victory conditions, making the end game a lot more interesting. Civilization IV ‚Äì The Complete Edition is an amazing package, with virtually endless fours of fun that players want to spend time with, even if just for‚Ä¶ one‚Ä¶ more‚Ä¶ turn‚Ä¶

review: Started playing when I was in middle school on my Uncle's MacBook whenever he visited. Still my favorite civ game. Sure, it's pretty easy to snatch a diplo victory, and later civ games have a lot more complexity with "districts" and "ranged warfare", but tell me, have they ever created a moment as singularly cathartic as finally seizing China's last city after literal centuries of brutal, slogging stack conflict, leaving hundreds of units dead and world politics broken beyond measure? Do those other civ games have mods that turn it from a loosely historical fantasy game to a fucking sci-fi squad tactics game?  Do the other civ games only cost 10 dollars? Do they run well on a laptop from 2013 with no gaming optimization and charging port you need to use duct tape to make work? No, I thought not. This game fucking rocks. It is the George Clooney of 4X strategy games: a charismatic grey fox that only gets better with age. Everyone else may have moved on, I say let them. There's only one civ game that's number 1 in my heart, and that's Civilization 4.

author: {'steamid': '76561198406624764', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 32788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30742, 'last_played': 1696956949}
review: Still a good game. I have Civ 6 but I still come back and play this one because of the simplicity of it. I wish it had an "undo" button though. I've completely quit multiple games of it after investing a fair amount of time into them because I made game altering moves completely by accident, such as clicking "build city" in a horrible spot when I meant to just move the settler or completely deleting a valuable unit in the same way. At least have a dialogue box pop up asking if you're sure you want to make such a weighty move before it becomes final. Egregious oversight by the developers, who've obviously never made a mistake in their lives.

review:
it is friggin surreal how i haven't even finished a game yet and every moment of it is full of whimsy, discovering what's to come

i don't care much at all for strategy games, in any sense, and this is plain awesome

that should tell you all you need to know when it comes to whether or not this is worth your time

pro tip: the game has settings for an ingame real clock and alarm, and i strongly recommend you make use of them, because otherwise you'll keep saying "just one turn" and it's 5 hours later

author: {'steamid': '76561198016322725', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1684352943}
review:
One of the greatest turn based 4x Civ games.

This + Chronicles of Mankind mod is better than any game in the genre.

Chronicles of Mankind (and some other mods) not only give this game a huuuuuge number of extra units, civs, leaders, wonders, resources, completely game-altering features, but fix some of the biggest problems with the original as well. For example, the stack of doom. In the mod settings you can set up how many units may reside on one tile. It's like, getting 5 expansions for free.

Check out the civfanatics forums, where most of the Civ IV community and their wonderful mods reside!

author: {'steamid': '76561198026977988', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 808, 'last_played': 1556941651}
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization IV is a timeless masterpiece that has captivated strategy gamers for over a decade. From its engaging gameplay mechanics to its intricate diplomacy system, Civilization IV is an experience that is as fun as it is intellectually stimulating.

At the heart of Civilization IV lies the core of its gameplay, which revolves around building a thriving civilization from scratch. Players begin as a small tribe with limited resources and gradually expand their reach across the map by developing new technologies, building infrastructure, and negotiating with other civilizations. The game offers a variety of paths to victory, including military conquest, cultural dominance, and scientific advancement, giving players the freedom to play the game in their own way.

One of the game's standout features is its diplomacy system, which allows players to forge alliances, trade resources, and negotiate peace treaties with other civilizations. The system is deep and nuanced, allowing players to use a variety of tactics to achieve their goals, from coercion and bribery to charm and flattery. The system also takes into account each civilization's unique characteristics, creating a dynamic and unpredictable playing field.

In addition to its gameplay, Civilization IV also boasts stunning visuals and a beautiful soundtrack that immerses players in the game's world. The attention to detail in the game's design is impressive, from the unique unit models to the lush environments and cityscapes.

Overall, Sid Meier's Civilization IV is a true masterpiece of the strategy genre. It combines engaging gameplay mechanics with an intricate diplomacy system and stunning visuals to create an experience that is both intellectually stimulating and immensely enjoyable. Whether you're a veteran of the series or a newcomer to the franchise, Civilization IV is a game that is not to be missed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089564999', 'num_games_owned': 507, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 435, 'last_played': 1651415121}
review:
Two brief bits of clarification before I dig into the actual review:

1. My playtime is a lie. Beyond the fact that the DLCs act as standalone games, and your playtime on them doesn't contribute to the base game, I also owned the CD-ROM version back in the day, and played it until disc rot made it literally unplayable.

2. The base game isn't the definitive way to enjoy this game. Get the Beyond the Sword expansion, because you're honestly doing yourself a disservice if you don't.

Now, onto the review.

I am a historian. It's an integral part of me. It's what I've studied, it's what I explore in my free time, it's what I can talk about for hours without a pause. Civilisation 4 is a large part of the reason why. It came out when I was pretty young and I was always terrible at it, but for hours an hours on end, after I came home from school, I would play Civ 4. Hundreds of hours. Thousands of hours. I played this game for [b]years[/b] almost religiously. As mentioned above, the CD-ROM I played it on eventually succumbed to disc rot because of how much I was handling it.

Even without Civilisation's long and impressive pedigree, this is quite possibly the perfect historical 4x game. It's easy to jump into at low levels, but with layers upon layers of strategy to dig down into. The graphics are aged, sure, the sound design is rough around the edges, and even through my extremely rose-tinted glasses I can acknowledge that it has its jank and weird moments, but getting through that rewards you with an endlessly replayable experience, always fresh, always there, always ready for you to make your mark on the world. It [b]oozes[/b] charm and care. The technology quotes are narrated by the late Leonard Nimoy for Christ's sake! (One of his only non-Star Trek related video game credits alongside Kingdom Hearts, funnily enough.)

I still go back to it, year after year. Partially out of nostalgia, yes, but also because it hooks me like no other Civ game really can. Civ 5 is excellent, yes, and SM:AC probably some of the best science fiction ever put into video game format, but Civ 4 will always be my beloved.

And, if you've somehow extracted all the dopamine from the base game, fear not. The modding community for this game is prodigious, and it even comes bundled with a few of them to give you a taste. My personal recommendation, if you find the base game too slow or not detailed enough, is the truly ludicrous mod of Caveman2Cosmos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198245034620', 'num_games_owned': 44, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 499, 'last_played': 1703648229}
review:
One of my favorite strategy games of all time, this was the pinnacle of strategy games back in 2005. You play as a civilization trying to become the biggest empire of all, from a timeframe of 4000 B.C. to 2050. The gameplay is turn-based, and you can advance by developing your cities and improving your army, as well as developing technologies. Overall, graphics are dated but serviceable, and gameplay is very fun!

Graphics: C
Gameplay: A
Music: B
Story: Not much of one
Difficulty: Depends on difficulty setting, ranges from 3/10, Easy but not a joke, to 9/10, Dark Souls has some competition!
Overall: A

author: {'steamid': '76561198033818893', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 2436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2433, 'last_played': 1673325003}
review:
This is the first 3D Civ game, and it manages to keep the very high standards for the series. The gameplay is substantially changed from Civ 3; in my opinion, for the better. UX is simpler, the game offers more techs to research, and there are a lot of small but significant additions that makes the game so much more complex to play, but easier too. Some people may prefer the more open gameplay of the predecessor, but, having heavily played both of them, I can say that Civ 4 is the winner, being a better 4X game.

Although not really important in a Civ game, graphics are ok, but the music is amazing, with the best soundtrack for the series so far. The presentation, in general, is very good.

I believe this is a game that few people will be on the fence about buying it or not. Civ is the foundation of the genre, and this entry is considered to be best by many people. So, for anyone even slightly interested in this genre, Civ 4 is basically a no-brainer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023373303', 'num_games_owned': 90, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 9754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1185, 'last_played': 1698680626}
review:
I finally moved on from Civ 3 and i dont regret it. I've only played almost 20 hours of civ 4 currently. I've played thousands of hours in civ 3 since i was a kid and i think it's safe to say it's my favorite turn based game, or was until i played civ 4 that is. In my opinion they are virtually the same game, with civ 4 having a few slight improvements (and one or two things i don't like as much)

Some of the changes are not necessarily an improvement or a detriment, just makes them different. There is some different music although civ 4 does retain some of the same soundtrack. I really enjoy both soundtracks. I havnt found a way to make armies in civ 4 yet and i found them instrumental to military victory in civ 3. The graphics in civ 4 are slightly cartoony and i kinda liked the look of civ 3 better. But that's just  my opinion. I also don't care for the way artillery seems to work in civ 4 where they get into direct engagement with an enemy each instead of bombarding, which changes my gameplay a bit. I do like that i'm challenged to change my play style which has made me a better player while the game still remains pretty balanced. 
In civ 3 i found it easy to expand exponentially with spamming settlers, but it civ 4 i found the maintenance costs too great and i was forced to slow down. I really like the way maintenance works now. Instead of many of the buildings coming with a certain cost(some still have cost requirements), the cost is attributed to the city itself. And instead of having corruption costs the further you are from your capital, you simply have maintenance costs and the courthouse still serves the same function in both cases. 
Another reason i found it suitable to slow down expansion was because i used to play civ 3 with the barbs on sedentary. Maybe i just havnt figured it out yet, but there doesnt seem to be way to alter the barbarian behavior or even to alter the amount of players manually in single player, although it of course changes based on the map size. I figure some of these things i used to do in civ 3 were kinda cheating and i really needed the challenge to become a better player. Here are some things i've had to work on in order to be decent at civ 4:
I used to automate my workers. Yes, im very noobish for doing this after all this time and after actually studying the behavior of the workers i realized how incredibly lazy i had been for not micromanaging them. In civ 4 i really need the economy boost to continue my expansion. so i end up building a lot of cottages at first while keeping a careful eye on my food, trying to maintain a small food surplus for growth. And don't forget that building settlers and workers effects population growth so build accordingly. 
In order to boost my economy i cut down forests to add to my production. This one is pretty obvious and i  used to use it sometimes but found i never really needed to manually use my workers in civ 3. Of course if i had been playing above noble (the balanced difficulty) this would have been a requirement.
These days i usually keep my science at either 0% or 100%. You will make more money and research will be greater in many cases than if you stay at 70% for example. This may changes as you continue to build libraries, universities, ect... 
After playing civ 4 i felt like i had been getting away with ignoring a few fundamentals of civ 3.
Pros:
In civ 4 unit selection, cycling is not as glitchy and usually will rotate through the stack instead of some random unit somewhere else although it still seems to do it sometimes. 

the map regenerate button is awesome. Especially useful in civ 4 for regenerating a new map because they always stick my capital next to an ocean.

The players also seem to be more evenly spaced out from one another at the beginning of the game but that may be due to not manipulating too many or to few AI when i choose the settings. 

Cons:

There seem to be less options for generating a new game, although some have also been added liked having a pressed or natural coast.

I miss the old artillery.


All in all Civ 4 is mostly an improvement over civ 3 and i would recommend someone holding out playing the older installations to give it a try. 

I also feel the need to add that the base games seem to have roughly the same civs. With the civ 3 gold edition there were a lot of civs added. There do seem to be extra civs in the civ 4 expansions which are separate and i have gotten to them yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085059421', 'num_games_owned': 88, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 8192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8192, 'last_played': 1684640175}
review: I haven't played the original aka "vanilla" Civilization IV since Beyond the Sword came out. 15 years later I decided to revisit the game and experience it all over again. I found I didn't miss the changes added by Warlords and Beyond the Sword DLCs at all, though, I guess I do miss a civilization's unique building. Civ IV is just as addicting as I remember and playing civilizations I normally looked over in Beyond the Sword was a great experience. Civ IV still holds up today and is a great entry point into the franchise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198812613563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 5410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4931, 'last_played': 1692147564}
review:
Pros: 
- The most fast-paced mainline Civ game
- Perfect blend between the simplicity of the older games and the complexity of the newer ones
- Harder to build a million wonders
- Better UI
- More unit diversity
- Some civs allow you to choose between two leaders
- Animations for building wonders, of which are more unique from one another than in Civ 3
- No more "shields", meaning you can't use the production from a granary to help build the Colossus. You can also select multiple buildings to construct
- Multiplayer is a complete improvement over Civ 3

Cons:
- The religions all do the same thing
- Combat relies heavily on building large stacks of units
- Despite being in 3D, the graphics are worse than in Civ 3

author: {'steamid': '76561198076302773', 'num_games_owned': 78, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1697846446}
review:
Civilization IV is absolutely the best civ game and nobody will be able to convince me otherwise. I say this as someone who has played every civilization game except for Civ VI. I got the original game as a birthday present from my parents and became obsessed with each one since, so I know the strengths and weaknesses of them. The early civilization games were good, but had flaws. For instance, if you screwed up even a little bit, your game was finished. Never ending wars were a constant issue in civ 1-3 to the point where it became like Orwell's 1984; "we were always at war with Ghandi..." It was only truly fixed in this game where peace treaties became binding and it was not possible to cross borders without an open borders agreement (in the old games, you could keep troops in your opponent's territory and they would have to tell you to get out or declare war, after which most AI would declare war). So Civ 4 (this game) fixed these issues whilst still retaining the core gameplay which was utterly decimated in Civ V and newer versions. Later versions changed the core gameplay a lot and added complexity which doesn't really complement the game at all. Most people were happy that unit stacks were removed (i.e. you could no longer have 20 riflemen, 10 artillery, and 5 catapults on one tile) and with other changes to how combat works, but I feel that it ruined the game. It made combat more strategic in a way, but also more complicated in a bad way for gameplay & enjoyability. It's hard to describe exactly why, but Civ IV had the best of both worlds: the beginning of improvements that made civ better whilst also retaining the game mechanics and spirit of the old civ. 

Oh, and I actually have 300 hours on this game, plus a bit more from when I owned it before having a steam account. I don't know why, but it reset my hours when I reinstalled this game on my new PC.

TLDR: Civ IV is the perfect civ game and you should definitely get it.

review: Not the best Civ if you're new to the series, and really not the best if you have other Civ games to play given the game feels like it stumbles around with its gameplay and options compared to the others.  It's still technically good, though, but to be honest: if you're new to Civ, play V (no, not VI).  If you're not, play V or III, or better yet, go find a copy of the absolute best Civ game ever made: II.  It's criminal that Civ2 isn't on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201118017', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1663462408}
review:
good in it's day but easily surpassed with civ 5, only worth owning in a sale or key purchase to complete your collection (wish civ net and civ 2 were on steam too ) ... yo gabe do a solid and port over

Edit: i must have been on drugs when i wrote this review because civ IV with BTS is the best of the entire civ collection, i think i got confused with civ III, i bought each civ game so my steamy account had juice from yesteryear in it and i think ive not actually played civ4 till now and to me it takes the good bits from civ 3 then pumps them up for civ4. 
The good bits i've noticed so far are the icons and ui style are ripped straight from civ3 but with civ5 graphics for most of the rest, the rivers work similar to pre civ5 games and are animated too unlike civ5, trees are also animated and grow and decline in civ4,  the troops also stack which i used to love in civ 2-3 and make it feel bigger somehow, ive not reached late game yet but tube vids and other web pages show a much better end game than any civ game.
The voice acting is by Spock ‚ù§ and each troop has it's own speech and you can actually hear what they are saying unlike other civ games, the graphics are not dated in my opinion and work really well for this game plus the game is really quick loading and playing on modern pcs compared to other civ games.
Also the modding community is pretty huge for this game and once ive played a few dozen games of vanilla civ 4 BTS i will be adding a few mods and there's a few which totally change the game giving even more value, some mods are none workshop so you will need to install from none steam websites but it's easy to install, and there is an inbuilt map editor from the get go not like the annoying ridiculously hard to use one in civ 5.

All in all a superb game one title every 4x or strategy gamer should have in their library, buy the complete edition so you get all the DLC which is only ¬£12 at the time of review and cheaper from steam key sites (i paid ¬£5 for the lot) ... stop procrastinating and buy this beauty you won't be disappointed .

author: {'steamid': '76561198174229817', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 21647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 634, 'last_played': 1664696396}
review:
Start a game.
Meet like eight civilization in the first 20 turns.
At some point they all declare war on you for no good reason.
Die.
Restart.
Mind your own business.
Other civilizations surround you with a gorillion cities, you can't expand, you're crushed while trying to defend with a longbowman against eight tanks.
Die.
Restart.
Quickly build some cities with a few defenders.
Every turn every city is attacked by three barbarians.
Die.
Restart.
Build some cities, well defended.
You end up with no money, no research, units in strike who self destruct. Barbarians attack.
Die.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117720423', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 9088, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2810, 'last_played': 1666409868}
review: I have played CIV since the first one came out many years ago.  You can make it a long game or a short one.  There are levels of difficulty.  The "settler" difficulty, the least difficult of all the levels, can still be difficult.  I play the "settler" level because I'm not looking to create stress for myself when I play.  I play to relax.  At my age, too difficult a game isn't a challenge; it's an exercise in frustration.  So in the Civilization games, there is something for almost everyone.  The many different ways you can win the game also allows the player to adapt it to his or her preference.  You don't have to kill off everyone in order to win.  I like most of the music in the game.  Some of the music used for the later phase of the game is modern, atonal music which is not my cup of tea.  Other than that, the music is fine.  Actually, my favorite among the Civilization games is CIV 3, but CIV 4 also provides hours of good play.

author: {'steamid': '76561199042820372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1648315858}
review: I only review games I've beaten at least once. In my opinion the IV is the best game in the series. It was created by one of the best game-designers -- Soren Johnson. He wasted some years after that but his latest games (Offworld Trading Company and Old World) show his true potential. So even after all these years I still come back to IV and buy it for every account I have on any platform available. I love the way culture and religion work in this one. Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561197995355816', 'num_games_owned': 446, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 2915, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2915, 'last_played': 1648087046}
review:
[i]Civilization[/i] continues to improve with each installment. With this fourth attempt, the series has cleaned up almost all of its old shortcomings. The interface is nearly as streamlined as gameplay this complex will allow, and the controversial ‚Äústrategic resources‚Äù from [i]III[/i] have been made more plentiful and less decisive. In fact, due to overhauls of several mechanics, especially combat, this is probably the most balanced these games have ever been. It feels more organic than past titles as well ‚Äì large cities spill out into adjacent tiles, the spread of religion across societies is only moderately controllable, and there are more numerous and interesting options for government style, unit promotion, and Great Person behaviour. The only remaining issues that aren‚Äôt endemic to the genre (such as game speed) are in the presentation. Outside of the famously incredible title theme, the music is quite boring, there are some odd sound effect choices, and the jump to 3D visuals had mixed results.

[b]Score: 8/10[/b]

https://www.imlgames.com/sid-meiers-civilization-iv/

author: {'steamid': '76561198204737521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 10811, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8647, 'last_played': 1685420843}
review:
Unlike most of the gamers I know, I never really cared for shoot'em'up or military conquest computer games. But games like solitaire and the ubiquitous merging games found on cell phones and computers today simply bore me to tears.  I have been playing Civilization from when the very first edition came out in 1991.  I welcomed CIV II and CIV III, but the advent of CIV VI gave me the strategy game I really was looking for.

I play CIV IV because it gives me the opportunity to win by diplomacy, cultural spread, and the space race as alternatives to outright war against the other civilizations. I play just the desktop mode, and generally customize to run the largest maps with marathon speed to let me really get into micromanaging the cities and units in games that might take me months to win, depending the real life time I have available to me.  

For me it is the journey  I take in developing my civilization, rather than the winning over the others that I enjoy.  I set the game to always be in a state of peace (which I know is unrealistic) and dive in to the complexities of diplomacy and culture to either work together with the AI's civilizations or to entice them to join me through my culture development (usually by culture bombing the border cities by having Great Artists move to those locations and creating their Great Works). 

I have yet to find another strategy game that caters as much to those players who don't enjoy warfare focused games as they do to those who are more interested in military conquest.  CIV IV lets both types of player have an enjoyably challenging time creating and growing their civilizations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139060220', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2059, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1643159417}
review:
I cried when I heard the main menu music again after having not played it for over 8 years. This was a huge part of my childhood, and hearing that menu music after starting it up after so long is heart-wrenching, having deprived myself of that beautiful song for so long.

Baba Yetu is the most beautiful song I've ever heard in a game. Whether you have, or have not played this game before, I recommend it for nothing else other then nostalgia and the song Baba Yetu.

review: Civ IV is a an excellent game for those who enjoy the 4x genre.  I have always enjoyed the Civilization franchise and Civ IV does not dissapoint.  I particularly like the way you can customize your government and society, as well as being able to found a particular religion if you are the first to advance a particular tech associated with that particular religion.  The map zoom in/out feature is also very helpful in keeping an eye on what is going on in and out of your empire.

review: Easily one of my most nostalgic games. I played this all the time as a kid, and it got me interested in history. On top of that, it has Leonard Nemoy and Baba Yetu, so what else undo you need really? If the answer is a great strategy game that still holds up, then it‚Äôs got you covered there too. I am one of those heathens that actually likes this game without the expansions, largely because that‚Äôs how i did as a child. Anyways, great strategy game, I‚Äôm always hungry for more Civ.

author: {'steamid': '76561198320097560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1519, 'last_played': 1499198922}
review:
fun fact, this was Sid Meier's last game he himself worked on. as a result he combined his knowledge from every previous game into this little bundle of joy i literally put into a folder with only 2 other games called "Games i don't play at night". Hearts of Iron IV and Ark: Survival Evolved being those two other games. It was a Mitigation measure to ensure i wouldn't spend a whole night playing due to the sheer craftsmanship of these 3 Games that would keep me at my keyboard thinking about what to do next. it's a diplomatically polite way to admit to the Addictive properties behind the Designs of all three Games. HOI4 was the first inclusion but without thinking I had no doubt Civilization IV already stirred the same experience from the whirlwind of a mind under Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD, thou very mild and mitigated when the "Hyperfixiation" symptom that Asperger's Syndrome is known for comes into play).

good buy for only 5-7 USD in a Steam Sale for every Expansion. Beyond the Sword Especially i Consider the Definitive Civ 4 Expansion since Warlords and Colonization were likely more of a Gameplay Experiment.

Might of Been the Nintendo Switch Version as my only Experience of Civ VI but the Cohesion of the Experience Especially when Compared to Civ IV... It did not hold up. the same song being used through the entire game with different time period sound fonts felt like a broken Record and at some points I don't know when it transitioned to Another Era. At least Civ IV had a Better soundtrack for this from it's own Ancient tracks and Antiquity down to the Rennaisance and Medieval Pieces from Public Domain. Civ III Tracks even made it in. VI barely felt like a True Sid Meier's Civ game though i can blame that on my General Incompetence with a Controller and the Tech and Cultural Trees Feeling Awkward. Also used to IV's Squares instead of Hexagons. I Felt like the Map Needed to be Bigger, i Ran out of Room quick in a my Capitols to Build Manufactories and I had a Whole Continent to myself in the New World. 

It Hit uncanny Valley when i went to China to Sent an Embassy there and Realized that not only Qin Shi Huang was the leader of China instead of a Later dynasty like the Ming or Qing but that They Had Bullet Trains in the Early 1900s (I was Expecting WW1) and that the Hunnic Migrations never Quite had it's Consequences End with the Poles being Further West then the Vistula (The Rabbit Hole that Is Studying the Fall of Rome to see How it could Repeat when MIT (that Massachusetts Institution of Technology) Literally Predicted not that long Ago that Society will collapse Bronze Age style Within this Century). At Least Gilgamesh was a Good Friend when they Founded the New World in the Late 1800s. At least somewhat predictable in the Event that Medieval Europe never was subjected to Muslim Expansionism since Discovery was Fueled by the Fall of Constantinople and the Sheer Will to Bypass the Silk Road under Ottoman Control. Yes Learning History is something else i do to Stave boredom like it's the Plague and i found many Humors while doing so; Plague doctor jargon aside to the Blood letting table. suppose i'm such a late bloomer that i only now think of the idea of making custom scenarios. ideas are a dime a dozen and products and prototypes are the Gold of the Gold Standard that Backs a Worthy Suggestion. I digress my rant, my ADHD turns me into an Abraham Lincoln and Vladimir Putin when it comes to Keeping the Unions between Country-states together and keeping a concise meaning in a world wall of the different shades of print

Better experience over graphics any day would happen to be the Bias i Shine like a Motto at. the Tier list war amongst the Franchise Playerbase has convinced me thoroughly that Civ 4 is the Best Civ Game. if it wasn't for that i would have never come to know that IV was the Final and Apex of Sid's work; Akin to How Final Fantasy 9 was Composer Nobuo Uematsu's Final Game (where he composed solely, he was passing 10 to a successor concurrently) and in his own words "Magnum Opus" though i Consider FF6's Soundtrack to be the Best.

A: Yes I turned on comments because a Humanly debate amuses me when video games fail to accomplish the ole Roman Bread and Circus mechanic used by most modern deep states and Our Civilization's Very own Political Machine. Good playing everyone. Boredom causes me to Break my usual Docile nature so i try to find productive ways to Exploit the Manhole's Kinetic Energy when the sewage in the mind breaks all Valves.

author: {'steamid': '76561198326827953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 950, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 866, 'last_played': 1660741721}
review:
The Civilization series's marvellous! Perfect if you want to just chill, drink coffee, relax, and multi-task; since it's a turn-taking game. This is the one you want if your computer can't quite run Civilization 5 properly and it's the one you buy when Civilization 3 is just too primitive for you. Yes! This one's sure got a bundle of a bunch more spice than Civilization 3; however if you're looking for less of a challenge then turn back, right now. The A.I. still practically does almost everything it can do in it's power; once the planet-map's made; to completely work against you.. The only way I've discovered of keeping up to them and becoming somewhat of a super-power-nation, is to go with the flow; and hope to Jesus Christ that you've got some really great resources in the early game. (You want either a massive river or river-system/delta, you want one of your cities to be on the coast with fish, or/and any amount of stone/copper/iron/silver/gold/gems/diamonds in your close-reaching-grasp.) ((Big fertile lands of rivers with great farmland is just perfect for building up a large population to get things done or simply to raise a simple/large army/navy; although, you're definitely going to want at least one city in your empire to be on the ocean with some sort of type of fish... And don't forget to go nuts over things that either bring you much money: or things that'll upgrade the quality of your peoples' tools/weapons.)) A small army with an abundance of copper can easily annihilate a massive army of simple people who don't have access to creating bronze weapons out of a certain tin/copper consistency. I hope the game takes into account that hardened bronze takes at least 3 years to become hardened to almost it's maximum potential. It'd be even more silly if you had stone walls before the enemy tried breaking in with their soldiers, armed with bronze weapons: because if you researched archery and have some guys with bows/arrows in your walled-city - it can be crazy-difficult for the enemy to break into that. So, no... You really don't need copper and tin to become powerful, though, you need them to make bronze if you're going on the offensive. Which reminds me, if you choose to make your nation a slave-trade, which happens in the early game: after researching the ability to have bronze, you can become a slave-trade. I highly recommend that you do become a slave trade if you want to be successful at an incredible rate because it's simply one of the steps Mankind has to take in order to compete strongly with many other nations of men. (It's practically the only way to become a strong super power in the early game which usually means you actually have a shot at survival; I've done many games without doing the slave-trade thing and it always ends up with my nation getting left in the dust and fighting off against hoards of barbarians or simply getting erased by an enemy nation, who did decide to become a slave trade.) ((But to become a super successful slave trade, towering over all of your enemies, nearby: you absolutely need a source of copper connected with roads to your most military-enhanced city; which's usually got to either be your capital city or one that you created a barracks in, right off the bat.)) As far as becoming an extremely massive slave-trade, you really need to conduct assaults with the dudes who have bronze, 2-handed, axes.. Often just a few of these bronze-axe-men combatant armies can, easily and absolutely, wreck an enemy nation who isn't immersed with an amount of abundant copper. It's necessary to conquer these militaristically 'weaker' nations because: as a slave trade; you need to enslave many other people, you can't be enslaving many of your own people or there'll be turmoil in the streets and wonders of your own empire! As a slave trade, you must conquer at least one other nation; no matter how kind they are; or suffer radical and economic collapse. This is how you can become an economic powerhouse in the early times of the world or be prepared to be easily picked off a tree and eaten by; barbarians, your own people, or/and another slave-trading empire: it's practically like this anyway... To tell you the truth, complex strategy and being responsive in many ways are how you take off from being a slave trade. Choose a good religion for your people which suits the overall strategy of you and your empire. If you don't go a strong religious route and are not very successful in becoming a good and quite religious empire; then be prepared for your empire to go into revolution after revolution against you. I personally, always try to hit religion at the same time that Christianity is introduced in the game-match; it's also alright to take that religion from another nation: as long as you end up on top of them, at some point; power-wise. If your nation's the one that Christianity happens in via enabling a bit of liberty so it's much more possible - then you have the best ability to subdue the other nations, both with peace, obligations, or simply war. If your nation's the first Christian nation; you've really got the game in the bag and you really ought to save the game right then and there. I say this because the rest of the game's going to require much more, complex and responsive, immensely great strategy and tactics. Pick up as much iron as you can by this time; you need to prepare for the era of the future world wars: if they even erupt. You have to get ready to make complex machinery on an industrial level; definitely become a monarch along the way, too. You need oil deposits. If you don't have at least 2 deposits of iron connected with roads to your military production centres; and if you don't have at least one deposit of oil connected in the same way; you don't stand a chance in a world war. Become a thinker like an industrial revolutionary leader!!!!! If you don't have at least 2 units of infantry and at least one unit of some sort of combat-vehicle; like tanks, bomber-planes, or artillery: then go back to that save file that I told you to make, earlier. If you don't; then if a world war happens: and it's highly likely in this game: you're getting stomped and your nation will belong to another in a hurry. For the amount of raw, non-politically-correct, and difficult: realism: I give this game a 10/10. It really doesn't need the hottest graphics and sure lacks a bit in the quality of the sprites and what you get visually: this game isn't even for a wide screen monitor.. But, for what it's taught me about just how competitive you need to be as a people; in order to survive for thousands of years, even making choices that're considered major mistakes today: in order to maintain your people on a competitive level... I will not take off any of my rating for the lack of great visuals. (It's not the worst game on a graphic and visual level, but it could sure use a wide-screen version.) You're all the very best for reading my review and dedicating your time to check out my profile! Thank you all very much for your time and energy, take care, have a good time, stay safe, enjoy, and good bye for now!!

             Sincerely, Milo!

review:
i'm only not recommending this game because it doesn't work. you download it on steam and play it through steam IT SHOULD WORK!!!!!!! 
I have a windows  10 operation system.... I'm sorry Steam but if you are offering these games off your platform then you should ensure they work. I cannot get this game to work (and i have tried at least 2 fixes off the community page so far) and from a platform (such and yours) that  is offering classic games such as this and others, it should work through your platform. i love the civilization series but if your going to sell these nostalgic games and not ensure that they function on all Systems that is a real problem.... 
it's like selling a used car and  asking full price on that used car that is broke down and not working and you nor fixing it and telling the owner to just "figure it out"
A honestly another thing....The system of reporting glitches in your platform is the biggest most ridiculous thing...in that it is practically non-existent!!!!!!  and i hate to say it if it's some legal issue say 2k or firaxis games won't let you modify code in the game to make the game function on modern systems....then they are really dumb. cause that means a loss in profits for yourselves and possibly them....i guess by some proxy maybe.

review: Mit beiden Erweiterungen immer noch der H√∂hepunkt der Serie. Sp√§testens wenn man in Civilization 6 zwischen Aztekien und Zululand gestartet ist und mit einer anderen Religion als Spanien einen friedlichen Kultursieg eingefahren hat, ist man wieder hier. Hier sieht man noch, was man wo produziert und kann dadurch auch sehen, wo man sich verbessern mu√ü. Es ist alles so beliebig geworden. Ein Wunder ist in Civilization 6 nur der Verlust eines Gel√§ndefelds. Baut man eben ein anderes, wenn man Bock drauf hat. Andere Dinge haben sich dorthin so sehr verbessert, wie die diplomatischen Beziehungen zu Tokugawa im Laufe einer Civ4-Partie. Als R√∂mer liegen die Eisenvorkommen am anderen Ende der Karte, die KI schickt die Artillerie an einen anderen Frontabschnitt als die anderen Truppen. Das hat man schon hier. Multiplayer? Auch nur instabil zusammengefrickelt. Grafisch nicht mehr so der Hit, aber Civ4 bleibt √ºbersichtlich.

review:
It is said that Civ4 is one of the best of the Civilisation series and I've played it for a while a few years ago but I can not recommend it anymore. I installed it on Windows 10 but couldn't get it to run. I tried all of the compatibility modes even back to Windows XP running as Administrator but it crashes on a render error. I searched in Bing but couldn't find a solution to get it running when using Microsoft Remote Desktop. It run fine on the directly connect display and I got to work remotely after setting a suitable display resolution.
Windows 10 Pro 21H1 Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E3-1270 V2 @ 3.50GHz 16GB RAM GeForce GT 710 1360x768

author: {'steamid': '76561198035345202', 'num_games_owned': 1423, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 1866, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 914, 'last_played': 1632713192}
review:
Civilization IV is a turn-based strategy game in which you attempt to rule a civilization from the dawn of civilization to the start of the real Space Age. You balance the development of your cities' infrastructure, the quantity and quality of your military, your research projects, and trade routes. And using whatever means you can, you vie for victory by achieving any of a variety of victory conditions, such as being the first to colonize space or by becoming the uncontested global superpower.

I played the balls absolutely off of Civilization II back in the Windows 98 days. It was an exceptional game for its time. But Civilization IV became my favorite entry into the late 2000s. The territory game mechanic in particular was a much appreciated improvement, in addition to graphical, UI, and music modernization efforts.

I only ever have two complaints with Civ IV, or with most of the Civilization games, One, that city management over long periods of time can be obnoxious to micromanage. It can be time consuming and aggravating to try and keep your cities keeping up with their infrastructure, and some of the later AI improvements to help automate this aren't always the best. Two, sometimes you get absolutely whacked by a large number of units that appear suddenly out of nowhere deep within your territory. I wish Civ IV had the mechanic included in even older Total War games to reduce this frustration, namely the ability for military units to construct watchtowers to maintain visibility (instead of requiring engineers to build forts).

In single playthroughs, these are not nearly enough to eliminate the fun of the game. But it does prevent playability without long breaks of time in between game installs.

Pros:
+ Nice graphics (for its time)
+ Nice UI (for its time) and map navigation
+ Large variety of Civs, Units, and city buildings
+ Hatshepsut is a cutie

Cons:
- Micromanaging can be exceptionally time consuming, which can make longer games boring, and hurts replayability
- You can't build watchtowers with military units to help with map visibility, guaranteeing that large stacks of enemy troops will somehow zip past your suburbs to whack you deep behind the actual front.

Rating: A- (for its time), B+ (for 2021)

At its normal price of $19.99? It's not worth it in 2021. But it regularly goes on sale for 70 or 70% off. At that price its a no brainer if you like turn-based strategy games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052496013', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 5, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5, 'last_played': 1619093991}
review:
Absolutely the best game in the series, /Especially/ for singleplayer games. Improves in all areas from previous titles, and has the classic combat that allows the AI to actually be a threat. as fun as the new entries are, the computer cannot properly wage war in them, and so is no challenge at all.  Civ IV has the most interactive city borders as well, allowing strategies and gameplay styles unavailable before of after.

 If you want to play Civilization, Play IV.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993455369', 'num_games_owned': 191, 'num_reviews': 331, 'playtime_forever': 1801, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1801, 'last_played': 1627423317}
review: Civilization is one of the oldest video game series out there. The very first game came out in 1991... Crazy, right? The whole franchise is just 2 years older than myself. So, speaking about Civilization IV, it is one of most long-living game of the franchise, which received a lot of fan content during the years after its release. Its original gameplay is much closer to the older Civilization games, however, it is more complicated because of various elements like corporations mechanics. In later titles Firaxis started to change their classic formula for more modern and somehow even mainstream approach. And I think it was for the best because I never was big fan of old Civilization combat system. And while I came to Civilization franchise with Civilization V and for very long time I played only that game, when I was living in Germany in 2016-2018, my German friends, who were big fans of Civ IV, introduced it to me and we had pretty nice time playing Civilization IV together. Concluding this review I want to say that I am glad that this game showed me how the classical civilization gameplay looked like.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045501597', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1626862088}
review: Civ IV puts the onus of learning its mechanics on the player a little more than its---at the time of writing this---two sequels do. That said if you've played another Civ game, this one won't be difficult for you to learn. I'd recommend players new to Civ IV start on Noble difficulty. I play Civ V and Vi on Emperor difficulty, but that proved too much of a challenge for me while learning Civ IV. Like other civilization games, civ IV has a built in civilopedia, and I recommend you use it, or the online version, whenever you discover a new social policy, building, or anything else that intrigues you. If you enjoy the process of learning a game, Civ IV is rich in mechanical complexity, perhaps even more so than its sequels, but you are by no means required to understand all of it on your first, or even your third, playthrough. A Youtuber with a channel called RazingHel has a three part series that I found to be very edifying as a newcomer to Civ IV, and I will include a link to the first video in that series: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CgBnpbaQFo4.

review: I have been playing the civilization series since I was a kid and have still yet to find a comparable alternative. The in depth range of options for development of your nation, diplomacy, and game play customization is amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561199065701089', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 98817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2195, 'last_played': 1707711665}
review: CIV IV is the crown jewel of the series. I love to do the earth-based scenarios. Gameplay is captivating, almost dangerously addictive. I've downloaded it on 3 computers over the years and rely on it as a way to keep my brain sharp. CIV IV is perhaps the best strategy game of all time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042074547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 30571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1049, 'last_played': 1706770278}
review: This may not be the newest version, but I consider it the best because it does not overly complicate the rules and is extremely addicting.  It is the origin of the "just...one...more..turn" meme for a reason.  Still just an excellent strategy game, and I consider it a classic, much better than Civ V and IV which get overly drawn into multiple themes like religion that drown out the classic conquer strategy.  Five Stars!

author: {'steamid': '76561198067541317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1608716682}
review:
As a HUGE fan of Civ3 with thousands of hours on it back in the day, I was excited for Civ4 when it released. I still have the book but apparently lost the CDs. 

Civ4 was a MAJOR change from Civ3 and serves as the template for the latest Civ games. Civ4 had a huge graphics overhaul from 3 and added many features and changes. At first I was a little "iffy" about the game as I was a die hard Civ3 fan....but Civ4 grew on me and I played it almost as much as Civ3. 

 I won't say Civ4 is the best in the franchise...but it was the turning point in appearance and content from the original first 3. Most game franchises that have a major change like Civ4 made, end up tanking the franchise...but this one survived because it was done right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057362231', 'num_games_owned': 208, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 980, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 980, 'last_played': 1615730998}
review: One of the best Civilization games. Lots of maps, lots of options in the game (religion etc.) one of the most complete package. Didn't play this much when it was released (as i prefered the graphics from Civ3) but it's a great game and not too heavy on computer systems. I play it mostly on my netbook.

–ò–∑ –Ω–µ–¥–æ—Å—Ç–∞—Ç–∫–æ–≤ –º–æ–∂–Ω–æ –æ—Ç–º–µ—Ç–∏—Ç—å —Ç—Ä–∞–¥–∏—Ü–∏–æ–Ω–Ω–æ –Ω–µ–∞–¥–µ–∫–≤–∞—Ç–Ω–æ–µ –ø–æ–≤–µ–¥–µ–Ω–∏–µ –ò–ò (–æ—Å–æ–±–µ–Ω–Ω–æ –ø—Ä–∏ –∏–≥—Ä–µ –Ω–∞ –º–∞—Ä–∞—Ñ–æ–Ω—Å–∫–æ–π —Å–∫–æ—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–∏, –Ω–∞ –æ–≥—Ä–æ–º–Ω—ã—Ö –∫–∞—Ä—Ç–∞—Ö —Å –º–∞–∫—Å–∏–º–∞–ª—å–Ω—ã–º –∫–æ–ª–∏—á–µ—Å—Ç–≤–æ–º –ø—Ä–æ—Ç–∏–≤–Ω–∏–∫–æ–≤), –∞ —Ç–∞–∫–∂–µ ¬´–Ω–µ—á–µ—Å—Ç–Ω—É—é¬ª —Å–ª–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç—å, –ø–æ–≤—ã—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä–æ–π –¥–æ—Å—Ç–∏–≥–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è –Ω–µ –∑–∞ —Å—á–µ—Ç ¬´—Ö–∏—Ç—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–∏¬ª –ò–ò, –∞ –∑–∞ —Å—á–µ—Ç —Å–∏—Å—Ç–µ–º—ã –±–æ–Ω—É—Å–æ–≤ –¥–ª—è –∫–æ–º–ø—å—é—Ç–µ—Ä–Ω—ã—Ö –æ–ø–ø–æ–Ω–µ–Ω—Ç–æ–≤ –∏ —à—Ç—Ä–∞—Ñ–æ–≤ –¥–ª—è –∏–≥—Ä–æ–∫–∞. –ù–æ –æ–±–µ —ç—Ç–∏ –ø—Ä–æ–±–ª–µ–º—ã ‚Äî –±–∏—á –≤—Å–µ–π —Å–µ—Ä–∏–∏, –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä—ã–π —Ä–∞–∑—Ä–∞–±–æ—Ç—á–∏–∫–∏ —É—Å–ø–µ—à–Ω–æ –∏–≥–Ω–æ—Ä–∏—Ä—É—é—Ç –±–æ–ª–µ–µ –¥–≤—É—Ö –¥–µ—Å—è—Ç–∏–ª–µ—Ç–∏–π.

–ù–µ—Å–º–æ—Ç—Ä—è –Ω–∞ —Å–≤–æ–π —Å–æ–ª–∏–¥–Ω—ã–π –≤–æ–∑—Ä–∞—Å—Ç, Sid Meier's Civilization IV –æ—Ç–ª–∏—á–Ω–æ –ø–æ–¥–æ–π–¥–µ—Ç –≤ –∫–∞—á–µ—Å—Ç–≤–µ –æ—Ç–ø—Ä–∞–≤–Ω–æ–π —Ç–æ—á–∫–∏ –¥–ª—è –∑–Ω–∞–∫–æ–º—Å—Ç–≤–∞ —Å —Å–µ—Ä–∏–µ–π, –æ—Å–æ–±–µ–Ω–Ω–æ –µ—Å–ª–∏ –≤–∞—Å –Ω–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å—É–µ—Ç –æ–Ω–ª–∞–π–Ω-–º—É–ª—å—Ç–∏–ø–ª–µ–µ—Ä. –í –æ—Ç–ª–∏—á–∏–µ –æ—Ç –±–æ–ª–µ–µ –Ω–æ–≤—ã—Ö —á–∞—Å—Ç–µ–π, —á–µ—Ç–≤–µ—Ä–∫–∞ –∫—É–¥–∞ –º–µ–Ω–µ–µ —Ç—Ä–µ–±–æ–≤–∞—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–∞ –∫ –∂–µ–ª–µ–∑—É –∏ —Ñ–∏–Ω–∞–Ω—Å–∞–º, –Ω–æ –∑–∞—Ç—è–≥–∏–≤–∞–µ—Ç –Ω–∏—á—É—Ç—å –Ω–µ –º–µ–Ω—å—à–µ.

[b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31260806]–ú–æ—è –ø–æ–ª—É–º–µ—Ä—Ç–≤–∞—è –∫—É—Ä–∞—Ç–æ—Ä—Å–∫–∞—è —Å—Ç—Ä–∞–Ω–∏—á–∫–∞ –Ω–∞ —Ä—É—Å—Å–∫–æ–º[/url][/b].

______________________________________________

When I found out that Civilization IV had been out for a couple of years, I was still playing its predecessor. And if it weren't for the dozens or even hundreds of hours I've spent playing Civ3, coupled with fatigue from its limitations and dumb AI ‚Äî Civ4 could, potentially, became my favourite instalment in the whole series. Looking back, the fourth part seems to be the most polished and competent iteration of the iconic franchise. Especially if you compare the basic versions, without the paid DLC and add-ons, which the creators of the series are so like to abuse nowadays.

Sid Meier's Civilization IV inherited the best features of its predecessors, polished its mechanics and made a lot of small changes and improvements to the well-established formula. Thanks to a much more user-friendly and informative interface, fancier graphics, mature stylistics (hello to cartoonish Civ6 and Revolution) and FullHD resolution support ‚Äî the project looks and plays pleasantly to this day. And the amount of starting content, old and new civilizations, as well as the presence of alternative leaders are surprising. 

Of the drawbacks, I could mention the traditionally inadequate behaviour of the AI (especially when playing at marathon speed on huge maps with the maximum number of opponents), as well as the "unfair" difficulty, which increases not via the "cunning" AI, but through a system of bonuses for computer opponents and penalties for the player. But both of these problems are the scourge of the entire series, which the developers have successfully ignored for over two decades.

Despite its solid age, Sid Meier's Civilization IV is a great starting point for getting to know the series, especially if you're not interested in online multiplayer. Unlike the newer instalments, Sid Meier's IV is much less demanding in terms of hardware and finances but is just as addictive.

[b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/35095872/]My half-dead curator page on broken English[/url][/b].

review: I can't really say anything bad about the Civ series. Sid Meier is an absolute genius to think up a series to not only entertain, but to teach history and how civilizations came to be and, not only that, the theme "Baba Yetu" is absolutely killer. I could listen to it all day! If you haven't played a Civ game before, I suggest picking up this one, if it's still being made, and its successors. You won't regret it.

review:
Meiner Meinung nach ist Sid Meier's Civilization IV ein super Spiel, ich habe pers√∂nlich mit dem V Teil der Reihe angefangen und finde hier Klasse das man zB Einheiten Stapeln kann und eine Richtige Armee damit aufbauen kann, das auch mehr Diplomatie M√∂glichkeiten bestehen usw.
Ich finde aber auch dieses Spiel herausfordernd da die KI gerade wenn man das Spiel noch nicht so gut kennt ziemlich einen Druck machen kann und man immer schauen muss das man nicht zur√ºck f√§llt.
Kurz und knapp jeder der was mit Civi anfangen kann, wird mit dem Teil nichts falsch machen! ^^

review:
I actually far prefer Beyond the Sword, but I've logged quite a few hours in Civ IV outside of Steam, it's an incredible game that, true to it's nature as a Civ game, consumes your life without you realizing it. The graphics by this point are obviously rather outdated but it's a game nearly old enough to start driving in the US and their low fidelity doesn't really subtract from the experience (you're not staring at each model close up). Overall, I would rate the game rather highly and recommend it to people even if it is two releases out of date.

Also, fun story with tech support, I received this copy (and the DLC) for free, I owned the discs and a while back wanted to move the game to Steam, slight issue, Steam didn't exist when the discs were made, so I contacted support, they requested that I send in an image with all of the discs, about a couple hours later lo and behold I now had a nice story to tell and a genuinely good experience with customer support, something that's pretty rare to come by.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964923627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 200477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62906, 'last_played': 1707686658}
review:
I've owned all versions of Civilization, and this is the last of, what I consider, the true Civilization games.  This game allows you to, not only build cities, but to build armies as well.  You can have wars, and not have to worry about the one unit per tile limitation.   You can have a small civilization with a large army.  It doesn't take 300 years to build 1 unit, so you can build an army.

If you want to select which building you want your cities to have, and then hit <next turn> fifty times, you'll want Civ V or VI.  If you want to play Civilization, you'll want this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198404393385', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6534, 'last_played': 1689448954}
review:
Awesome game, unlike many other games from 'it's time' it has bearable graphics. Also, the graphics don't impact how you play as it isn't a shooter game or anything fast paced. The game is now 15 years old and runs relatively smoothly only freezing every now and again if you click the 'next turn' button too quickly.
The game itself is a strategy game that I have loved loads, easy to learn even though at the begining you will be utterly hopeless. There are multiple playstyle options and you can choose the way the AI civilisations behave when you start the game. 
You save the game in your PC's files and can have multiple civilisations (different games) saved at the same time, meaning you don't have to worry about losing your progress if you want to start again to try a new stratagey!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970562615', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1619223635}
review:
For me this is the best Civ game, too much to list why. One can quick scan other reviews and for most I'd agree. Ignore the low play time, I easily have over 400 hrs. (I missed out on the Steam key trade in program.)  
One day, I got a hankering for some 'real' Civilization so grabbed on Steam sale. Eventually, I hope to install my CD version onto an off line PC just for old games.

What hurts 4 versus 5 and 6 is that technology and media distribution has changed, so I miss what the 2 newer ones actually improved. I am having to reteach myself the old ways of Civ. 
I can't run UHD resolution,crashes my game but that's fine, game still looks good and runs well at standard HD. Plus, one gets to hear Lenoard Nimoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198409082726', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1600024255}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198119428064', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5844, 'last_played': 1708518050}
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization IV, kurz Civ IV, ist der vierte Teil der Civilization Reihe. Da ich lediglich Civ IV und Civ VI gespielt habe, kann ich wenige vergleiche zu den Vorg√§ngern ziehen. 

Das Gameplay besteht aus dem Managen, erschaffen und Zerst√∂ren von Einheiten und St√§dten. Die St√§dte stellen den Kern des Spiels dar, dort werden Geb√§ude und Einheiten errichtet. Um die Bauzeit verschiedenster Produktionen zu beschleunigen, kann man in den St√§dten Bautrupps errichten. Diese modifizieren die Felder um die Stadt herum mit diversen Geb√§uden und Einrichtungen. Um weitere Truppen und Geb√§ude freizuschalten, muss man forschen. Die Forschungsb√§ume sind umfangreich und an die Zeitalter, welche das Spiel abdecken m√∂chte, akkurat angepasst. 

Das Kampfgameplay, h√§ngt beinahe ausschlie√ülich von den Feldern, auf denen sich die Einheiten befinden, und den Spezifischen Kombinationen der Einheiten ab. Beinahe jede der Einheiten besitzt Felder mit Boni. Ebenfalls wichtig, sind die Einheiten welche aufeinander treffen, so sind Lanzentr√§ger beispielsweise st√§rker gegen Kavallerie als gegen Infanterie. Bei einem aufeinandertreffen zweier verfeindeter Einheiten, werden nun also die Felder beider Einheiten ber√ºcksichtigt, welche, genau wie die Kombination der Aufeinandertreffenden, Modifikationen zur Grundst√§rke der Einheiten bieten. Aus der Differenz dieser St√§rke wird dann eine Siegwahrscheinlichkeit vor dem Angriff eingeblendet. 

Die Grafik des Spiels ist den Umst√§nden entsprechend gut, und vor allem der Artstyle, ist allen anderen Teilen der Reihe √ºberlegen. 

Das Online-Gameplay ist simpel einzurichten und l√§sst sich jederzeit Lokal sicher um zu einem sp√§teren Zeitpunkt weiterzuspielen. 

F√ºr weitere Infos zum Spiel, kann ich nur Gameplayvideos empfehlen.

review:
Baba Yetu!

There's a lot to love with Civ IV. The thing with Civ V is that it pretty much threw out all the tradition that Civ had had up until this point. Every game and expantion was pretty much just an extention of the last game in the series. As a result, this game probably isn't very easy to get into. There's a lot of bagage that comes with this game. But if you can get past that, there's a lot of depth and enjoyment to be had.

author: {'steamid': '76561198321298211', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1642440518}
review:
Long ago, I had this game as a hard copy, and it was a major part of my childhood. I wound up getting this game again during the Summer Sale for nostalgia, and was pleasantly surprised to find it still held up 15 years (!) after release!


Music: Great quality, great selection, not to mention the Grammy-winning "Baba Yetu" as the main menu theme. 9/10.

Graphics: Dated, but very well detailed on max settings. Mods like Blue Marble exist that push things even further. 7/10.

Gameplay: Many consider this the best Civ game, including me. Civ IV gave this series its modern look and feel, and it is a formula that is still in use even with Civ VI, 15 years later. Where this loses its point is the lack of an interactive tutorial for new Civ players, but the Civilopedia is useful to help with this. 9/10.

Learning curve: Easy if you've played a Civ game before, hard to learn if you haven't. The Civilopedia has some info, but you'll need to figure some stuff out yourself. 7/10


Final Point Tally: 32/40 (Excellent)

Final Verdict: Buy this game. The expansions are not needed but will enhance the playthrough further, though they are not compatible with each other (to my knowledge). I had some issues downloading Beyond the Sword right away, though leaving it in your account for a few days should be enough to get it to work.

review:
I have played Part IV for several years, I still find it to be the best of the Civilizations ever and it ranks at the top with Age of Empires II which is another game I just cannot get enough of.

Kudos to the Dev's for making Civ IV, I'm a long time gamer going back to games like Manhunter in New York, Police Quest Series, Hero's Quest Series (now called Quest for Glory), Wing Commander Series, Leisure suit larry Series and the likes.

Thank you for awesome games and keep it up.
