review: I pretty much didn't consider this game at all due to having Civ V and Civ VI. But boy, I'm pleased I purchased it. And what a bargain at 75% off. Very indepth game - which is common to all Civ games, but this one definitely is a bit more comprehensive. I've started off with the "vanilla" base game, and after learning the ropes I will launch the second expansion (which holds the vanilla and 1st and 2nd expansions). Great game.

review: I'm gonna get a lot of heat for this, but I didn't actually enjoy Civ IV that much. I love the music, the game looks good but playing against mime leaders is boring. I'm not a big fan of the religion concept in this game either and the combat seems off, making hard to know if you'll win or not. The narrator is awesome because it's Spock, so there is some stuff to like, but I'd honestly recommend Civ V instead of CIv IV.

review: I've had this game as a hard copy since the late 2000's (I think I bought it in '09). I've logged well over 3,000 hours over the last 11 years. Recently, I got a computer that didn't allow me to play CD's without having to buy extra hardware. Now, I am a lazy piece of trash and there's NO WAY I'm going to put forth the effort to go to Office Max to buy a new CD drive just for this purpose. So, I bought the game on Steam. It is still BY FAR the best Civilization game in existence.

review:
This game is ok, but Civ 3 is better imo.
Civ 4 is overly complicated and the amount of techs and unit/building types is overwhelming.
Sometimes less is more, and this is definitely one of the times when less would be more, but I'll still probably play the game occasionally to hear Leonard Nimoy's voice.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993023804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 524, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1584217423}
review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#333 out of 612)... it's time for Civilization IV.

It's a bit hard to talk about Civilization IV today. In many ways, Civilization IV is, you see, arguably the last genuinely great Civilization game. In many ways, its successor, Civilization V, is a superior game--more polished, more focused, with greater depth and better balance--and the definitive Civilization experience. But at the same time, I can't help but lament how unambitious subsequent Civilization games are--and that lack of ambition seems to be a patter currently affecting all of developer Firaxis' output. Rough around the edges though it may be, Civilization IV is still a fantastically engrossing and addictive turn-based grand strategy game, with hugely ambitious standalone expansions that radically transform the core rules and mechanics. Going back into Civilization IV today, one might be disappointed by the lack of modern polish--most especially the absence of tooltips and proliferation of awkward iconography in their stead--but despite it's self-evident age, I think Civilization IV still stands proud as a landmark 4x game.

And if Civilization IV on its own does not merit revisiting in the wake of Civilization V, its expansions--most notably Beyond the Sword--most certainly do.

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.

review: Best game ever made. I recommend playing the basic version first and gradually adding exapnsions as you learn the game mechanics. The fact that it's extremely well balanced means there are lots of different ways to play, the most appropriate depending in the given generated world. There are also some interesting mods available, but just the basic game will give you hundreds of hours of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060429756', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1579714531}
review:
This game, is probably as good as Civ III, but is better in other ways, like the graphics are much better obviously. But, also coz you can zoom in now on the world map and on units. You can still stack units in this game, which i love to do. I mean, lets face it, who doesnt like stacking a hundred units to continually pillage other cities, or to just wipe them from the map. 
I have probably around 100 hours in game time playing this game, but for me, i had the non steam version, so steam never kept track of those hours when i bought the steam version. And why i bought the steam version, was coz oneday, i think it was last year, i went to have a game of Civ IV non steam version, but Microsoft had done a update to Windows 10, and it essentially killed the non steam version of the game, so i had to rebuy the game on steam.
The pros :
The tech tree is pretty extensive with heaps of different technologies to research.
Heaps of different units to make.
Different scenarios to try.
Nice visuals for its era.
Nice soundtrack (if thats your cup of tea....or coffee) :)
Different lengths of game time to play, I.e; play a marathon length game or a quick length time game.  With marathon, it takes more turns to research items, to build improvements,etc. Where as quick games, the research, build times, etc are cut down so you can play more quickly, advance more quickly,etc.
Several DLC's to choose from...Or buy the complete edition where you get all dlc's included with base game.
Repeatability in playing the game over and over again.
Community modding content available. 

The cons : 
The DLC's...I have never agreed with a company that makes games, and then releases DLC's as an added extra purchase. I think thats just being greedy and the companies taking advantage of us players.  
The ONLY time i dont mind companies doing that, is if you are buying add on's for a MMO that i might play, which in turn keeps that game going. 
But not these sort of games where you buy the game, the DLC's SHOULD come with the base game. Its like they are charging us 2,3,4,5 times for the same game. With that being said, im going to contradict myself and tell you to go look at my profile and see how many DLC's i own :D.....Just because i dont agree with their methods, doesnt mean i wont buy their DLC's ;)
There are a few minor bugs in the game. But nothing game breaking. For worst case, its a visual bug, where the units, instead of walking to the next tiles, its like they just vanish and appear on the next tiles. Sort of like a warp i guess. Or if they do move to next tiles, they dont walk, they slide. 
Or, for me anyway with this one, i cant watch the intro of the gmae and then play the game, it just flat out crashes every time. Soon as the 2K logo shows up on screen, i have to click the mouse button to skip it to get to main menu. OR watch the entirety of the into and wait for it to load the main menu..Again, nothing game breaking. 

My thoughts :
Its still a great game in its own right. Civ VI offers non stackable units where as Civ IV allows stacking, so, its almost 2 different games with 2 different strategies for the player. 
Still has plenty of life in it along with plenty of entertaining hours of gameplay in it. 
Well worth purchasing if you like turn based games. 
Score : 8 out 10

review: The music is the best compared to the music in the Civilization series in my opinion, it's the thing that got me excited to play it as often as I do. Civ4, even if it doesn't look great compared to the modern Civilization games, it still plays just as well, if not better, than the other games. It's not that I hate the other games, I love the more modern ones to shreds, it's that I love this game because it started my love for the series and that can't be changes no matter how much time passes

review:
I played CIV 3 foreverrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr. Finally gave part 4 a good try. I like it.

edit: BUG: It has trouble launching from within Steam. Workaround is to launch it in Steam so it shows it is running (the process also shows in task manager, yet no game is seen anywhere), and then launch it a second time using the Civilization4.exe file or a shortcut thereof.

ALSO, make sure mouse trailing is turned off in your Windows mouse settings or you will not have a visible cursor to use within the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012473463', 'num_games_owned': 4062, 'num_reviews': 417, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1485367531}
review:
[h1]Follow our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/36214917/]Curator Group for more reviews[/url][/h1]
Civilization IV is, for me, the peak of the Civilization franchise. It's much more accessible and user friendly than the first 3 games, but isn't overly streamlined like the most recent games. It can be played casually and you can still get a lot of enjoyment out of it, but you can go deep into the micromanagement of it and make the game a lot more complicated, if that's how you prefer to play your strategy games. This flexibility is another of its strongest aspects, which is heightened due to the extensive modding community. It is the largest and most active modding community across the entire franchise (in my experience). There are some truly amazing mods that can completely change how the game is played and what it's about. My personal favorite would be Caveman 2 Cosmos. It has 5 times the technologies of the base game, which expands each era into its own small game of Civ. It is extremely long and adds dozens of new mechanics, so it might be too much of an overhaul for some people, although I still recommend giving it a shot.

10/10 (with Caveman 2 Cosmos mod)
[quote]
Visit our [url=https://www.mmmreviews.com]website[/url] for more in-depth reviews and recommendations
[/quote]

review: Ich habe im Alter von 7 Jahren, auf dem Steam-Account meines Vaters, das erste mal dieses Spiel gespielt. Heute, einige Jahre sp√§ter, spiele ich das Spiel immer noch. Es ist ein klassisches und anspruchvolles (je nach Schwierigskeitstufe) Strategiespiel Spiel mit vielen Addons. Die Grafik ist f√ºr das Alter des Spiels auch noch sehr gut (Ver√∂ffentlichung: 2005). Ich pers√∂nlich finde das Spiel wesentlich besser als die Nachfolger, da mir diese Grafisch nicht zusagen und auf mich sehr un√ºbersichtlich wirken. Au√üerdem gef√§llt mir die "Nur eine Einheit pro Feld Systematik" bei den Nachfolgern nicht. Der Soundtrack des 4. Teils gef√§llt mir auch am besten. Ich finde der Kauf dieses Spiels lohnt sich auch heute noch.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990453351', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 969, 'playtime_forever': 1459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1459, 'last_played': 1504897366}
review:
The main things I don't like about this are how slow it is to play, and the main gripe, the ridiculous numbers of units needed to conquer an enemy city, yet if the enemy has horse archer or elephant he'll take your city in one attack. In theory the idea of experience and strength/attack improvements is good, but you get ridiculous situations of attacking a city and your tanks are getting wiped out by defending archers!!!! This is at Chieftan level, the second lowest. The graphics are pretty but I'd take Civ 2 any day as its better as a game. I almost feel I want to buy an old XP machine just to get back to Civ 2. The sounds and graphics are nice but this game has serious flaws. 

Besides, game doesn't run in a window, and it isn't too fond of windows 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031480148', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 161, 'last_played': 1648358287}
review:
Although my Steam clock has only about 2 hours on this, I owned this game years before and can comfortably say that I have put in a lot more than that. 
This game was probably the best of the Civilization series. It was before the franchise moved to a hexagonal board and got rid of the stacking elements. So in some ways it is not as interesting as newer incarnations. But in other ways, this was the high-point of the franchise, with balanced units, challenging AI, and great concepts that were either innovative to the series or were entirely unique. I loved this game and still do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121331791', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2321, 'last_played': 1560268469}
review:
I wanted to change this review, after playing more I now recommend it.  So much good work went into this game.  From the graphics to the sounds to the gameplay.  While its not perfect I believe it is worth it for a low price.  I prefer this game over all other Civ computer games, although Civilization Revolution is by far my favorite it is only for console and I am tired of playing it.  I have played it so much.  I have also played Civ 4 PC a lot, way more than steam shows, because I also have the CD version of the game installed.  That is because I prefer to mod it and the steam version is not as mod-friendly IMO.  Although it can be I suppose if you install it to something like C:\civ4\ or some easily accessed directory.   Being able to modify most aspects of this game is really awesome.  It really is a game changer.

I have figured out that if you use custom continents and use tiny map and 4+ continents and only 2 other civs the game can be quite good.  It is a grind though.  I wish I had another human to play this with it would be awesome, however it is a huge time commitment and you will find it extremely hard to find someone to commit that time at the same time, as you.

Also I have modified the XML to remove all leader traits and change a couple unbalanced early game units.

I am liking a lot of the music in this game now, but not all of it, but I am modifying that as well since you can easily replace the MP3's in the game folder.

Well below here is my negative review, it is kind of funny, but true..  after I finished my first super long space race victory game..... space race in this game isnt for me, it's very tedious and feels like a chore, espcially compared  to Civ revolutions.... I was super suprised at all the global warming near the end of the game, LOL, I guess it was because of all my coal plants and and a few nukes detonated over China capital, lol... I have now modified the global warming chance also in the XML files.... seriously though it was out of control there was like 3-4 tiles every turn turning to desert in my main cities and it was pissing me off big time...
------------------gonna leave it for fun---------------


I have bought this but mainly played Warlords, however it is basically the same thing.  As a huge fan of Civilization 3, I wanted to like this game so much.  The graphics are well done, and the camera does not allow rotation which I much prefer in any strategy game.

  Of course the first thing I noticed is the game is totally unbalanced.  The Africans get an attacking unit right at the start that can move 2 spaces and other civs cant move 2 spaces for like 200 more turns.  The "industrious" leaders all get a +50 or is it 100% bonus to great wonder building speed.  Why is that unbalanced?  Well because this game is 70% building great wonders there is a great wonder for almost every technology.  These types of things are  unacceptable in a strategy game really and I noticed they have all been fixed in Civ 6.  Well, what I did is I modified the XML files of this game.  It is surprisingly modifiable and that is a plus.  Of course you can't modify a lot of things and it is a hassle to figure out.

Okay lets talk about the audio.  You have Nimoy narrating which is fine with me, but when he tries to joke, awkward.  The sounds when managing cities, which you have to do alot, are annoying.  The music system is rediculous.  So what happens is it plays the "world theme" unless you zoom in, and then it plays your "civilization theme."  It gets louder and softer depending on your zoom level, and there is a spot in between where it plays no music basically.  This is also the spot where the graphics look the best but its still playable.  Now if you play it zoomed out like most you are going to find the "world theme" to be not very good, and when it changes to the modern age you will have some disturbing modern classical "doomed world" theme to listen to.

Speaking of doomed world, the game tries very hard to make it feel that way, closer you get to the end, you will be bombarded with GLOBAL WARMING destroying your cities I kid you not.  Also on the "Internet" wonder they have a picture of AL GORE and I think they paid him to be in the game and use his global warming MYTH that I guess he has a copyright on?

Now lets talk AI.  The AI is just as bad if not worse than Civ 3.  Barbarians appear out of nowhere anywhere there is fog of war, as do other civilizations that attack you.  I don't think other civilizations have to even research or produce units in their cities at all.  Their units just show up out of the fog of war after a certain amount of turns.  Modifying XML files probably does not even affect a computer controlled opponent.  When in war, they will have maybe one invasion force, if you defeat that or they cant land or regardless they are going to go around just destroying your fishing boats and fishing spots.  Most annoying thing ever and not fun.  The AI will never attack you, until about 1850 AD and if you are winning, and then of course they will always declare war on you.  The enemy moves don't animate properly most of the time, leading to enemy just magically appearing without the camera tracking them or even showing them at all.  Due to the way the game shows multiple units there can be a huge force under one weak unit and you cannot tell.

Other forms of victory like space race is way too difficult and then the game just ends with no reward but a short crappy cutscene of you staring at earth from a window.  Nukes are underpowered and unsatisfying.  If you play the game with "standard" size map get ready for your game to last 100+ hours.  The map size changes on the type you choose and its really hard to create the right size map.  There are in reality no random maps there are continents, pangea, or waterworld, and one called fractal which I have found just creates continents or pangea.  I like to play maps with both continents and smaller islands and this game will not generate a map like that.

I highly recommend Civilization Revolutions over this, a great game for xbox 360, not perfect but way way better.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990562257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 228, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1558895935}
review: Civilization IV has a ridiculous amount of strategic elements packed into it. Firaxis have managed to thoroughly overhaul one of the classic games of all time and drag it up from its dark ages into the renaissance era. Even with its speedier gameplay Civ IV will be the cause of many sleepless nights and damaged relationships. No more micromanagement, diplomacy is finally easy to understand and combat is more rational than ever before. Between the multitude of challenges that players must overcome in the single player campaign, the mods that can be made and played with the included World Builder and the ever-changing multiplayer scene, I am happy to say that Civilization IV should hold the attention of the strategy gamer for months to come. It's worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999635090', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1558752398}
review: Good game, don't get me wrong: excellent addition to the series in its time and an advancement in many ways (moddability, in particular) over its predecessor. Note, however: everything in this game is also in the follow-on standalone game Civilization 4: Beyond the Sword, so you can either buy the compilation pack or just buy Civ 4:BtS standalone, also on Steam, if you're looking for the best value for money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198327309184', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 13696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2565, 'last_played': 1707554959}
review:
I don't know what to say. This game is so good, it is ruining my life and I have to uninstall it for now. First time I installed it, (it was about 11 pm) I wanted to test it for about 40 minutes or 1 hour at max, next thing I remember is sun lighting up my room.

And last time, I played it for 1,5 days straight (as you know, you can continue after time victory), only slept couple of hours, the computer was on and the game was running for the whole time.

Goodbye Civilization IV. Farewell.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002608541', 'num_games_owned': 6122, 'num_reviews': 214, 'playtime_forever': 136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1617978954}
review:
This is one of the best Civilization game in the Civilization series. For those of you who dislike units occupying only one tile, Civilization IV is the last game in which multiple units can occupy the same tile. Moreover, the graphics in this game is great for a 2005 game and it runs flawlessly on modern systems. 

After about 14 years since Civilization IV was released, this game has aged beyond expectations. Highly recommended for hardcore strategy fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112173506', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1556136098}
review: Great game! I played countless hours off my CD version, and bought this as a backup (what's that tell you?).  This was the last great civ game before 5 came out, has all the moving parts you need/want.  I think every civ fan I ever talked to came back here after trying 5, it's kind of the dud of the series.  Civ 4 or Civ IV was the last great version, and beyond the sword was the final expansion pack, so you can try the base version if you want, but you'll want the extras in beyond the sword before long.  Ps. Difficulty-settler is for learning/practice, and noble has you on equal footing with the AI, you're welcome!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030335347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 28560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28560, 'last_played': 1543551546}
review:
I've played Civ IV, Civ V, and Civ VI, and this is the runaway winner for the best strategy game.

What I want from a game is frequently being given lots of not-obvious decisions that matter, where the right answer can be deduced through careful thought and thorough knowledge of the game.  I'm wanting a game where these choices matter far more than the dice.  What I don't particularly care about are the graphics, the story, or the "emersive experience" of feeling like I'm really talking to Cleopatra.

In Civ IV, one worker option is cottages, which are the short-term loss/long-term gain option.  Civ IV balances it well enough that thinking long term isn't necessarily the right choice; you have to assess the odds of a war within 10-50 turns and think about it.

Another home-run is the civics.  Many of the options are niche-strategies, but collectively, it's likely that you should eventually choose a niche.  For instance, one average, theocracy is bad.  But sometimes, a war is coming, and the free experience motivates building an army and crushing someone.  Even in games where I don't do this, the fact that I had this option looming over every single turn from turns 100-200 drives home how open ended the game is for players who want to explore the frontiers of just how high of a difficulty level can be beaten.

Also more so than Civ V and VI, I find myself taking different tech paths each time, which helps keep the game fresh and different each time.  In Civ V, I quickly felt like I had found the "right" strategy, and was now only testing to see how far it could take me.  In Civ IV, I've never felt like I've mastered it, or even close.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024793242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 798, 'last_played': 1554566171}
review:
What kind of civilization do [i]you[/i] want to build? Figure it out turn after turn in Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ IV as you follow the 4X empire-building model. Explore, expand, exploit, and exterminate!

It's hard to believe that this classic entry in Sid Meier's legendary strategy franchise is already almost 15 years old. It honestly holds up today and there are plenty of options to customize gameplay and make things feel comfortable for a variety of players. There's so much to do - so many strategies and builds to explore in this game, and I've barely scratched the surface, but I still enjoy playing it on a casual basis.

I got this game for $3.64 as part of the Civ IV "complete edition" bundle on sale. Definitely got my money's worth already and I look forward to trying the expansions!

author: {'steamid': '76561198052961058', 'num_games_owned': 93, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1654634415}
review:
The game that started it all for me. Timeless game, brings back lots of good memories of crushing Gandhi and Montezuma.

[u]Graphics[/u]:
By now the graphics are a bit dated, though the relative simplicity retains its charm. Nothing better than seeing your Panzer tanks tearing through barbarian warriors wielding those chunky clubs.

[u]Gameplay[/u]:
Turn based. Strategically place your cities to maximize growth and production, while seeking out game changing resources like iron, coal, and oil. Produce workers and settlers to work and expand your territory, various military units to give your empire the edge on the battlefield, and buildings to give your cities vital perks. Construct wonders grant bonuses and give an edge in many areas. Research technologies that boost your advantage over your neighbors. Spread your religion(s) through your own lands and those of other civilizations, giving you a common cause. 

[u]Soundtrack[/u]:
One of the parts that makes the game timeless. Immerses you in the current age, from beating on tribal drums to [i]Miserere mei Deus[/i] to Piano Concerto no. 20. And who could ever forget Civ IV's theme?

Even so many years later, Civilization IV is a classic. Lots of replayability, with two DLC that add new civilizations, units, wonders and scenarios. Full price or on sale, worth your pennies. 

[u]Score[/u]: [b]9/10[/b]

review: This game is simply put wonderful.  If your coming to this from civ 5 or 6 combat is a little different.  Army units can stack into a single tile and move about so make sure to check all enemy army stacks to see what their moving on your border.

author: {'steamid': '76561198801725697', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 796, 'last_played': 1555520924}
review:
Great Game, I've played so much! Probaly one of the best Turn-Based games ever. I can't wait to play civ 5 and 6!

Edit: Now that I've played for almost 19 hours and have played civ 5 and 6, I would still say this is the best one. The amount of care and work that you can see went into the game is shown threw out the game. The AI is great, exploration is a lot of fun, my farvote being over seas exploring, playing with other people is a bit slow, but once you get used to it, it becomes a lot better. I would wait until a sale to get this game, and all of its expansions. I hope I clock in even more hours! Happy playing you all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198309270986', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1530135725}
review:
(Don't be fooled by my playtime, I played this game wayyyy back then on cd-rom for hundreds of hours)

An absolute classic of a game. The Rhyes and fall of Civilization -mod is particularly fantastic and brings so many good memories. Civ 5 might be more polished overall, but Civ 4 has some very cool features that make it a unique experience. I would recommend this game to all Civ fans who for some reason haven't played it yet, or for fans of strategy games in general.

author: {'steamid': '76561198345503421', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 27498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14708, 'last_played': 1615783013}
review:
Probably the most addictive game I've ever played. The gameplay is pretty self-explanatory: you get to control a build one of the myriad world civilizations, and you must defend it and defeat your opponent. There are different ways to defeat your enemy, but it must be done before the time limit elapses. This s a turn-based game, which means after you play your turn, the computer plays its turn, and so on. Lots of different resources are available, for example gold, fish, iron, copper, ivory, stone, and more. With the passage of time, your civilization progresses from stone age all the way to the modern age. 

One of the major drawbacks of this game is the amount of effort and time that one must spend on managing the myriad resources in your territory; for example, if you assign villagers to cut down a forest, you must constantly check whether they have finished cutting a particular patch of the forest. After they are done, you have to order them to cut another patch of forest, for they will not do it automatically. Also there are so many different technologies and warrior upgrades available that it is very difficult to keep track of the prerequisites for each. For example, if I want to upgrade my arrowmen to crossbowmen, I must meticulously research the technologies/warrior required to get it done in the right sequence.  While the AI in this game is incredible, the difficulty of the game is extremely frustrating. Personally, I could not go past the third level of difficulty because of the ENDLESS twists and turns. And as I have mentioned before, this game is INSANELY addictive. For this reason I think the cons of this game outweight its pros. I eventually stopped playing this game and probably won't resume.

author: {'steamid': '76561198349507144', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 56118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29541, 'last_played': 1566260424}

author: {'steamid': '76561198170544263', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 7539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7097, 'last_played': 1575274086}
review:
It is a world cvilizations build game. A turn based strategy game where you will erect your country and lead it trougth the flow of time.
Do you will be able to master the history?

In my opinion it is the best game of the civ brand.
In this one is introduced for the first time the world religions aspect, that was absent in civ III, are perfected the government forms meccanics (is up to you what to chose), the diplomacy with other nations and the different resources that you can find on the world map.
All those aspects are related togheter and more tattical oriented.
The tecnological tree is more deep and interconnected. To search for a tecnolgy, before of an other, have a real strategical meaning now.
The militar units choice is more tattical then civ 3 and 5. You can put more then 1 unit for square and you have to chose the unit on the base of the use you will do of it, giving so a deeper strategy  then the other games where a tecnological advanced militar unit was taking all others obsolete and meaningless.
Plus is added a better veteran promotion bonuses sistem.

You can personalize your games in many aspects, you can set the game speed and dimension on your taste.
There is a multiplayer section where you can iven play in two players directly on your computer.


Rating: 8.5/10 The best of the civ brand!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035649391', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1704412388}
review: This game is extremely good, and has unique parts to it that aren't exactly in 5 or 6. It feels like the development of the cities is more realistic at the start, especially in the countrysides due to the whole cottage/hamlet/village/town aspect. That is so interesting to me, that you can build the beginnings of villages and towns. Civ 5 is great too, as it has a darker feel, and the strategy of single unit per hex is great. The ideologies make for some incredible end game world wars. Civ 6 did a nice job on the city regions, like campuses and so on. But if you want something simple that will surprise you if you've only played 5 and 6, then try Civ 4. For me, the lack of villages and towns in Civ 5 and 6 was always sort of confusing to me. I kept wondering if they were just implied within the farming communities or what. But Civ 4 eased my wounds. Oh and you can take over barbarian cities that spawn near your country and count as actual annexed cities. Enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198206886068', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1552169837}
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization is one of the most valuable and crucial game series, and pratically introduced the idea of being a leader of a small tribe, then to become a grand and modern civilization, with many ethnicities and cities under your domain.

Sid Meier's Civilization IV, however, was the crucial turning point of the game series, aesthetic and graphics-wise. Civilization IV also brung in new features such as a built-in and accessible World Editor, where you can assemble maps, and simultaneously place nukes in 2000BC to annihilate Gandhi incase he gains nuclear technology in the distant future.
It also brung in actual terrain, like hills, grasslands, 3D forests, mountains and even moving rivers! It also brought a huge modding community dedicated to updating this game with their own, such as Realism Invictus and Rhye's and Fall of Civilization.

Nonetheless, Civilization IV has some bad things. It essentially lost it's sterness and a little bit of realism after the implementation of easily accessible cheats, and kinda looks like something a young player would be on, hours and hours during the day. 

In conclusion, Civilization IV is the default turning point of Civilization, and effected the recent games such as Civilization V and VI. It brought a huge modding community and a likeness graphically and aesthetically. I would recommend this game for all ages, as it is fun and quite a time killer.

review: I have played Civ 5 just about to death....so I thought since I can't afford Civ 6 yet, I'll try Civ 4.  Meh.  It's okay, almost okay, okay-ish.  Actually, to be honest, it was almost torture.  I read a review somewhere that said that Civ 3 is better than 4.  What, said I?  Well, after the disappointment of 4, I took the plunge and tried 3 because who can beat that price?!?  BETTER.  SO much better.  Oodles better.  Not 5 by any means, but I'd buy 3 loooonnnnnggg before I bought 4 if I were you.

review: For me this has probably been the most appealing of the five PC Civilisation titles I've invested time into over many years now - from the Commodore Amiga days initially - other players may well disagree but I believe IV captures the complexity of the other PC titles whilst adding an interface and presentation slightly more akin to the console release Civ Revolution, which was a really fun game in it's own right if not on a par with the rest of the series due to obvious technical limitation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198234749728', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1498279795}
review:
Are you a loser with too much free-time?
More importantly, are you autistic?
Do you hate dumbed-down games?

Then this game is for you!
Pros:
[list]
[*]Extreme modding flexibility. You can do some slight modification with XML, but man, you can do A LOT with python. The engine is so robust that you can play a fantasy world (Fall From Heaven 2), a civil war (RevolutionDCM), the neolithic age (Caveman2Cosmos) and so much more.
[*]Cities have their own identity. There's no bullcrap about some third world colony somehow making your citizens mad; not every war is Vietnam. Not to mention, culture is actually culture, foreign nationals will hate you and want to return to their country. This is further enhanced by RevolutionDCM.
[*]Your empire-building choices are diverse. There's no single answer to every choice you make; you have to design your cities to develop your country. You can move towards having industrial powerhouses, settle cities specifically for commerce and tax money, settle in far lands to establish cultural dominance, establish a corporate center, fill your coffers with the tithe of a holy city, feed your citizens specifically to enslave them, and so on and so forth. You have to work for your +50 gold, not click on some OP religious bonus.
[*]Your government is flexible. Communism and Fascism isn't fully fleshed out in the game probably for fear of poltical backlash, but all of the obsolete policies before modern government do have their merits. A caste system helps you with making sure you have a lot of merchants, slavery ensures you have fast production, mercantilism makes sure the benefits of trade isn't shared with your enemies.
[*]There is a war before war. Civ4 espionage and diplomacy is especially well-developed as there's no such thing as simple friend or enemy. Political blocs do exist, and there will be civs that support your power to ensure their safety, but they all have their intrigue to make sure you're not too powerful. Information war and proper war-planning exists in this game; if you don't have vision of your enemy's cities or units, you might end up with a severe counter of axemen destroying your swordsmen. Destroying your rival's economy can be done through espionage as well as poisoning the wells of their wonderful cities can hold them back, and yes, there is a chance for you to destroy a 1-turn progress towards building a wonder.
[/list]
Cons:
[list]
[*]You need to think. Civ4 isn't dumbed down for the wide market like Civ5 or Civ6.
[*]You will lose track of time.
[*]No Steam workshop. This is an old game.
[*]Old graphics, but with the right mods it can be repaired.
[*]Turn times may get very slow, especially with huge mods like Caveman2Cosmos.
[/list]
Overall, I would only recommend this to gamers who know strategy or history very well. In my opinion, I think playing without victory conditions can be very fun as role-playing countries can be a wonderful experience, and developing mods can be a joy as Civ4 becomes your alternative history simulator.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 5894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5894, 'last_played': 1533806716}
review:
Tags: TBS - Turn Based Strategy
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Vanilla version of CivIV:Beyond the Sword. Play that instead for better covert ops, quest lines and more.

Civilization IV is a great place to go back to when wanting to see older mechanics and design choices in this series. However, given that the vanilla version of Civ IV is a simplified, more accessible version of Beyond the Sword. It is difficult to recommend it over the more recent Civilization games which also streamline those designs and mechanics.

So my recommendation would be to play a more modern Civ if you need to get past the learning curve or get familiar again with the basic mechanics, or go to Beyond the Sword for the full experience instead. 

https://store.steampowered.com/app/8800/Civilization_IV_Beyond_the_Sword/

author: {'steamid': '76561198049801693', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 11314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10623, 'last_played': 1532213960}
review:
What more is there to say? It's a Civilization¬Æ game! You should know what to expect from this game but for those who do not know what Civilization is, here it is.

Civilization lets you take control of the first settlers who founded a nation on earth. Of course, not every nation is represented but the most important ones are. As you take control, you start in roughly 4000 BC. From there, you must expand your civilization by colonising new lands or capturing enemy cities. As you progress through time, you can research new technologies that benefit your empire. You empire is more than the sum of all of your cities and you also have technology, diplomatic relations, influence over land, terrain improvements and governement policies. You are the master of your civilization and how you play will dictate history itself.

In this version of Cilization, you have a 3D world for the first time. The graphics look nice and are obviously improved from Civ III. I haven't found any bugs in the game and the music is fantastic. They've used classical music mostly and it sounds great. There is no unit customization but the game has faction-specific units. As an example, the Americans have SEAL infantry, with unique strenghts. Otherwise, there are new wonders to build and the religious buildings are religion-specific. 

Overall a fantastic game, had a lot of fun. My 188h of playtime attest to that!

author: {'steamid': '76561197987809189', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1670864621}
review:
Esto de jugar offline y que no te cuenta el tiempo casi no me deja rese√±arlo. En fin, al turr√≥n:

El mejor Civilization al que he jugado, y mejora con las expansiones (y he tocado todos desde el 1 al 6, pasando por Call to Power, Alpha Centauri, Alien Crossfire, Colonizations, Beyond Earths y dem√°s), si no contamos Civ2. Como todos los Civ, tiene algo mejor y otras cosas peor, pero es de los que salieron bien de inicio, y los DLC, que eran en su √©poca "expansiones" no eran parches de contenido que no les dio tiempo a hacer antes de sacar el juego, si no que aportaban cosas adicionales.

Civ V y VI no est√°n mal, pero claramente cada versi√≥n  van a peor, sin contar temas gr√°ficos pr√≥pios de la tecnolog√≠a. Eso en el universo Civ, en el universo de juegos 4X, hay algunos otros m√°s densos y completos, pero a mi me divierte m√°s este.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027846336', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1671753778}
review:
So while my steam account doesnt show any real time played, I owned this game in cd form. And it was spectacular to say the least.  Good enough in fact that I just repurchased it on the steam summer sale as my new computer no longer has a cd rom drive so the old disk version I have not accessable. Now it is. Not sure how much I will play it again as I do think Civ V (with its DLC) is superior product. But Civ IV is a close #2.

This game, Civ V, Civilization Alpha Centari, and frankly Civ 2 Test of Time are all superior Civ games to Beyond Earth and Civ VI.

Civ V would be my first suggestion to any one asking but Civ IV isnt that far behind it and has a uniqueness all its own.

review:
(I've put in a lot more time on the non-steam version)

This game may have been considered good when it came out but it's not good by modern standards. If you really want a slow game with a lot of weird menus to craft your empire then sure, it's a well made product, but I think most people will hate it. Civ 5 is slow as well but feels a lot more exciting and satisfying, it's hard to put into words but civ 4 just seems all over the place and it's hard to keep straight what you're actually doing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198196453809', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 26628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7286, 'last_played': 1682403571}
review:
While the combat mechanic for this game seems to be a step back from the "Call to Power" games, the rest of the game is a significant improvement over what came before - better diplomacy options, more involved culture mechanics that take local nationalities and religions into account, more in-depth civics mechanics that allow you to create "mix-and-match" socieites (ex. a society with universal sufferage that also adopts vassalage, free markets and theocratic elements - customize your society to your play strategy instead of picking a "one size fits all" mechanic!).

While I do wish that they stuck with the "Call to Power" combat mechanic, I still this game on the whole - I do recommend that you buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980660889', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1797, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1797, 'last_played': 1327219200}
review: Played civ 5 to see if i liked civ as much as i did in the past. I 4got how fun the game was but civ 5 was pretty easy. So i buy civ 6 platinum and hated every possible thing about it. It felt like a chore to play and it looked like a mobile phone game. Even for 17$ with all the expansions i knew i wouldnt play a minute more nor ever enjoy it.. I realized i had civ 4 with expansions i bought many years ago but never played the expansions. I returned civ 6 after 40 mins of gameplay and installed beyond the sword expansion and civ 4. Omg... i find this version harder and more addicting than civ 5 or 6. Even the voice acting was amazing. I like the fact that you dont have to spend too long micromanaging like in civ 6. And your workers dont disappear. Civ 6 was such a mess players are going back to civ 4 and 5! If civ 7 isnt more like civ 4/5 with better graphics i won't buy it and keep playing civ 4 and exploring mods. The developers for civ 6 killed the fluidity of the game. And civ 5 was lacking content (unit variety) seen in civ 4.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049327070', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2011, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1828, 'last_played': 1622852739}
review:
SIDENOTE: This was my first Civilization game. I played it back in 2009 for hundreds of hours (before I had Steam of course). It was one of the two games to get me to switch from console to PC gaming.

Nostalgia aside, this is definitely tied for the title of "Best Civilization Game" with Civilization 5. There's a lot to like and there's some stuff to dislike about it. First, the positives.

The game looks like a game that came out in 2005 but it's not a bad looking game by any means. What you see in the screenshots on the Steam page is what it looks like in game. I also think that the game has a much higher learning curve compared to the newer iterations of the Civilization franchise, or at the very least compared to 5, BE, and 6. There's a lot more micromanaging in this game than the newer games. 

Moving on to the negatives, the game does feel very dated, and that becomes appearent at some of the mechanics. The movement isn't as good, since in Civ 4 they were still using square tiles, which makes some combat and movement feel terrible at times. The newer games have hexagonical tiles instead, and they're vastly superior to the square tiles of earlier games. But more importantly, the UI isn't that great. It can be a bit confusing, especially to newer players. 

Finally, some of the mechanics are completely barebone. There's a lot of stuff here to have fun with, but some mechanics aren't fleshed out enough (like city health) and just means that you have one more thing to micromanage instead of it being a completely different thing to keep track of.

Overall though, I would still recommend it because while it is starting to show its age, it's good enough that you can overlook some of the minor flaws that the game has. Also, it has one of the best soundtracks in the history of games period. Definitely pick this one up if you're a fan of 4X turn-based strategy games.

review:
Muito bom mesmo!
A princ√≠pio eu queria s√≥ testar o game antes de 2h, pra pega reembolso caso eu n√£o gostasse, baixei e fui jogando, quando vi j√° tinha passado mais que 2 horas pois √© muito envolvente a ritmo lento por ser em turnos, gostei demais das mec√¢nicas, das refer√™ncias, as grandes constru√ß√µes que foram criadas ao decorrer da hist√≥ria, etc... 
√â meu primeiro contato com a s√©rie do Sid Meier's Civilization, achava que eu n√£o iria gostar do g√™nero porque nunca joguei pra "valer" algo semelhante que envolvesse estrat√©gia em turnos, mas ao me deparar com este percebi que eu tamb√©m gosto de jogos assim kkj. Quando tiver oportunidade vou comprar os outros jogos da s√©rie.
N√£o sei se vou jogar muito por causa do fator tempo, o jogo demanda de muito tempo para progredir, n√£o sei quantas horas para tentar encerrar um Novo jogo; -Iniciei um Novo jogo e joguei por 2H e ainda n√£o t√° nem no late game. Se voc√™ quiser jogar eu recomendo ter tempo...

Se eu recomendo? Logicamente, principalmente para amantes de jogos do tipo! Jogo did√°tico, envolvente, estrat√©gico e +.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132995625', 'num_games_owned': 1399, 'num_reviews': 753, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1520675052}
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization IV
Dieses Spiel ist die bereits 2005 erschienende Basisvariante, dazu geh√∂ren noch zwei DLCs. Es ist das erste in 3D programmierte Civ. und in jeder Beziehung herausragend aus der Vielzahl der Civ. Spiele. Gemeint ist die 18 Zivilisationen Geschichtssymulation auf der Orginalkarte unserer Welt. Leider wurde hier der gleiche Mist gemacht wie schon in Teil 2. Die Grafik ist gro√ü die Karte nicht. Somit besteht das Problem das du nur sehr, sehr eingeschrenkt dich entwickeln kannst, da zB. nur eine Stadt auf das italienische Festland passt. Dennoch ist diese Variante die spannenste aller bislang existierender Civ. Spiele. Besonders m√∂chte ich auch hierbei hervorheben das Revolutionen und vieles mehr zu Abspaltungen oder Teilungen der L√§nder f√ºhrt. Auch das Auftauchen von neuen Volksgruppen ist sehr gut umgesetzt worden.. Klare Spielspa√ü und Kaufempfehlung.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015735861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1610489050}
review:
Thi is a good game and well worth the price.  the problem comes once you have mastered the basic game and push up to the higher difficulty levels.

You quickly realize that your start position is almost the only thing that matters in the game.   if you are surrounded by good resource hexes and have all that your civ needs and you can win easily, if you don't, which happens 19/20 times, and you are not going to win.  so you get into a restart loop rolling the perfect start and then when you get it, the game is a bit dull, because it is an easy victory.

Hopefully the expansion adds to the game, because right now once you master the basics of the game, it is so far the least entertaining of the Civ franchise.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014163253', 'num_games_owned': 391, 'num_reviews': 388, 'playtime_forever': 541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 541, 'last_played': 1513144294}
review:
[u][b]-Quick Review-[/b][/u]
Sid Meier's Civ 4 is a solid addition to the Civilization game series. Civilization IV is a turn based strategy game developed by Firaxis Games and released Oct 25, 2005.

[u][b]-Detailed breakdown review-[/b][/u]
[b]Story:[/b]  "What a minute Atratzu, why are you covering Civilization 4, when there have already been Civilization 5 and 6?" Good question hypothetical question asker!
The answer is: I got a ton of Civilization games from a humble bundle a year or two ago, and I'm still working my way through all of those games, and after playing a game I try to cover it somehow.
(For those confused, it's a closure thing for me... plus a fun hobby!)

If you're unfamiliar with the Civilization franchise; it's a turn based strategy game where you select a nation and slowly rise as a military power, science giant, cultural/diplomatic leader.
Out of those options I've only really been any good at conquest and/or science.
I don't trust other computers, and I would trust them even LESS if they were human players. [i](And don't trust me, I get bored easily, right Ben? (younger brother mumbles angrily)[/i]

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1190418146

[b]Gameplay:[/b] I think it's safe to say Civilization is one of the easier strategy games you can get into and play casually... but many people can take it to deeper levels and play.

The basics are very simple, you can build cities, move units around a hex-based landscape, build city upgrades, and work on scientific advancements.
...Are you going to build a bunch of troops and conquer thy neighbors? Or are you going to focus on special buildings called "wonders" even though they only work for a certain amount of time... will you focus on science?
Or will you do what I do which is a bit of everything.

I try to get a foothold of whatever island I start on... clearly I'm not fond of fighting on large continents, I like playing on archipelago maps. [i](Hey, I never claimed to be good, I'm probably disgustingly casual in how I like to play civilization, but boy is it relaxing and wonderful to play.)[/i]

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1194710391

[b]Conclusion:[/b] So with newer civilizations out, why would you want to play an older civilization game? PC hardware problems with new games... curiosity for what the older games played like... you preferred certain features in older civilization titles... cheaper price because it's an older game...
Regardless of your reason, Civ4 is a solid choice and worth or time, if you have the time to give. (that's a cryptic hint: "You'll be playing a lot of civilization if you like it)

[b]Unscripted Thoughts Video:[/b]

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QHMq_oy8CuI

author: {'steamid': '76561198081751638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1513505172}
review:
A estas alturas qui√©n no conoce este juego? Es un derrochador de horas, una vez que empiezas se te pasar√° el tiempo volando, y cuando tengas que dejar de jugar s√≥lo podr√°s decir; un turno m√°s, un turno m√°s!
 Evidentemente ha sido superado gr√°ficamente por sus sucesores, pero para nada ha envejecido mal, y tiene algo muy a su favor que han perdido los siguientes Civ, tiene una gran comunidad en internet donde podr√°s encontrar multitud de mods, y NO tienes que pagar por DLC¬¥s o contenidos extra que deber√≠an estar por defecto en el juego.
 Si te quieres iniciar en el mundillo de los Civilization, o recordar tiempos pasados, por el precio que tiene y las horas que da es una muy buena opci√≥n.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080059402', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 15549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15437, 'last_played': 1458056948}
review: I have loved playing the Civ series.  The advancements and changes from each version to the next were great.  Since they have chosen to provide this game only through Steam, it is not worth really buying anymore.  It is so unreliable.  Crashes unexpectly.  I have tried contacting Technical support.  I get a "canned" response telling me to update my drivers blah blah.  They did everything but come out and say it was my fault the game is not working.  I find it strange that my XP, Win7, Win8 and Win10 machines will not run the game the way it should.  I have tried it on a total of 8 computers in total.  Desktops and laptops alike.  These machines will still run much more advanced games without crashing.  I was really looking forward to getting CivVI as well, but not now.  Buy at your own risk.  There is a good chance the game will not perform without issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073643118', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1515124980}

author: {'steamid': '76561198105951052', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1488671437}
review:
I spent my childhood playing Civilization 2 and Colonization (original), I played Civ 5 and SMAC much later and I absolutely loved both, and decided to pick this up and see what all the fuss was about.

And...I feel like the only person who doesn't like this game. An inconsistent tone, clunky UI...and I just couldn't get into it like I could with other Civ games. Sure, Baba Yetu is a cool song, but there doesn't seem to be anything that stands out otherwise. Seriously, this is like a less boring Civ 3, but if you're new to Civ then just play 5, it's the best one so far for beginners.

Now all I need to do is hunker down and prepare for the flame wars I guess...

review: To me, the leap from Civ III to Civ IV was much more massive and meaningful than the leap from Civ IV to Civ V. Civ IV had the best music, the most polished and thorough mechanics, the most broadranging civs to select and original scenarios to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198329283449', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 11214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 860, 'last_played': 1590053086}
review:
Civ overall has sucked my life away and I love it for it. Incredibly high replayability and the historical aspect of it is perfect for a history nerd such as myself. I like winning via cultural domination and so I wish there was some way to take over all cities of an enemy with culture alone-- I always have to break out the army when it's just their capital city left.

Towards endgame, I wish there was a way to disable nukes being an option without getting the UN involved. I find the constant popups of the UN a bit irritating, although it's better when you don't vote for yourself as secretary general. That said, it's currently the only way I know of to not have to deal with nukes destroying my hard-earned cities.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069159152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2402, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1512179632}
review:
Great game. Perhaps the pinnacle of the series. The dulcet tones of Spock as you complete a technology helps set the mood (as it does if you let the intro to a game play out entirely). While there are some pieces missing (because when you get the "complete saga", you can play with all the expansions), it is a great basis for things to come. Having mentioned expansions... I miss those in many ways. The modern DLC model seems to miss... the point.

Anyway, this game is a great way to lose track of time and have fun while doing it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004201102', 'num_games_owned': 1123, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1511410025}
review:
I still recommend this as the best Civilization game ever made. Even though the series is two iterations out, the Civilization series made a terrible misstep that it has yet to rectify: 1 Unit Per Tile (or 1UPT for short)

Civilization takes place on a large strategic map, representing the entire world,  that's divided into tiles that each have their own features and terrain. War is waged by moving military units across these tiles.

The problem with 1UPT is a matter of perspective, and the matter of strategic vs. tactical combat. "Strategy" refers to the grand overall execution of a war by a nation's military, while "tactics" refers to the actions that a military unit takes in a single battle. A game series that's well-known for featuring both the strategic and tactical view of armies is Total War, and it shifts between the perspectives very well.

The problem is that Civilization does not shift between these perspectives (not that I really want it to, as I think that goes against the spirit of the game), so Civilization V and Civilization VI have tactical combat taking place on a map meant for strategic combat. In Civilization IV and all prior Civ games, you move your military units and when they meet an opposing force, RNG simulates what happens on a tactical level. It makes sense and it fits the strategic perspective of the playing field.

Civ5 and Civ6 use the same perspective, but the 1UPT restriction makes it so that on 1 tile, which represents a few hundred square miles, you have only one military unit. That doesn't make sense!

And I understand why there's a number of people who prefer it. They hate so-called "Stacks of Doom". In every Civ game through Civ4, you can have a theoretically infinite number of military units on one tile. These can quickly decimate a defending city's military if the stack of attacking units is large enough.

But that's the point!

If the enemy is able to defeat you with a stack of doom, then it's on you for not making your own stack to defend. Civilization isn't just about combat. It's also what happens between combat. It can also be about avoiding combat, if that's what you're going for. You need to build up the production of your cities, and then you need to produce wisely. Civilization is about more than managing a military, it's about managing your economy and infrastructure.

Forcing tactical combat on Civ puts too much weight on the military aspect of the game, since you have the headache of figuring out which military unit goes on which tile. And because Civ has ways to win the game peacefully, it goes against the spirit of the game to put that much weight on management of the military.

So, until Civilization reverses the horribly-flawed design choice of 1UPT, Civilization IV is still the prototypical Civilization game. It is the pinnacle of everything that Civilization is meant to be, and I hope that in time, Firaxis will understand the error of their ways and leave the 1UPT nonsense to games that are actually meant to be tactical combat games.

(Low playtime is due to all my playtime being credited to the "Beyond the Sword" expansion, plus most of my playtime was from when I had a physical copy of this game.)

review:
Premetto che √® stato il primo civilization che abbia mai provato. Vista la data in cui usc√¨, non mi aspettavo molto da questo gioco (che infatti avevo preso in offerta) e invece devo ammettere che mi ha decisamente stupito.
Il gioco √® molto intrigante e gi√† poco dopo aver capito le principali funzioni inizi ad apprezzarlo e successivamente ti ossessioni (esperienza personale lol).
Insomma, vista la mia poca esperienza personale in ambito di "civilization" non posso fare paragoni con gli altri titoli della saga, ma lo consiglio vivamente a tutti i novizi della serie giusto per non spendere troppi soldi per i nuovi capitoli e provare ad "assaggiare" le meccaniche di questa fantastica saga!
Spero di essere stato utile.

review:
I definitely dig Civ 4.  I've been a Civ fan since the first one, yet oddly I don't think I played 2 or 3... I just kept playing Civ 1 until I played Civ 4!  Of course that doesn't mean I've been playing them consistently.  Playing one game takes a lot out of me (because I try to let my culture take over the world), so I move on to other games.  I've only played Civ 5 once but I think I prefer Civ 4, so if you're going to get a civilization simulator....

9/10

review: Don't let the fact that I have few hours on this game derail you from this review. On the non-Steam version I have several hundred hours. Honestly, the worst thing about this game is how addicting it is. It really can mess your schedule up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036968140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 2225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2225, 'last_played': 1502602946}
review:
This is a great game.  If you get it on sale, it could end up being one of the best values--dollars to hours of entertainment--you'll ever get.  I got it on sale for $7.99 USD.  I've currently played it for, we'll call it, 37 hours.  That's somewhere around just over $0.21 per hour of enjoyment I've gotten.  Hello?  Value!  Now think--that ratio will keep climbing as I play this this game...  I digress..  It's a terrific game if you're into world build on a macro scale.  If you're here and reading this because you want to know if the game is good, you should probably just get it.

Dietrich Vader's Verdict: 4/5 Value Ratios

author: {'steamid': '76561198126081939', 'num_games_owned': 474, 'num_reviews': 344, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1501695224}
review:
A Civilization, an Amiga strategy game played on black and white TV, so much sentiment. Speaking of which, I really like the idea that building new world is an opening animation from first game. This series build up whole turn-based strategy segment, this part is far better then Civilization III which was a big disappointment for me and it ties and when one takes DLCs it beats Call to Power branch series easily. What I liked in Civilization the most, was the possibility to conquer whole big world. There are still some limitations here, but one can do it finally again here. The basic concept stays the same, but graphic is very detailed with zooming in and out, as well as some more additional mechanics. Pillaging improvements has great value, the political system is also far more detailed, units with special abilities, experience, and additional possibilities for veteran units, leaders each with own bonuses, the random events, conquest through culture and the list goes on. Game also has build in editor and modding community is still large. All this results in one, one can play through whole life with this and still get the enjoyment. 
As side note, it looks Firaxis heard that many people learn history from this title (and this game is a nice knowledge well for it) and one can feel the game was designed with the thought of younger audience (especially leader's pictures), personally I would prefer history accurate ones, but that's just preference, also there is no Poland civilization here.  
If what some people are saying about Civilization V and VI is true then this title will stay with me for ages. Highly recommended.

P.S. I'm an offline player.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969749884', 'num_games_owned': 2454, 'num_reviews': 1422, 'playtime_forever': 45286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20470, 'last_played': 1499708102}
review:
Civlization IV will probably remain to be one of my favourites for many years to come, as it is the Civ with the most depth while having sufficient presentation so far and my go to title when I get bored playing Civ V or VI.

It's also the title I'd recommend to anyone who played both Civ V and Civ VI and felt like they could have been even more complex. For all those people, Civ IV will be a revelation. For anyone else interested in 4x turn based (grand) strategy, Civ IV is one of the best titles of all time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065362431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 725, 'last_played': 1690624726}
review:
Es un juego que me gusta mucho. Tiene bonitos paisajes y un mapa grande en donde poder construir tus ciudades,  reclutar gente y navegar por las diferentes epocas de la historia adquiriendo tecnolog√≠a, mejorar tu econom√≠a, descubrir tesoros en diferentes pueblos distribuidos por todo el mundo, por ese lado es divertidisimo. Pero tiene un hipermegadefecto, pues no fue hasta que descubr√≠ como funcionan las batallas el hecho de que lo empezara a odiar,  pues no tienen ninguna logica. Por ejemplo puedes atacar a un ejercito de arqueros con caballeros con armaduras y caballos blindados y aun as√≠ terminan ganando los arqueros. Puedes atacar una ciudad con catapultas para tirar los muros, y una vez dentro con tus diez ejercitos puedes perderlos  sin matar a la √∫nica tropa que defiende la ciudad. Puedes pelear con ballesteros contra arqueros enemigos y ganan los arqueros.  Una unidad de caballeria te puede masacrar un ejercito de lanceros. Se supone que en la vida real arqueros a caballo son mas debiles que los ballesteros, prob√© atacar a un ejercito de arqueros a caballo con mis ballesteros y mis ballesteros murieron, lo mismo pas√≥ cuando mis ballesteros fueron atacados por un ejercito de arqueros a caballo. 

No hay tanto problema cuando te enfrentas a un ejercito a campo abierto aunque debo advertir que los resultados son impredecibles, lo se porque con una unidad de soldados con espadas largas ataque a un grupo de arqueros donde los arqueros terminaron ganando, carg√© la partida y volvi a hacer la batalla en donde ahora si resulte ganando sin ninguna baja. 
El problema empieza a la hora de asediar las ciudades, de verdad puedes terminar borrando la ciudad del mapa del coraje, porque son muy dificiles de tomar, yo recomendar√≠a asediar con 4 ejercitos de catapultas, muchisisisimos espadachines y mucha caballeria con lanceros y arqueros, o si tienes tecnolog√≠a superior no confiarte y llevar muchos ca√±ones y mosqueteros porque a√∫n asi van a costar mucho trabajo de tomar. 
Algo gracioso que pasa con tus aliados NPC es que terminan robandote la ciudad cuando tu hiciste todo el trabajo, de hecho detalles como ese son divertidos de ver porque simplemente son graciosos.
Tengo experiencia en otros juegos como "civilization revolution" que son de lo mismo pero a diferencia de ellos este me cay√≥ muy mal en cuanto a los asedios, todo es perfecto hasta que te das cuenta que la l√≥gica no tiene cabida en los combates de este juego, al menos en los asedios, en los campos abiertos aunque influyan las colinas y los bosques y todo eso si que puede ser un combate interesante y divertido porque determinadas unidades son mas fuertes o en ciudades o en colinas, o donde tu las hayas programado, pero ya estando en los asedios el resultado es aleatorio no importando que tengas unidades anti infanter√≠a o anti arqueros terminan muriendo si o si. 
Yo invito a la gente a que le de una oportunidad y a que aprenda a no desesperarse porque a veces en vez de desesperaci√≥n da risa, de verdad =). Y por lo de los asedios solo lleven muchisisisimos soldados y la ciudad ser√° suya, garantizado.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097512483', 'num_games_owned': 407, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1647006886}
review:
[b][i](Refazendo a an√°lise...)[/i][/b]

Civilization IV √© um jogo de simula√ß√£o em que se constroi uma civiliza√ß√£o a partir de limitados recursos.

√â um dos jogos mais viciantes que j√° joguei, al√©m de ser estrat√©gico √© um tanto educativo tamb√©m, trazendo elementos da hist√≥ria. 

O objetivo √© alcan√ßar a vit√≥ria sobre as demais civiliza√ß√µes. √â poss√≠vel alcancar de v√°rias maneiras: expans√£o territorial, diplomacia, corrida espacial (minha preferida!), entre outros...

√â um jogo bastante desafiador, com v√°rios n√≠veis de dificuldade e momentos de muita surpresa e tens√£o: mesmo com um imp√©rio rico e consolidado voc√™ pode ser desafiado a uma guerra cujo inimigo possui mais um aliado e ter seus recursos tomados, o que tornaria as coisas bem dif√≠ceis. Essa √© uma das in√∫meras possibilidades que Civilization IV oferece.

Voc√™ constr√≥i uma civiliza√ß√£o a sua escolha e escolhe como vai desenvolv√™-la durante o tempo. O jogo possui uma "√°rvore" de tecnologia, permitindo que o jogador decida quais recursos ou inven√ß√µes ser√£o desenvolvidos primeiro, montando sua estrat√©gia de acordo com o que o mapa oferece.

Minha √∫nica cr√≠tica √© que as partidas as vezes s√£o bem longas, mesmo limitando o n√∫mero de turnos. Mas sempre haver√° um desafio √† sua altura.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078140432', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1466893659}
review:
[h1] Ah... The good old days.	[/h1]
I have had more fun with Civ IV over the years, than I had watching the entire works of the cast of Monty Python and the infamous 5lbs Harebo "Digestable" Sugar  Free Gummy Bear review combined. The gameplay is phenominal. I think all other titles in the series pale in comparison, maybe bar Civ VI. If you're looking for a comparison of Civ IV to Civ VI, you won't find it in this post. That is because I enjoy both so equally right now, that I couldn't form an opinion of it if my life depended on it. The opening theme for Civ IV is amazing. I only recently learned that the lyrics to the game's opening theme translate to The Lord's Prayer, which is merely an interesting tidbit. Though I find the former interesting, in combination with the fact that Civ IV introduced  religion mechanics to the series. I doubt that that is a coincidence. This is the first Civ game I played to any level of seriousness or competency. I have sunk hundreds of hours into every Civ game since Civ III.

I recommend this game to people ranging from those who have never touched a strategy game in their life to veteran Civ players.

author: {'steamid': '76561198289549681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3245, 'last_played': 1547391137}
review:
With over 6 million units sold and unprecedented critical acclaim from fans and press around the world, Sid Meier's Civilization is recognized as one of the greatest PC game franchises of all-time. Now, Sid Meier and Firaxis Games take this incredibly fun and addictive game to new heights by adding new ways to play and win, new tools to manage and expand your civilization, all-new easy to use mod capabilities and intense multiplayer modes and options. Civilization IV comes to life like never before in a beautifully detailed, living 3D world that elevates the gameplay experience to a whole new level. Whether playing multiplayer or single player, team play offers a new way of setting locked alliances that result in shared wonder effects, visibility, unit trading and shared territory that delivers a plethora of new strategic and tactical options.

Very good game, but I do think that the price should not be this high for and old game like this one...

author: {'steamid': '76561198081827207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1104, 'last_played': 1490157158}
review:
An Absolute Classic. Many great memories with this game. Sid Meier's Civilization IV is a cult classic, and for good reason. Fun, fast paced gameplay, extensive research trees, interesting tech that completely changes the landscape of the playing field. Being over a decade old, the visual aspect of the game is understandably lacking nowadays, but you see everything you need to. The extensive choice of rulers and perks that come with different civs is commendable. It provides the player with the feeling that they have much more control over the course of their civilization, and this gives a unique depth to the world. As is the standard with Sid Meier's video games, the player truly feels like they are discovering something never before seen when they trek the vast expanse of water in their Caravan for the first time. Multiplayer mechanic is a perfect platform for competitive players or cocky friends to challenge each other to a great, long run of civ and gives way to an incredible, unique experience that no other game can quite achieve. A truly unique game that spans across generations, and will surely be remembered for its incredible run as the go-to RTS game. I speak with a heavy dose of bias, and the game does suffer a bit from graphical glitches, bugs, the occasional crash, etc., but it's an experience everybody deserves to have at least once. 

9/10, from a long time fan of weekly Civ IV night.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044838472', 'num_games_owned': 398, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 552, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 469, 'last_played': 1489173215}
review:
To be honest, I'm glad I got this in a bundle. I would be raging like hell if I didn't.

It's not a strategic game.
It's more like Monopoly against AI: there is a set pattern to go, exploitation and, in end, a pinch of luck required. 
Don't look to game hours since I've played it offline ('cause Big Picture is a wonderful mode and doesn't crash every 20 minutes with a controller attached, not at all) and it didn't record almost 20 hours. So I've clocked 30 hours into this and... it sucks.
Not like a very bad game, or literally, but compared to the other Civs... it just sucks. The AI wants to hinder you, the logic behind them is just pre-setted and poorly programmed: you invade in an early part of the game? They all swap to Slavery, basically fuck themselves and then, in a point of history or another, gang up and declare war on you - clearly ahead of them in every term possible - from a turn to another, sometimes even with a relationship of -2. You try to buy some allies, to fight them... and your allies usually end up going either to waste or with a peace treaty/peace in a matter of 10-20 days. 
Also, prepare to give away free techs if you don't want them to dogpile on you.
Also, prepare to slow down construction and research a lot, 'cause you're going to fortify your cities like hell. Even so, the AI can expand, build new cities, ramp up military and constructions without a trouble. It's not cheating, they just optimize the written path you all have to follow.

You know what, probably I was too used to how strategic Europa Universalis is.
Too bad.
Glad I got it in a bundle.

EDIT: gotta love the fanboys downvoting on this. Looks like you can handle only the "IMSOFUNNY" 8/8 comments and those reviews long half a sentence, definitely short-term focus. That would explain why you consider this a strategic game, after all.
