J√° instalei e tentei seguir o tutorial do Civilization IV umas tr√™s vezes, mas agora estou oficialmente desistindo. O jogo √© √≥timo, eu √© que sou um loser mesmo ^_^

author: {'steamid': '76561198158969660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1488823777}
review:
The original Civilization is among the most enjoyable, influential games of all time. Its sequels have sought to build upon the basic model by adding greater levels of complexity and streamlining the interface. And though the sequels were definitely great games, they were still rooted in an interface and gameplay style that had changed very little since the original was released in 1991.

That's not the case with Civilization IV. It reenergizes the core concepts of the series, staying faithful to what fans expect while also creating a wholly original game. While the game hasn't lost any depth or detail, every aspect of the design has been streamlined to make it easier for new players to jump in and less monotonous for veterans. Die-hard fans will definitely find that the game offers up so much more variety this time around. The shape of each game is quite different, from the ways you build up your empire to the ways you tear down the empires of others. 

Sadly, even the most comprehensive reviews of Civilization IV can't discuss every aspect of the game. There's just so much to experience in this game that you can't possibly hope to cover every topic. While I'd love to tell you all about the other joys and secrets here, Dan and I have to go and teach the Greeks a lesson

For me, it would be Baba Yetu. It is the theme song for Civilization IV (though not much is known of its inspiration why Baba Yetu was chosen as the soundtrack for Civilization IV?). Listening to it even with your eyes closed, and you can still feel the song embodying all of human history.

The lyrics are below. I do not speak Swahili. The lyrics in bold are sung by a chorus.

author: {'steamid': '76561198164432217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 435, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1553348437}
review:
[h1] Sid Meiers civilization IV [/h1]
This game is about ruling the world. You start with some troops and progress to the timeages.
Its a fun game.
[h1]SOUND[/h1]
I really enjoy the soundtrack. The title screen music is the best.
[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
The game is fun to play. But it gets boring so i recommend playing for 20 min then taking a break.
(Its my opinion ;) )
[h1]TOASTER?[/h1]
Yes indeed.
[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The game has okay graphics. Looks like any other 2005 game.
[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]
The game is fun. Is cheap when on sale.
So i give it 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197990643240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 487, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 487, 'last_played': 1486913420}
review:
What a joke, 2k Games at it again, where they completely change the values in the game, where the opponents can one shot any unit, any city without a fight. 

Word to the wise, you may think this is the classic you played before, its not. Its been heavily tampered with, where you, as the player, can be killed in the first 10 turns just because the AI decides to declare war on you. And you could even possibly make it to turn 60, where every town has a decent number of units to protect it, walls, whatever, the AI can take the city with a brand new warrior who has never earned a single point of experience, bypassing all defenses.

author: {'steamid': '76561198219238953', 'num_games_owned': 129, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 892, 'last_played': 1511031291}
review: I haven't played this game enough to know half of what is possible, but I think i've played it enough to be able to write a review on it. So far, I love this game. It's not something I'll play everyday but it is an amazing strategy game, and you really need to rack your brain and play smart to win. You can't just make 10 warriors and take over a town. You have to plan, scout  around, and consider your options. I haven't bought the 5th or 6th one because i heard the 4th was better than the 5th, and the 6th is still $60. But i definitely plan on buying them in the future. All in all, this game is worth what I payed for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032698727', 'num_games_owned': 925, 'num_reviews': 150, 'playtime_forever': 475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 475, 'last_played': 1483666028}

If I'm going to play an uneven stragey game, I'm better off with Warcraft. At least I have half a chance of pushing them back off my land. Using rifelmen and they get swarmed by knights. WTF!

author: {'steamid': '76561198118099497', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 125, 'last_played': 1518987503}
review: When first loading up a game you are met with a series of complex systems; the tutorial only covers a third of the game's content. Along the way you pick up the tatics and the mindset to play this game. If you get over the intial learning curve you'll be right as rain later in the game. Overall a solid gaming experience, even though my hours look quite low compared to others, as a beginner I can rightfully say that I am enjoying this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159121180', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 841, 'last_played': 1515819242}
review:
Played this game years ago and picked it up during the black friday sale. It will always be one of my favourite Civ games. 

Its not the easiest game to figure out for new players. You have to deal with culture, taxes, city happiness, diplomacy, city health, barbarians, religion, empire expansion and the GOD FORSAKEN MONGOLIANS.

However, Mongolians aside, it is hands down one of the best games I have ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073316584', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1461380596}
review: My hours played is misleading. I played this game for hundreds of hours before I even had a steam account. It is one of my all time favorites.   I have played every Civ game since the original except for the newest (Civ 6) and this is hands down my favorite. It has great expansion packs, scenarios and mods (fall from heaven 2 is a must-have). It seems there is a dispute over whether civ4 or 5 is better. Personally, I feel 4 is more in depth and when I play 5 I get bored for some reason. Some people complain about unit stacking in this game,  but I have never had strong feelings about it and am not sure what the argument against it is.

review: This game is wonderful! I have spent many fun hours playing Civ, both by myself and with friends. I always play the BtS expansion and not this base game though. But it still is fun, and would be worth $50! Buy it if you want a fun strategy game in which you can take your time. The game is turn based, not time based, so waiting a while on one turn to make a decision doesn't harm anyone. Buy this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198007765886', 'num_games_owned': 1270, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1480425023}
review:
I highly recommend Civ 4 for one of the best mods I played. Fall from Heaven 2. A mod that adds so much to the game that the vanilla game is like a mud hut next to Taj Mahal.

The mod is set in a dark fantasy world, recently waken up from a long period of winter due to the god of winter reigned unopposed until a hero emerged and slew him. This new world has decimated the old civilizations and sent them into a tribal life, struggling to survive. And here you come in. In short order, the mod adds a bunch of new civilizations, very different from each others. Orcs sucks at science, but can produce 2 units at the same time. The Khazad (dwarfs) rely on their stockpile of gold for prosperity, the elven civs can build improvements on forest tiles, etc. Religions added. Civilization alignment from good to evil. An armageddon count which turns the world into fiery hell terrain as it climbs closer to doom. Lairs and dungeons to explore. A ton of story, more or less every unit and hero (did I mention heroes?) have a backstory. Magic. So much magic. It fixed a bunch of issues with the older Civ games, like when the computer civs just zergs down everything, in FfH2, you can combat that, you have mages that can aoe blast a pile, cast fear and break up the stack, use Blind and lock them up, and if you are the one attacking a strong base which contains those mages, you could use assassins which has the promotion that enables them to start attacking the weakest unit in the stack.

And if you get tired of this, there is modmods and modmodmods with a dedicated community who worked to keep enhancing and expanding the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179779915', 'num_games_owned': 1657, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1136, 'last_played': 1480406608}
review: Regardless of the new games coming out I still find myself coming back to this one. I started my civ addiction at this one so I'll probably always be coming back sooner or later for another fix.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077356953', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 10457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10180, 'last_played': 1466896584}
review:
I am nominating this game for Steam's "The Test of Time" Award because of its virtually endless enjoyability. Even compared to its successors 5-10 years later, this game can hold its own any day. 

I was first introduced to this game when it was still new (I couldn't have been more than 11 years old at the time), and I was very intrigued by it. The person who let me play showed me it when their civilization had reached at least the Modern Era, as his SAM Infrantry defended against a helicopter attack. He was playing as America, so when he handed off control to me, I felt a sense of duty to carry my country to victory. 

Besides the fact that I had next to no idea of how to even play the game, let alone [i] win [/i], Civ IV managed to invest me in the game from the very beginning. This is something it still never fails to do. 

I highly recommend this game, and I hope one day you'll be able to appreciate the sense of duty in the words, [b] "Can your civilization stand the test of time?" [/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198029212344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1480378886}
review:
Championship Manager 01/02 is a great game - yes, it doesn't have all the bells and whistles of later versions, but you can complete a whole season in like 2hrs!  Now, you'd maybe manage to play about 3 or 4 matches in the same time. CM 01/02, put simply, is the filtered down essence of what makes CM.

Which brings me to Civ IV. I suppose I could stop there and let the analogy do the work for me, But Civ IV deserves more attention.

This game, the add-on's that followed and the extensive modding community make for the best experience I have found in this genre. Startling with just a settler and a scout, you will build huge cities, conquer (or be conquered by) other civilizations and  discover new lands and resources to exploit. Smile as you discover a new civilisation that is way behind you in military tech, or feel your heart sink as you realise the nearest source of copper is way on the other side of your island, or worst still, on another land mass altogther!

Whether I play a short duel map are a humungously huge one,  I always find myself coming back for one more turn and, hours later, wondering what the hell happened to the evening I'd planned.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005604963', 'num_games_owned': 4588, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1707546399}
review:
To me this is still the best entry in the Civilization series, but I still havent't played Civ III and VI.
It's the superb blend of nice graphics, timeless game mechanics (with a rather good di0plomacy system), great music and of course quotes for the technologies read by the late great Leonard Nimoy (although they got some other guy to read the technology quotes for the new techs from the addons).
Simply near perfect game, one of the few that ever got me to play till the sun came up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034907090', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 946, 'last_played': 1508275140}
review:
Don't get fooled by the low number of hours shown on Steam. I originaly bought this game in DVD when it came out and must have clocked almost 3,000 hours. I lost count of how many times I got surprised by my alarm clock going off in the morning and I was still playing.

Of all the Civ games I played, this is my favorite. The AI is pretty decent, there are lots of things to micro-manage, requiring some very carefull strategies to balance the needs of culture, research and expansion without running out of coins.

But as a war-monger, what I like the most is that this is the last standard Civ game that still allows for unit stacking. This makes combat really awesome.

If you're looking for a game that have that "Just. one. more. turn!" factor, this is the one.

It really passed the test of time says a lot. There are not that many games out there that are 11 years old that you can still play and enjoy as much as when it was new. Now stop being a cheap schmuck and buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024731609', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 16588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4609, 'last_played': 1542169125}
review:
I hadn't played the Civilization franchise since CIV 2 back in the late 90s. When I played this game I though "yeah this was the game I played."  Don't get me wrong, Civilization is a great game, and if you've never played it before and you love strategy games, then you'll love this one as well. It's fun, time consuming, and a blast to play. My only criticism of CIV IV is that it felt like you could too easily put your units on autopilot and then the game becomes pick what you want to build and burn turn after turn.

You won't regret buying this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013359559', 'num_games_owned': 538, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 3065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3065, 'last_played': 1473068219}
review:
The ultimate in 4X games, the civilization series is a staple to all players of this genre. Compared to Civilization V, this games is closest to the original Civ I and II before the move to only one unit in one square as per Civilization V. With many mods and varients, this stands out in the series and was the technical high point. Later games started to change the nature of the game from the original feel. 
There is rich DLC and many community mods. There are some bugs in the community mods but they are diverse and flavourful. The game is readily modable by an enthusiast and small tweaks can be made by the amature. 
In short, for the price and the play you should have this in your library. 10/10.
Just one more turn...

author: {'steamid': '76561198032614383', 'num_games_owned': 13373, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2084, 'last_played': 1452759424}
review:
I'm a great fan of all Civs games (Sid Meier is one of my computer game creator heroes).
I have played Civ1, Civ2, Alpha Centauri, (some clones not to be named), Civ3, Civ4, Civ5.
I still play Civ4 because it is still playable on older/weaker computers and it is  better than the ancestors. 

Well, some of the (some clones not to be named)  were quite nice and Alpha Centauri is in its own league .

Since it has all it 'needs' for what its takes to be a good Civ and you don't have to have the newest/funky equipment, it is the perfect game for the Civ experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997106051', 'num_games_owned': 531, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1479975553}
review: Out of a classic franchise spanning many games, this iteration is perhaps the most worthy of praise. It combines the simple elegance of the first game with increased depth, usability improvements, and great modding support. Like all Civ games, it improved markedly with expansions, and I would consider Beyond the Sword to be a must buy. I urge you to try the Fall from Heaven 2 total conversion, a mod so engrossing I still dream of it a decade later.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972572095', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2182, 'last_played': 1420318815}
review:
A classic 4x strategy game with lots of Mods, and the mechanics are different enough from Civ V that I sometimes
switch back and forth, to me this one is still one of the pinnacles of the series.
Leonard Nimoy is the narrator and we will never get a re-work of this type of CIV, the new one's are great
but this one is also a must have in my humble opinion!
Tons of mods and user created content provide for hundereds of hours of replayability.

review: This is, quite simply, the greatest world-building sim of all time.  It's the best in the series, despite the developer's claims that they're improving with each iteration.  In this one (with all the DLC) they found the perfect balance, and those of us who have put countless hours into it in the last decade+ fear they won't do it as well ever again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198317561542', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4398, 'last_played': 1525785603}
review:
I haven't played a game like this for years and years.
Admittedly I chose Civ IV because of the price.... but damn I can't help but play for hours and hours.
Love every aspect of this so far. I've only been playing on the easier difficulties but I find this game has lots of replayability due to the various win conditions, starting points, map types etc you can use to make it more of a challenge for yourself.
Would recommend this to anyone who hasn't yet tried a Civ game who doesn't want to invest too much money into the unknown.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198212790828', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 4453, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1705887531}
review:
This game is truly destined for greatness. Part 4 of the amazing Civ series allows you to learn about history while play a video game! And it's fun! Choose your civlization, each with special talents (I favor the Mongolians, who are better at conquering new lands and battle.) and begin in a lonely land. As your Settlers create cities, build Workers and all kinds of warriors to valiantly defend your homelands from the armies that you will find. Communicate with other civilizations and form friendship or create war. As you research technologies from the medieval ages, such as smelting, animal husbandry, farming and agriculture, who will become the strongest and modern civilization? 
This game progresses from the early Classical era to the Modern era, and soon you'll be in combat with jet fighters and ICBMs. Pass world laws, and join sides to demolish an enemy. 
Create a civilzation to stand the test of time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198244399106', 'num_games_owned': 101, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1510421937}
review:
Still my favorite Civ game. Admittedly, I have never actually played Civ 5 or 6, but I have read about and watched them, and am quite happy with this one (although tastes do differ).

Unquestionably a direct upgrade from Civ 3. Corruption is gone! Research and production have overflow now! You can tell how much techs cost!  Culture makes sense! Diplomacy makes sense! There are now anti-StackOfDoom units!

If you're new to the Civ series - well, this is the cheapest entry except 3, and there's enough options and difficulty levels that pretty much anybody can find something that works for them. You can pretty much ignore many of the aspects of the game if you want to.

Did I mention that this game has Leonard Nimoy? This game has Leonard Nimoy.

Of all the games in my Steam Library, this one has given me the most hours of fun compared to the cost (except TF2 - can't really beat infinity).

My advice: get the Complete Edition during a sale. A real steal at six bucks.

review:

Ancora oggi mi piace dedicarci qualche turno,  le mie ore sono quasi nulle qui su Steam ma l'ho giocato molte ore dall'uscita (quando ancora utilizzava pienamente GameSpy e non era possibile registrare le ore). Purtroppo non sono stato in grado di attivare su Steam la mia copia fisica ma l'ho preso comunque in saldo a 5‚Ç¨ con tutte le espansioni.
Se non avete mai giocato un Civ questo potrebbe piacervi, ma vi consiglio il V o il VI perch√® delle meccaniche del IV non sono facilmente comprensibili ai neofiti della serie.

Curiosit√†: La main song di Civ IV Baba Yetu √® stata la prima canzone nella storia dei videogiochi a vincere un Grammy Award.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131973975', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1490596700}
review: F. I grew up playing this game on a disc copy, and when I saw it was on sale I couldn't resist. This game is EXTREMELY fun, and isn't too hard to pick up. I would choose this game over Civ 5 any day of the week, except wednesday, but this game and Civ 5 are completely different, yet exactly the same, if you know what I mean. The gameplay is very fun and can have you playing for days, or you could just be playing a game for a few hours and be done with it. The expansions are quite good but the possibilities in the base game are vast. Pick this game up for yourself, if you can't figure it out refund it and get Civ 5

author: {'steamid': '76561197970805958', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 555, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 555, 'last_played': 1357459200}
review:
I had this before I got it on Steam, and I've logged MANY MANY hours on it, because you just need one... more... TURN!

Build a civilization, wage war against others, and become the dominant nation on the planet with a deceptively simple interface and easy to learn mechanics.

Choose your nationality and start from meager tribal beginnings to become an empire to be reckoned with as you build city improvements and recruit armies to defend your people and subjugate others. All the while researching new technological advancements and managing your people's happiness and growth.

It's insanely addictive, you need to play this if you enjoyed any of the previous games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198250479928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 333036, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1577, 'playtime_at_review': 35678, 'last_played': 1710887288}
review:
I have preferred Civ IV to any other version (both earlier and later editions) since it was published. I also find the Civilisation games superior to anyother of its kind. I find the graphics simple but effective and the strategic opportunities offer plenty of interest. Later versions have tended to overdue the graphics at the expense of gameplay - but I look forward to Civ VI in due course.
I would recommend CivIV to anybody who likes this kind of strategy game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160234597', 'num_games_owned': 65, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 11880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11027, 'last_played': 1589496262}
review: Ah√≠ quien dice que Civilization IV no es tan bueno como el III o V, pero no es cierto, aqu√≠ empesaron los cambios: Se empez√≥ a usar el 3D para hacerlo m√°s vistoso, se agregaron efectos de sonido ya sea bosques y selvas o en el mar y cielo, tambi√©n se agreg√≥ m√°s formas regir al pueblo ( Ejemplo el vasallage), adem√°s tiene un mejor editor de mapas, otra caracter√≠stica es qu√© el juego es multi idioma (incluye el espa√±ol) cosa que EL III no tiene, para terminar; esta versi√≥n de Civilization es bastante recomendable tanto para los que empiesan en los juegos de estrategia como para los veteranos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071305138', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 1818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1179, 'last_played': 1592830201}
review:
A good Civilization game on it's own and even with the base game you will get alot of hours use out of it. But it is made even better with the Beyond the Sword expansion which I highly advise you to get for the full experience to really hold up well against Civ 5  and I should imagine the upcoming Civ6. Don't worry about the Warlords expansion as Beyond the Sword contains everything except its scenarios and opens the game up for a good selection of mods. 

Put it on your wish list and wait for a Steam sale where you can get Civ 4 complete for less than this game on this game on it's own. I got the CIv4 complete version for much less than Civ 4 and Beyond the Sword seperately like that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064418546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 7879, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7384, 'last_played': 1482114848}
review:
Got sick and tired after the AI got predictably bastardly. Some random empire decides to declare war for no reason, from across other nations. Just pure self-destructive armageddon. They aren't even doing to win any land, just slash and burn. Civ II was the best they ever made. These cheap ripoffs don't come close to it. At least Civ II had the spirit of the original Civilization, which was best when played on the Amiga 500. Civ V looks like the same dumb junk, and I doubt Civ VI is going to be any better.

Plus, unstable as hell.

review:
Civ IV
>Random Civ

>Done some more improvements

>Attacked his second city
>Get_Rekt_N00b2.gif
>Decided to train more units till I attack him again
>While I was away he makes a third city on the remains of the second
>Attacked his third city
>Get_Rekt_N00b3.gif
>Created Kraljevo on the remains of the third city
>Genghis begs for peace
>10 turns peace + 10 gold! yay..
>1389th y just passed.. The great battle for Kosovo field - Serbia vs Ottomans
>Stationed an army just next to Genghis' borders
>After the peace treaty passed ordered my units to attack his fourth city
>Get_Rekt_N00b4.gif
>Actually_kept_this_city.jpg instead of BURN_BABY_BURN.gif
>Named the city Kragujevac
>Genghis Khan's trail went completely cold for now
>Meanwhile I researched Electricity and starts researching Flight
>Almost_Bomb_Time.gif
>Genghis wants peace
>LOL_GTFO_SCRUB.gif
>>Destroyed his fifth city
>Get_Rekt_N00b5.gif
>Meanwhile destroyed his sixth city
>Get_Rekt_N00b6.gif
>Genghis Khan only has one more city left
>PREPAREURANUS.p0rn
>1715 AD - The Mongolian Civilization has been destroyed!!!
>Better think three times before giving me an ultimatum and declaring a war on me bit.ch
>The war lasted from 125 BC - 1715 AD (1830 years)
>I'm the coolest kid in the neighbourhood
>Sinan ≈†akiƒá was born in Kyoto
>Got bored so declared war on Arabs
>Captured and burned their first city
>Get_Rekt_N00b1.gif
>Captured Medina and renamed it to Novi Pazar
>Captured Meca and renamed it to Subotica
>Fu.cker captured Kragujevac
>Reclaimed Kragujevac
>Captured Baghdad => renamed it to Atenica xD
>After tens of years I finally managed to conquer Najran - and rename it to Ra≈°ka!
>One more city left
>Stupid Arabs conquered Russian city...
>Finally managed to capture Anjar with great losses
>I did it! Destroyed the last Arabian city! ..or did I? That fu.cking wasn't the last city....
>Wait, wait. It was. Silly me.
>1912 AD - The Arabian Civilization has been destroyed!
>War weariness is making my people unhappy (-12 happiness)
>After a few years the revolt stopped and the people were happy again
>1914 AD - No WW I, thank God. I've spent all my army to conquer Arabia, and I thought it'd be easy. I've sacrificed too much.
>Over the course of next 25 years I've prepared everything - repaired my infrastructure, made an army again, done a lot of researchs just in case some idiot decides to start a WW II
>1939 AD - So far no signs of WW II, yay!
>2004 AD - U.N. Elections - (Secretary General) Leading candidate: Tycho with 294 votes!
>2008 AD - U.N. Elections - (Diplomatic victory) 239 votes / 274 needed
>2012 AD - U.N. Elections - (Diplomatic victory) 240 votes / 274 needed
>2016 AD - U.N. Elections - (Free Speech Global Civic) 348 votes / 224 needed - SUCCESS!
>2020 AD - U.N. Elections - (Secretary General) Leading candidate: Tycho with 310 votes!
>2024 AD - U.N. Elections - (Diplomatic victory) 257 votes / 285 needed
>2028 AD - U.N. Elections - (Diplomatic victory) Another failure.. Needed like 20 votes
>Started the production of spaceships!
>2032 AD - U.N. Elections - (Free Religion Global Civic) 100% 473/473 votes :steamhappy: - SUCCESS!
>Just realised I researched literally EVERYTHING. I'm at Future Tech 3 already lol!
>2040 AD - ANOTHER FU.CKING FAILURE! Neede 30 more votes this time to win.. Nvm, 10 turns left, and I'm ahead for like 2k points xd
>2044 AD - Needed 29 more votes this time..
>2048 AD - Last election before my victory! Needed 20 more this time.. Dayum!
>2050 AD - BAM! VICTORY! TIME VICTORY! TYCHO IS VICTORIOUS!

And that, ma lads, is the tale of my first ever campaign in Sid Meier's Civilization IV
It took me 12 hours but I did it.
I destroyed two civilizations on the course of 6050 years, built 5 spaceships, researched every technology, founded United Nations, founded Christianity, Facism, Nuclear bombs, hookers and drugs.

10/10 would play again

author: {'steamid': '76561198036063422', 'num_games_owned': 802, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1315810800}
review:
The best Civ game in my opinion. It  covers with the dlc many possibilities of the game. I especially love "Colonization", that's actually a remake to the original Sid Meiers game, a good one by itself. (Colonization is about the European settelment in North America)

I don't know why it shows only 0.3 hrs - as a matter of fact, I played hundreds of hours as this game is super super super addictive, espcially with the add-ons. For a game like this, they should invent something like the parental advisory or cigarrets : " Level 1 warning : this game will loose your sleep, your social life, your wife, and your job.Notify the authorities immidiately after using".

author: {'steamid': '76561198169561090', 'num_games_owned': 132, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1819, 'last_played': 1472090764}
review: This is one great game! I love the Game because it shows people how to run something. This could help someone how to run a business or even something in the army. The Civilization choices are a little limited though. I get this is an older game that isnt as advanced as Civ V and the up and coming Civ VI. But i would have liked to see more civilization choices, or at least more leaders in some of them. This game is also good for another reason. The Multiplayer challanges you to do something new in the game. You can play with your friends against each other alot. Which is something i plan on doing soon. I would recommend this game! Thanks for Reading, and have a nice day!

review: As a long time Civ fan I was surprised when I received a copy of Civ4 Complete Edition on Steam. That being said I can Recommend this entry in the Civilization series to anyone who is a fan of 4X games, Civilization or not.  Civilization 4 might look worse than newer strategy games because of its age, but dont let that fool you, it stacks up to be just as good, if not better than a ton of newer strategy/4X titles!

author: {'steamid': '76561198081354312', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 1867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1750, 'last_played': 1463926036}
review:
Das wird n kurzer Review
Ich hatte Hoffnung in das Spiel gesetzt .... wollte ein rundenbasiertes Spiel das nicht im Weltraum oder auf dem Meer spielt sondern VIELE Land Schlachten birgt .....
Das Spiel hat mich entt√§uscht weil es einfach einen Zufallsfaktor hat bei den Armeen... 
Da ist ...z.b. Rome 2 besser -schwere Kavalerie gewinnt IMMER gegen leichte Bogensch√ºtzen ....
Hier konnte ein Kriegstrupp mit Kupferschwertern gegen einen Panzer gewinnen -_- 
Ich mag es ein Spiel Wiederspielwert hat , sei es durch verschiedene Handlungstr√§nge oder Zufalsereignisse
Aber Armeen die einfach unberechenbar sind und sich gerne mal komplet abstrakt gegen andere Armeen durchsetzen ....
Wer das mag dem sei gesagt das Civ 4 ein gutes Spiel ist .... Das prinzip ist auch toll, nur der Zufall ist bescheiden

review:
Civilization 4 is the high point of the series. Civ 5 may have brought new elements, but Civ 4 was special, and even after all the DLC for 5, it still can't top Civ 4.

UPDATE: Civ 6 is still not better than Civ 4.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127880193', 'num_games_owned': 472, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 521, 'last_played': 1705337555}
review:
Honestly I own Civ III - V and the game I play most is 'Civ IV: Beyond the Sword' ... for the few extra bucks, the complete collection is the way to go.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991478994', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 52057, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12767, 'last_played': 1481323147}
review:
[h1]I had a lot of fun playing Civ 3 Complete.

CIV 4 Complete made my brain explode! Fortunately, my life has been unaffected (obviously, my brain was much larger and far superior to that of you common Earthlings. I mean 'humans'... er, people).[/h1]


[b]It much pertier now ([i]was[/i] superior).

The smooth integration of the IN-GAME editor (press CTRL+W) allows me to create more land, cities, friends, enemies and ridiculously large armies - on the fly! It also means that I begin each game with 2 Billion gold for bribing or, preferrably, enslaving the world.


You know? This game reminds me of our strategic training simulators
back home [spoiler][b] on PLUTO.  It's a FOCKING [i]planet![/i] [/b][/spoiler][/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198087543896', 'num_games_owned': 2008, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1440743467}
review:
I probably have hundreds of hours put into this game previously to owning the Steam version. It's generally been my favorite  in the series. This concept worked better when you could still stack miltary units. I've been a huge Civ fan all the way since the very first one came out in 1992. Civ IV was the first to really get every element right... AI, resources, everything.

9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198123257880', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 721, 'last_played': 1503862859}
review:
The Russian people under there wise ruler Flazam II, decide to found there first city, Moscow.
Moscow started as a small farming city. With little to no army but an expansive amount of fields and pastures. But soon enough we were running out of space. We decided to found 3 more cities all in the continet we resided in. After exploring the continent the Russians met two other Empire who lived nearby first was Asoka of India, and secondly was Saladin of Arabia. Asoka and Flazam became good allies, Russia would send some of are livestock from are farms and in return he would give us money.  For 1000 years we remained a humble farming civilization. That was until the scholars in Moscow came to there great leader Flazam II with some reseach. Gun Powder, this new discovery allowed are civilization great new oppitunties, and so in 1245 AD Russias militisation began. Are Armies grew with the most advanced soilders in the planet. Grenidiers, Riflemen galore. We gained a reputation so great two nearby Arabian cities revolted to join are Empire. Quickly Russia became the greatest military might, but still we remained close Allies with are neibhour Asoka, a relationship that had stood the test of time. Saladin however attempt to convert my people to Taoism and was spreading vile rumours about are wise ally Asoka. After hearing this news Flazam II got his noble stead and rode to Mumbai to discuss the pesky Saladin. it seemed India too resented him, therefore Flazam II gave are knowledge of gun powder to Asoka, with this gift Flazam II made a proposition. The Russia-Indian alliance should combine on a common enemy of Saladin and to unify the continet  under are great alliance. Therefore in 1348 war on Saladin was declared by both are nations. We quickly mobilised are troops on the eastern front storm 3 of Saladins cities adding them to are now vast empire. The war on the west was more vicious India was suffering some large casulties, therefore Flazam II sent some of the best fighters in are Empire from St Petersburg to aid in that front. With the help we pushed both fronts right back to the circumference of Saladins capital. In only 25 years Saladin was on his knees. India accept a treaty with Saladin. Flazam II was furious. India had left when we were so close. However Flazam II peristed the battle around Saladins capital was a bloody one. Lasting 40 years and draining the great Russian empire, slaves in St Petersburg were on strike and the War was begining to drag on. Therefore Flazam persuaded India to join the war once more in a final battle on the capital, and the famous Battle of 1 Turn occured. Saladin was destroyed and The Russia-India Alliance were victorious, but Flazam II still rembered how Asoka has betrayed him and the Alliance was on thin ice, Flazam II spent the next 300 years picking up the pieces of his problems in the Russian cities. The people demanded democracy and in the summer of 1789 Flazam II abdicated and was replaced by the New Russian president. Moscow was well known for its scientfic discoveries, and in 1867 we discovered Urianium and began the Manhattan project. Meanwhile over the past 200 years Asoka had entered a golden age with an empire far superior to ares. This competion began a Cold War with Russia the alliance broke down and times were tough. By the dawn of 20th centuary we had completed the Manhattan project and in 1920's the Cold War became increasingly serious. India mobilised troops round are borders and began sending spies. After India blockaded are Urianium farms the Cold War esclated and in 1935 the Russian president declared War on India, the next year we launched 3 nucleur bombs on Indias cities. India suffered but however they invaded are Urianium fields and launched a vicious offense. Russia was overwhelmed with a war on 5 fronts. And in 1977 we were on are knees all are cities were on the brink of revolution and Asoka had captured 1 of are cities. Russia pleaded with India and India agreed and the war ended albeit with a harsh treaty. India empire flourished as we attempt to pick up ares. In 2014 the Greek Empire was getting worryingly large. It was on a separate continet sharing there land with Mao Zedong. I negotiate with Mao. I asked him to declare war on the Greeks. I pretended to ally with Mao but really I only wanted Mao to invade Greece because I knew the Greeks growth would slow, I secretly however knew Mao would lose albeit it would take at least a hundred years. In 2050 the game ended with India its victors


10/10 would spend 30mins making review again

author: {'steamid': '76561198023359027', 'num_games_owned': 1120, 'num_reviews': 735, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1455218678}

author: {'steamid': '76561198280813313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 3594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 848, 'last_played': 1584490941}
review:
I am playing civ 4 with no expansions and am loving it! It was a great deal and has a lot going for it. I played civ 3 previuosly and most of my likes involve improvements from that and most of my dislikes involve frsutrations from switching to this one. 

Pros
more map and leader options
great graphics and details
very complex to maintain good relations with other leaders, but not impossible. 

cons
I don't fully understand how to set up a map/game as im used to the civ 3 method
the civelopedia seems incomplete as far as helping with playing the game and learning to adjust from the chages from 3-4
I cant find a way to prebuild a custom map
worldbuilder after game starts make cheating too easy and tempting

Overall I am very happy with it, and mostly my complaints are about adjusting from civ 3. I see no reason in buying the expansions unless you particularly want what they give you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069206818', 'num_games_owned': 782, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 344, 'last_played': 1576135849}
review: I totally missed out on this game because life got in the way for a few years, and I really regret it. It was kind of hard to fall into, because it is so vastly different from how previous (and future) verions of Civ have worked. It was fun for a playthrough or two before I put it down and went back to V, but I recommend a playthrough if you are lucky enough to find it on sale.

review: Unlike Civ III, which now seems graphically outdated, Civ IV has tons of replay value. I just bought the Complete Edition on sale for less than ten dollars.  The intro to this version of Civilization is still breathtaking.  If you are looking for deep strategic play, you could do a lot worse than Civ IV.

author: {'steamid': '76561198167550283', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 6972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1826, 'last_played': 1635578556}
review:
I'm a long-time fan of the Civ series (from the original "Civilisation" onward) and it was pretty inevitable I'd be getting around to this game eventually.  So, the main differences from Civ 3 I can see are these: it's got a lot more different types of resources; the tech tree has been tweaked and had a few more items added in; there are more Wonders and types of Wonder; there's the whole new "religions" stream of progress options (very Pokemon, in a way - collect them all!);  there's better animation of your units (and you can see your unit as a group, rather than a single individual); civic rules are a lot more customisable across a variety of dimensions (political, economic, social, religious); and you've lost the ability to tweak your palace or view your city close-up.  Oh, and the game can be customised to a much greater degree than before.

It still has a lot of the same basic assumptions (and thus a lot of the same basic pitfalls) as the earlier games in the series.  A victory via conquest or other aggressive means is always going to out-score a victory by cultural hegemony or other such peaceful means.  The view of "progress" is still very linear, and there's very much a perspective of "the only way is up" (now, admittedly, I haven't really got to the modern era all that often, so I don't know whether there's still the pollution and global warming hazards to be aware of - I really should read the manual to be sure).  The world leaders you're playing are very much biased toward European and Western cultures (there's China, Japan and India representing Asia; Mali and Egypt representing Africa; and the Incas representing South America; meanwhile there's the USA, England, Spain, France, Germany, Russia, Greece, Rome and Persia representing Europe and the global West), so the whole issue of over-emphasis on technologies found useful in the global "West" is a thing.  However, as I said, these are standard problems (of the "this thing I like is somewhat problematic" variety) with the entire series - it's very much a case of either they're deal-breakers for you  as a player, or you accept the game for what it is, and make a mental note of the problematic bits to think about later.

Gameplay-wise, it's much the same as all the other iterations of the series: you move any pieces you have available to move, and press enter to signal the end of your turn.  If you don't have any pieces to move, the game will sit there prompting you to press "enter" until the skies fall (my biggest gameplay annoyance, quite honestly), but then, this [i]is[/i] a turn-based game, and that's what you're in for as a result of playing it.  (Oh, and if you didn't already have every single turn-based game known to humanity sitting in your Steam preview queue before you started playing, you will shortly afterwards... or maybe that's just me).

I can't comment on the multi-player aspect of the game, because I don't play multi-player (I play games to relax, not to stress myself out by getting pounded into the dirt).  The music is very pleasant (and very repetitive) and you're able to turn it down or off as this suits you.  

Given I play this game to relax, and I'm not really into high scores or anything like that, I'm probably not the best person to review it.  But overall, I'm finding Civ 4 to be an interesting upgrade from Civ 3, and I'm really liking finding out how to handle all the new bits and pieces in the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041404063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 16032, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4060, 'last_played': 1700416779}
review:
So addictive that if I keep it downloaded on my computer I will start playing it every time I see the shortcut, even if I'm currently playing another game.

Don't be fooled by the time Steam shows. I owned for a long time on CD Rom and uninstalled it because it was too fantastically addictive. Now it's on Steam, I've bought it and played it yet again, had to unistall again and I keep wanting to redownload it so I can hear the screams of other civilizations as I crush them.

Must resist. I have other games to play. But one day I will reinstall and the screams will haunt my homestead again.

review: This is Sid Meier's Civlization! It is definitely a revamped version of Civ II but with some interesting changes. There are limits as to how many Natural and World Wonders a city can have, the AI is far more advanced- especially the Barbarians. Trading is a much bigger factor than before. The game progresses quickly. If you loved the first ones in the series- you'll be hooked on this one as well!

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198251361560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 288, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1444534807}
review:
My god..this is addicting. You'll spend hours repeating the line "Just one more turn".

Only buy this game if you don't mind losing some hours of your life on a daily bases, once you start playing you'll be hooked on trying to improve your empire and beat out the other Civilizations (or wipe the others out all together, whatever takes your fancy)

10 years since it's original release and this game is still a gem, way more appealing then some of the modern 'fancier graphic' PC games today, you're always learning new things about the game, and though hard at first you'll soon figure out the basics on what you're meant to do.

Though this game never gets dead easy, it will always be somewhat a challenge which is good. Who wants to play a dead easy game? Not me, that is boring.

If you want this, I recommend  The Complete Edition it adds much more value and gameplay to it..though it increases the addiction rate.

Buy this game you will NOT regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033771227', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 872, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 872, 'last_played': 1449942907}
review:
In a nutshell, sid meiers masterpeice. 
Big fan of the Civ titles, some more than others. Played Civ III for the majority of my childhood on a regular basis, Great game, crazy learning curve

Then, picked up Civ V on a wim and was actually rather disapointed. not a BAD game, but not on par with the early'r instalments. To simple, by comparison. (Dumbed down for the casual gamer I guess?)

When i stumbled on civ IV on sale I desided to take a risk on it. Best choice of my adult life. Though I haven't had the time to really sink my teeth into it hours wise. the gameplay is so solid I knew I had been shorting my self for all these years. Has much of the complexity of the third title but slightly less intimedating, plus, losts of features that should have been in the games from the get go, such as a state religion. 

10/10 for turn based perfection

Spoiler alert. Its number 1.
  http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2015/04/24/best-strategy-games/8/

author: {'steamid': '76561198008758421', 'num_games_owned': 360, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 646, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 376, 'last_played': 1698193860}
review:
I'm gonna split this into two parts; those who've never played a Sid Meier's Civ game and those who have.
For those of you who have never played a Civ game before and enjoy turn based empire building strategy games, look no further. This is a superb entry into the genre for inexperienced people due to it's fairly simple playstyle, if you were looking for something a little more complex then you can go for that here too. For those who just want to build and play the long game for wars then this game is easy enough to keep on friendly terms with AI empires and easy enough to just click on what you want to build next in your cities. For those looking for a more complex game you can keep an eye on all aspects of your city, from what it is lacking to where your citizens are automating their production. Now, for those who haven't played this game but have played a Civ game I am just going to assume that it was Civ 5 you've played. Compared to 5 this game is a little more complicated but at the same time feels a little more basic compared to the newer installments. It's a refreshing play and feels much more rewarding for that win at the end. For those tiny few that have played 1-3 and expansions but have yet to touch on this then you should seek help for somehow missing this fantastic gem of a game that will leave you saying 'One more turn' like every other Sid Meier's game.

Ignore the small amount of hours at the time of this posting but I've played a lot of hours prior to the purchase through steam. (Civ IV, the game so nice, I bought it twice.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198002766941', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 33, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1434548852}
review:
First off, I actually have 75 hours in this game at the time of writing, since you launch Beyond the Sword if you have the DLC. This review will be done through [b]the eyes of a player coming from Civ V and will be a comparison of the two.[/b]

TL;DR - I love it. Probably not as good as Civ V, but familiar and different enough that I think it makes an easy buy for any Civ V fan. 

Pros:
+ The espionage is much, [i]much[/i] more entertaining and active, I love it. The capabilities of a spy include bombing building, poisoning the water supply (food reduction), sabotaging production, stealing technology, influencing religion and civics, and a couple more. You can also alter your production of espionage points to lean towards or away from certain civs (for example you can produce more points towards your biggest rival, and less points from distant civs). It is a great system.

+ Combat is very different, and in my opinion better. Units unique abilities are given more weight; archers and longbowmen can be incredibly powerful on city defense, catapults and trebuchets are almost absolutely necessary for taking a city, etc. There is more incentive to not just build 20 of whatever unit has the most combat strength and charge in. Combat gets a little smarter.

+ Given the 5 year gap between IV and V, you'd think that Civ IV would look much poorer...and you would kinda be right. Things don't look as great, a couple of the leaders are ugly as sin, but it more than makes up for this in building a [b]stronger atmosphere.[/b] It does this by actually having a few different models for units, and I don't mean unique units for civs. It things like this; everyone can build a swordsman, and they will have have the same stats, but if you play as Arabia, they will have scimitars, if you play and England, they will have broadswords, workers will look different, etc. It is a great touch. There is also unique music for each time period, like when you first start a game it will play tribal music. If you are playing as Spain and click a unit, they will speak in Spanish. These kinds of things make up for the 5 year gap in graphical capabilities. 

+ Random events. Now I know this might sound bad, but they are reasonable and I think spice things up quite well. They are not completely random and tied various things like the time period. Examples would be a nearby mountain being an erupting volcano and destroying nearby improvements, if you have the slavery civic you might have a slave revolt and lose production for awhile. You'll also get choices most the the time. Like a Russian government official wants to defect to your country, do you accept him and gain espionage points against Russia? Or arrest him and hand him back over, gaining a relationship boost for Russia? It's fun.

Cons:
- What I feel is the biggest con: there is a loss of uniqueness for civs. There are no civ perks like they're were in Civ V (Venice can only build one city, Rome gets +25% for each building already in the capital, etc). These perks were one of my favorite things in V and I miss them. Each civ still gets a unique building and unit, but these often are (mechanically) much more boring than they were in Civ V. Nothing like the Zulu unit who has a first strike, or Portugal's ship that can also do a trade mission. Often in Civ IV, the unique units just start with a particular free promotion, that any other unit could get if it gets enough experience. These changes allow for more freedom but also take away some of the reason you pick a particular civilization: to play a particular playstyle. I pick India because I want to play small but powerful, Rome because I want to spread my empire far and wide, Germany because I want to have large standing armies, etc. Instead most civs have multiple leaders to choose from. While this is cool to see different faces, all the leaders have two traits that many other civs also have. Yeah Genghis Khan has the aggressive trait (certain unit types get free promotion and double production speed of barracks) but so does Stalin, and probably 5 or 6 other leaders.

- Half of the victory conditions have issues. [b]Science[/b] and [b]score[/b] are fine. [b]Culture[/b] victory is boring as hell. It involves nothing more than accumulating culture points from building and wonders and once 3 cities reach 50,000 bam, you win. Even pre-dlc Civ V cultural victory had you build the Utopian Project. [b]Diplomatic[/b] victory is nigh impossible. There are no city states in Civ IV, so you are force to kiss everyone's ass and bend to their wills if you want that victory. Even then if you have different religions they will basically never vote for you. [b]Conquest[/b] Involves you taking ALL other cities. Yes even that one out in that distant snow-covered island that has a population of 2. This is kinda-sorta "fixed" by the [b]Domination[/b] victory type, which involves getting x% of the total land and y% of the total population in the world. Except the numbers are so high that you basically only get it when you could have easily won through science/military/score.

Minor stuff:
- Unit can stack on one tile. Except the markers for how many units are there max out at 8. So I can't tell if a nearby city has 8 units (hey this is a border city and I am just defending it) or 24 units (hey I am about to fucking wreck you in two turns).
+ You can see numeric breakdown of relationships for other civs. -4 for different religion, +2 for fair trades, -9 for huge recent war. Quickly brings you up to speed on how heavy certain actions are.
+ You can trade technologies!
+ A couple more interesting technologies.
- The religion system has no perks to choose from like in Civ V.
+ In the very beginning of the game you have to watch out for wild animals like bears and wolfs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198194190363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 785, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 785, 'last_played': 1435719409}
review: One thing this has that the previous version did not that I am a fan of is the way they show wonders get built in front of you after they're finished. The look and feel of the game is completely different and the controls have also been changed around A LOT. It has some of the same concepts from the last game but you basically have to relearn almost the entire thing. The terrain looks completely different (which is just ok) and the cities are set up in a different grid format that i'm really not a fan of, The city display screen has a better way of controlling what the city focuses on such as production, food, or commerce but the way you control what is being built is terrible compared to the old simple list format. Units are controlled with the right click of the mouse severely limiting your access to the civilipedia on certain objects. Units also don't have an attack and defense rating but just a strength level. Although I like how certain units are useful against other certain types there are way too many types of units. Civilization III was way better in almost every aspect of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024893178', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1461200257}
review:
(This refers to Civilization IV with Warlords and Beyond the Sword.   Also, ignore my playtime; I put 100s of hours into Civ IV BTS off a disk.   I got the Steam version for convenience sake.)

This is arguably the best 4x game ever made; I don't think I am alone in this opinion.   What make it so is a combination of things, not just individual features.   The variety of strategies, the diplomacy, the range of units possible, the difference in the character of the Civs, I don't know I could go on and on and I think there are people who can say it better.

There are two points I do want to make in passing, however.   First, Civ IV was an evolution of Civ 1, 2, and 3.   Some people criticize it because it is an evolution, not a revolutionary new take on 4x.    Personally, I think taking all the good stuff and making it better and adding little stuff that made the whole pie a beautiful thing to experience is a very, very good thing.    Second, Civ IV Vanilla was a very good game, but not a world beater.   The addition of Warlords and especially Beyond the Sword is what made it great.    Of course there are a  lot of mods out there if you want, but the fact is that the only mod I think you might want to get a great gaming experience is the Bug Mod, which doesn't change the game play at all but adds a lot of helpful tools.

10/10  Best Ever.

review:
A revolutionary game for its time, Civ IV is still good nearly 10 years later. By far a better game than Civ V, IV is complex and engaging with more to learn every time you play. If you buy this game, there is a strong chance you will become obsessed and spend hours on end playing. As long as you have the time, Civ IV is much more worthwhile than many of the newer, more expensive games out now.
BUT if you do not want to lose hours of your day without noticing... DO NOT get this game!
You don't mind playing marathon sessions and being totally obsessed with conquering the world? Then this is the right game for you!

Just one more turn ... and one more turn .... one more ...

On regrette simplement le fait que la strat√©gie de bataille soit limit√©e. Pour etre plus clair, la meilleure fa√ßon de gagner une guerre est d'amasser le plus de troupes possibles a la fronti√®re, d√©clarer la guerre, une fois quelques villes prises, faire la paix. Et... Rebelote.

Les graphismes restent appr√©ciables et la religion y est mieu trait√©e que dans CIV 5.

review:
If you're a fan of turn based strategy games like Risk, then this is for you.

If real-time strategy like Starcraft II, Command & Conquer, and the like are more your speed then this is not for you. After only a few minutes in the tutorial, I was bored. I have no doubts that fans of Sid Meier's games will disagree with me and I'm sure that it's a great game for those who like this kind of thing but it's not for me.

review:
Hi

Civ IV ist nach meiner Meinung der Beste Teil. Das CiV Fieber hatte mich beim 2. Teil gepackt auf der PSX. Trotz dessen, dass eine Runde zum Schluss allein 13 Minuten Rechnerzeit in Anspruch nahm war es irgendwie fesselnd. 
Am PC habe ich dann den 3 Teil gespielt und dein 4 geliebt. Auch den 5. habe ich ausreichend gespielt, doch muss ich hier sagen ist der 4. Teil der Beste. "Ich spiel nur eben eine Runde." ..... 4 Stunden sp√§ter "Bin gleich fertig." ..... weitere 2 Stunden sp√§ter "Ja ich komme jetzt auch ins Bett." .... zzzZZZ ;D 

Alle Spieler dieses Spiels wissen was ich meine.

12/10 Points goes to Sid Meier's Civilization IV  :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198006176581', 'num_games_owned': 488, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 5212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 531, 'last_played': 1694394441}
review:
Once upon a time, I tried Civilization V. I discovered it was buggy. What I did play was really fun though. So my in-laws bought me Civilization III, which was really fun. I then saw that Civilization IV was on sale, along with the expansions, so I bought the main game and a couple of the expansions. I am currently enjoying the happily ever after.
This is one of the most addictive games I have ever played. My husband and I are enjoying a hotseat match in which I am sure will end in a bloodbath. In Civilization IV: Beyond the Sword I am preparing to conquer the world with my mighty Celtic army. Civilization IV is an awesome strategy game in which almost anything is possible. There are so many different leaders to choose, and many different ways to beat the game. Sure, you could do a military victory, but you can also win diplomatically, artistically, and financially. There is also the Space Race...
For those of you kind of wary of strategy titles, let me assure you this is a very newbie friendly game. There are a variety of difficulties, and very detailed tutorials to help out. Also, being turn based has a huge advantage in being able to think out what you want to do. Having played Paradox Interactive titles like Victoria II, this is a far cry from the level of complexity found in those games. Nor is it very concerned with historical authenticity. When I first played as Boudicca, a warrior queen of the Celts, I expected to run into one of the Caesars, but instead I ran into General Bismark! My husband demonstrated some interesting divergents from history by having his Germans found Judaism 8), Christianity, and Islam. By what should have been mid-early Dark Ages, his musketmen were busy conquering the Russian Civilization. By the Industrial Revolution, his assorted tanks were conquering the world. He then won peacefully by using the UN to vote himself as the ruler of the world. Yeah...you definitely couldn't do that in a Paradox Interactive title.
I know I have many many more hours of enjoyment awaiting me in Civilization IV. This is a great game to play solo or with others. I can't wait to explore all the possibilities.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011614105', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 78791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10764, 'last_played': 1534988382}
review:
With Leonard Nimoy's voice-over talents, and the intuitive way the game allows you to build a civilization without flagrantly leading you, this game is a huge favorite of mine. When I was broke, and had a computer that wasn't exactly the belle of the ball, this game would run, and I run the beejesus out of it (I actually played the first game so much, the disc developed a crack, and eventually blew apart inside a dvd drive in my desktop). Still, the enjoyment even outweighed the damage and replacement cost of the drive. I bought a new drive, and re-bought the game. 
I regret nothing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039503650', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 48006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 93, 'playtime_at_review': 14867, 'last_played': 1710108837}
review:
This game should come with a health warning, it is highly addictive.  The temptation for just one more round of play just eats up your free time.

This turn based game requires you to build your fledgling civilization (choose one from many to control) into a dominant force in the world whilst reacting to and possibly being at war with a number of other civilizations controlled by the game.

There are ample choices to tailor your game to suit the time you want to play and your skill level.
You can change the size and shape of the world, the level of the other civilizations and the requirements for a victory to produce almost limitless options.

It can take a while to become proficient in all the facets of the game, using the various sources of information available to inform your descisions and to use the different units to the best effect. It is however, once you have a reasonable grasp, an excellent challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027477199', 'num_games_owned': 224, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 5577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5995, 'last_played': 1480128691}
review:
[h1] Civilization IV [/h1] 
      As I awoke a week or so after christmas, it appeared that I got a gift from the worlds best thing, Steam. I quickly downloaded a game that I thought wouldn't be that good, I never really got into turn based strategy games. And I sadly assumed that would be the same case for Civ IV. 
       My first match was a simple one against a couple AI's. As I chose the best leader (in my opinion) Julius Caesar. I quickly got murdered by barbarians. But during that ten minute interval I learned something: 
[olist] 
[*]Build your first city near natural resources.
[*]Screw building any workers, go straight for a military unit to defend said city.
[*]THEN make your workers and crap.
[/olist]
       After my experiance with this wonderful gem of a game, I learned, loved, but mostly lost. Because I suck at this game. But now I can impress basiclly everybody I know when it comes to civics, economies, powerful world leaders of the past, and what those world leaders led. If you play this game for as long as I have, you can pass any world history exam.
Bam, now i got a lvl 4 badge for the review thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034144370', 'num_games_owned': 106, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 670, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 670, 'last_played': 1428022860}
review:
Of the four Civ. games i've played (Civ. Revolution DS, Civ. III, Civ. IV, Civ V) Civ. IV is my second favorite of them.

 it has a great 3D world with great detail and design as well; the HUD is very user friendly and nothing is hard to find. One of my favorite parts is when you complete a wonder, It gives you a nice animation showing the blue prints then the wonder being built. The units look great too, more so when battling other units.

 The camera angles can be a bit off sometimes but its not often; the customization is really good! You can change your nation's name and description; then pick what victories are allowed and which ones are not.

 I wish there was more options for the map instead of just the size and weather types. But overall it's a great game and I highly recommend it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198003156862', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1420247578}
review:
I used to play CivIV for years, logging hundreds of hours. I thought about buying it for Steam as well, but stumbled upon the deal for CivV instead - and purchased it. Sorry to say, it didn't feel like IV at all, so now I've purchased the IV as well. 

IV is definitely more complex - you have a lot of details to worry about, there is tons of micromanagement (the city you completely forgot about for 22 turns has developed unhappiness because they demand Emancipation etc). But this is precisely how it mimics the "real world" and captivates the powerlessness that you need to urge yourself to play just another turn. 

I like the diplomacy mechanism. I like the different automation options for the workers. I like the health aspect in the cities. In fact, I like most things about the game, with only one exception - combat. Now this is something that can be really frustrating - imagine defending your city with SAM infantry and it is being brought down by a heap of ancient era warriors. Not cool. 

But overall, a very enjoyable experience, the vanilla Civ IV is better that CIv V complete, EXCEPT the combat system. To be honest, it all boils down to Baba Yetu...

review: Where does one begin? A game of this breadth is difficult to encapsulate in words. Profoundly addictive, naturally. But strikes an odd balance between intuitive simplicity (build, expand) and mind numbing complexity (the effects and strategies related to resource exploitation, tile managment etc) that'll leave you content to play by either broad strokes or narcissistic micromanagement.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983923420', 'num_games_owned': 263, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 86400}
review:
I've been a Civ fan since the very first one (it was the second game I bought for my first-ever computer), and this is the one I still keep going back to. Civ V is nice and all, and I like how they got rid of the Stack of Doom problem, but Civ IV just feels so much richer to me. There's something deeply satisfying about culture-bombing an opponent and taking over a corner of his empire without ever firing a shot. 

Add on the expansions, and Civ IV is a must-have for any even halfway-serious 4X fan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066764288', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1389624335}
review:
I realise that it says I have played only 0.2 hours but I assure you that it is lying and in fact I have played closer to 40 hours in the expansions.

Rather than write a story about my gaming experience I'm just going to say that after looking through the other positive and negative reviews I have noticed that neither truly bring to light all aspects of this game.

This game is simultaneously great and awful. A turn based strategically good time marred by a horrendously stupid AI that coninually demands advanced technologies in exchange for rudimentary research. 

Don't buy this is you want a complex diplomatic experience as the AI will only leave you disappointed.

Edit: I am surprised people disagree with my review. This game has some of the worst diplomacy in any game I have ever encountered, so bad that is truly does remove enjoyment from what would otherwise be a good expanding, researching and auto-resolved battling game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013566220', 'num_games_owned': 4825, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 39664, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5797, 'last_played': 1546506347}
review:
Diary Entry 1- Heliopolis is under siege by Rome. I've been unable to send reinforcements because Caeser is moving his troops around my territory, destroying farms, mines and villages. I can't spread too thin in fear of my other cities being attacked.
So 5 handfuls of Heavy machine Gunners have been defending the city from catapult bombardments and grenadier attacks.
And now, he seems to have set his sights upon the neighbouring city of Memphis.

Diary Entry 2 - I've reached out to the Malinese and Isabella of Spain, and both have declared war on Ceaser. They are on the opposite side of him to me. So while they cannot directly help my cities, they will put pressure on the Western side. So hopefully I can repel the siege and push to his cities. I have a troop of tanks coming in from the Northeast, and a regiment of Marines coming in from the southeast. 

Diary Entry 3 - The marine regiment was ambushed on both sides upon coming around a mountain. Despite the enemy taking heavy losses, we lost the regiment.
Luckily a reinforcement squad was detailed to memphis, so now it's a case of bunkering down for the incoming attack, and planning the counter offensive.
The tanks have made significant progress, taking the city of Ardea from the grasp of the Romans. They will continue their progress north, towards Rome itself.

Diary Entry 4 - A reserve regiment of Marines have rendezvoused with the tanks. The dispatch will push on to Rome, flanking from the south, whilst Memphis defends and draws the brunt of the Roman Empire.

Diary Entry 5 - We took two cities to the south. And i decided it was now the time to counter attack. Making losses along the way, we broke through the memphis siege, and took the city of Ostia. It was short lived however, as the enemy retaliated while we were at our weakest and reclaimed the city. Luckily, the reserve squad was just 1 click behind, so now we can retake the city again, and await reinforcements.
I see very little action on the Western side, I am beginning to believe my allies have hidden motives. Their troops linger on the enemies borders. Perhaps waiting until I am weak enough that they may strike both me and Julius Ceaser. I must prepare for this eventuality.

Diary Entry 6 - I was wrong to doubt Isabella. How could I let the seeds of battle cloud my mind. She commenced her march across the border today, and in one fell swoop, she liberated a city from the enemy. Her troops have now joined mine, and we march together to the heartland of Mother Rome-ia

Diary Entry 7 -  Isabella and I, sat down today and signed the Permanent Alliance of our two peoples. We will forever be comrades in arms, and for this, I graciously gave her 3 cities as gifts. Not without proper thought mind you. They are in 3 strategic places to mine enemy and mine future enemies. This will allow us to adaquately aid each other in times of war, and even further each others growth.
To our future! -clinks glass-

Diary Entry 8 - Rome has fallen to Spain! I made a good choice in allies, Isabella is ruthless, a worthy opponent to any who may cross her.
The Chinese also declared war on Germany, Frederick reached to me.. unfortunately, as well as the war on the Romans is going, I cannot extend myself at this time. He seemed disappointed.

Diary Entry 9 - An achievement I am unsure of. We have created...The Atom Bomb. I don't know what to think about this. A weapon with destruction beyond any imagination. One that would win countless wars, but with such heavy costs. I must make sure this never falls into the hands of our enemies..

Diary Entry 10 - We were pushing the city of Cumae today, they had heavily fortified the city, and it seemed an arduous task. The combined might of myself and Spain, and yet we struggled.. A shadow appeared on the horizon. They came bearing the flag of Rome, and begun a charge on our flank. We were outnumbered, the rest of our forces had lagged behind to clear up the enemy remnants. We hastily mustered a defence as best we could. The doors to Cumae opened, the cities huge force came out to greet us. We were preparing for defeat..
But then there they came. The Malinese army! They routed the enemy on our flank. Taking advantage of this turn of tide, we charged the enemy city, gates wide open and with morale turned, we claimed it for our own.

Diary Entry 11 - It's been a long war, spanning many years. Due to the efforts of our 3 way alliance, we have chipped the Romans down to a fraction of the strength they once possesed. Brundisium is their final city, their last stain on a world so tainted by greed. I have the honour of being the one to remove that stain. I now make my march, our footsteps of doom bellowing down upon the city walls. We are coming..

Diary Entry 12 - As we approached the gates of the Palace, Ceaser panicked. He offered a Peace Treaty, along with all his coffers. "Why barter for what I can simply take?" I said, leaving a lifeless corpse on the floor. My troops rejoiced, sharing drinks with the Spanish, and food with the Malinese. What was I doing? I was looking across the border to the North... towards the prosperous Chinese Empire.

[b][h1]TL;DR[/h1][/b]Honestly, you have to be a fan of these types of 4x games, to enjoy them. A lot of people find them boring because there's a decent amount of waiting around while you wait for buildings to finish, units to be trained, research to be finished etc. Saying that, I find Civ games to be faster paced than games such as Crusader Kings/Europa Unversalis. The learning curves are a lot smaller too!

You'll never find great graphics in these types of games, but you'll always find amazing gameplay, and that's what matters right? Great gameplay is what keeps you playing, not great graphics. 
I'm not a fan of the newer games, Civilization: Beyond Earth especially. I think they completely ruined that game. However, if you enjoyed the previous games (1, 2, 3) or you want to get into the series without spending a lot of money. I whole heartedly recommend this game.
