author: {'steamid': '76561198048420683', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1548483081}
review:
Don't let my "1.9 hours on record" fool you, I've played over 2000 hours in the Civ4 expansions: beyond the sword, and warlords, and let me tell you - this is one of my favorite games of all time.

It's easy to get into and super addictive. Whether you want to play it like an economic or diplomatic power, or play it like a 4x war-style game (like most people do), it's got something for everyone.  Lots of customization, expansions, and mods to keep it fresh. Everything from fantasy RPG style scenarios, to space ship battles, to my personal favorite - next war; featuring giant tanks and mechs.

Matches can be as short as a few hours or as long as a few weeks.  Great turned based strategy that blends the need to balance economy, science, and culture with military might or defense.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037286545', 'num_games_owned': 353, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 4506, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3175, 'last_played': 1580647020}
review:
[h1]****
4 out of 5[/h1]

Addictive empire builder to the point of insanity.

It was Saturday morning, I decided to start a game of Civilization IV, a short session of one hour wouldn't harm I thought...36 hours later, aw damn it.

Yes, Civilization IV is addictive, but it's also incredibly awesome. Borrowing elements from other successful empire and city builders, Civilization IV is the top of the management game with such slickness you'd think you were actually playing a divisive game of chess. Buy it now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015777772', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 432, 'last_played': 1419657373}
review:
A good friend of mine bought this game for me, and I was really excited. Me, I am usually a Strategy gamer. And this was my first Turn-Based game. After a hour or two, I actually got a feel. Then I went against the guy who bought the game. 

I was kicking his ASS. He had no skill, and my Civ was double the size (Like my dick. Heh...stupid joke). Then the Barbarians came and took my city. Instead of kicking his ass at the end, we joined together and destroyed them. After the glorious battle, we shook hands, but quickly ripped the arms off of each other! I struck first, and he came in like an Elephant (Literally). At the end of the Greatest War I have seen in awhile, he won. He took over my 5 cities (I sold one to him, actually), and became a closer friend. In my opinion. This game, really did make us bond, just a little more than before. And that is what made me love this game. 

I am giving this 9/10, because I wish the Explorers could fight offense, instead of defense. I would have won. I could have won...

author: {'steamid': '76561198046480216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1709139983}
review:
The greatest turn based strategy ever created . This is far better than both civ 3 and civ 5 . This is where they hit the sweet spot, in terms of complexity/simplicity. Civ 4 is also the most thematically accurate iteration of the game - where both the civilizations  and the technology tree seem historically correct. The use of classical music (based on the age you are in), the game music and the memorable title screen song together make one of the best soundtracks in a game ...ever.

And then there are the mods :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198027976689', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 213, 'last_played': 1552931962}
review: Para quem curte jogos de estrat√©gia Civilization IV √© obrigat√≥rio. O jogo conta com muitas op√ß√µes de na√ß√µes, cada uma com suas vantagens. Dentro do jogo existem muitas formas de evoluir, concentrar em guerra, em cultura, em ci√™ncia. A diplomacia do jogo √© bem feita, embora possa ficar um pouco repetitiva.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082700035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1881, 'last_played': 1390781965}
review:
First and foremost, if you're thinking of buying a Civ game, and think Civ 5 is better than Civ 4, you might be wrong.

Civ 4 has a great deal of game play depth, offering multiple ways to achieve victory (culture, domination, conquest, space race, diplomatic) whilst also being accessible to the casual gamer who wants to play a no-stress peaceful game, to the best of strategists who play on the hardest difficulty, defending their lands from relentless barbarians and aggressive AI whilst trying to maintain stable relations and expand to dominate the world.

You can be a peaceful nation, focussing on culture or speeding through research. You can also focus on expansion, setting up as many cities as possible to own as much landmass and resources. You can be a nation of great military prowess, devoting production and research to improving your armies, which you can then use to defend your cities or dominate your enemies. You can decide to care about diplomacy, forging friends with the AI, and eventually, winning the diplomatic victory at the U.N.

World wonders are a fun feature. I always build the Stonehenge, and from then on build as many as possible. The culture and great person points they give are powerful. The game is also fairly educational on wonders of the world that actually exist or existed.

10/10 would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095761475', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1579486463}
review: Fair warning:this game is not for the faint hearted. The experience comes primarily from the involvement with the game over time. A good civ game is not one that lasts a couple of hours, but one that lasts eons where pretty much all countries have discovered nukes and robots and are on the verge of destroying the entire world. I will put my hand up and say I havn't played a proper game yet but coming from the earlier civ games, this is a thing of beauty.

review: Caution :: Don't play before you go to sleep, because it is too addicting and before you know it, it's 4 am. Now for the actual review. I have been playing Civ since Civ II and by far this game is the best of the series. The music is wonderful, the animations are great, and the gameplay is mostly smooth. If you are deciding between civ IV and Civ V I would recommend Civ IV because it has more replayability that Civ V.

review:
Very fun game
Pros: 
- Fun and difficult
-Menu's and hud are easy to 
understand(Overwelming at first)
-Very customizable compared to civ 5 
-Ai are reasonablely *smart*
-more to control and do than watered
down civ 5
-played 100+ hours with a friend having fun all the way
through
-Civ 4 has a very equal views on religion
(just as the rest do)
Cons 
-Ai are unforgivingly difficult
-catherine is civ 5's india
-Learning curve is big
-Must have a friend that is willing to spend
quite a few hours with you
-Units in game at times are extremely useless
-dlc for a game that is extremely old
-Servers have a glitch and make playing with other 
people difficult

author: {'steamid': '76561198101569740', 'num_games_owned': 97, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 5306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1340, 'last_played': 1676828979}
review: Civilization IV is a really enjoyable game to play. What I enjoyed the most about Civilization IV were the science, technology and culture upgrades that are avalable because they reflect world-changing milestones that real-life civilizations have achieved. There are six different ways to obtain victory, different map sizes, and over a dozen civilizations to choose from, each with their own advantages and disadvantages. This seemingly limitless customizability ensures a high replay value, and for only $19.99 it's a really good deal.

review:
Mir wurde Civilization IV von einem Freund empfohlen und zu Beginn war ich dem Spiel gegen√ºber eher skeptisch eingestellt aber nach einiger Zeit und einer Einweisung durch besagten Freund begann es, mir wirklich Spa√ü zu machen.

Der Soundtrack ist atemberaubend, es gibt eine un√ºberschaubare Vielzahl unterschiedliche Werke, die der jeweiligen Era angepasst sind. Die Grafik ist ziemlich gut, vor Allem, wenn man das Alter des Spieles bedenkt. Auch spieltechnisch macht Civilization IV einiges her, auch, wenn die Grundlogik doch eher etwas hinkt (Gandhi und Napoeleon bekriegen sich im Jahr 2200 mit nuklearen Waffen und Bogensch√ºtzen, ...).

Letztendlich l√§sst sich sagen, dass Sid Meier mit diesem Spiel ein hervorragendes Strategiespiel hervorgebracht hat, welches sich selbst mit aktuellen Neuerscheinungen messen kann.

review:
Its probably the last of the best civ's, though i hope not.

The only complaint i have about this game is that the worker automate is counter productive. They will keep changing farm to village, or remove plantation and put down a farm. If the worker ai was 100% perfect this game would be 10/10.

Get it on sale if you can, but its probably still worth the non-sale price if youve never played it.

9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029031939', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1397, 'last_played': 1402563755}
review:
A couple hours into the game and the incredabley slow pace of it reminds me of playing monopoly all night, at some point you just want to get to the point of saying I'm done you can just win already. The balance of the units is so off that advanced units are capable of being distroyed by lower teir; for instance muskets carrying soldiers can kill your commando squad; there are also times when your units simply stand there as they get hit with bullets, swords or elephants, the speratic dice rolling of the combat gets tiresome; expecalliy when it can take you all game just to get a decent sized army. 

         The food and disease levels on here also ruin it for me, no real way to fight the disease and trying to combat the hunger just slows the game down, at the end it can take up to a dozen or more turns just to research a new technology but at that point the computer is already 5 or six levels ahead of you, I played Rise of Nations and thought it would be something very similar but this is a very slow punch to the face, I really wouldnt recommend it to anyone unless you like taking all night just to build a couple towns and research some technology, the rts part of this game only makes up a certain 8-10%.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085304235', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 637, 'last_played': 1474565894}
review:
I have been playing Civ 4 for a while now, and I have to say that it's a great game to pass the time. It is also a good game to play if you want to end up ruling the world and are unsure of how to do it - um, did you just read that?

So anyway, first of all there's a bunch of empires all with their own technologies, pros, cons and so on. And for each empire you get at least one leader. Each empire comes with a unique unit which can alter gameplay, such as the English redcoat, the French musketeer or the German Panzer Tank.

That brings me to the next great part - the units in the game. You start off with one city, and from there you can choose to make/train anything you have the technologies and resources to make/train. For example, you can train a warrior to fight, a scout to explore the map, a settler to find a new city, and later in the game (literally almost at the end), if you have the right stuff, you can make nukes!

The real icing on the cake is the fact that it is all so - well, real. You make contact with a new country, you make peace with them, you trade with them, you give them stuff - and then they can turn on you. Honestly Germany, why did you? You beat me, and I had grenadiers, war elephants and artillery; all you had were a few archers and a single catapult!

And last but not least, there's the winning. You can win by lots of ways: getting the most points by 2050, getting to Alpha Centauri first (space victory), controlling at least half the world, killing all other civilizations etc. All this great stuff turns the game into a real life simulation that is addictive and super fun. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198040946492', 'num_games_owned': 1337, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1391631145}
review: The greatest part of this title is being able to become Julius Caesar without the threat of Marcus Brutus and the conspirators. There is nothing more excellent than the feeling of celebrating the Lupercalia without fear of omens from a Soothsayer on your impending demise. The sparing of Mark Antony's lachrymation also contributes to this triumph, and Sid Meier is indeed an honourable man. Always keep in mind that the evil you do will for sure live after you, yet the good will be interred with your bones.

review:
Commander la destin√©e d'une civilisation pendant des heures et des heures, le tout avec une B.O. magnifique et un gameplay d'une tr√®s grande richesse, voil√† ce qui vous attend avec ce jeu, ce qui vous attend avec n'importe quel Civilization d'ailleurs.
Cet opus fut d'ailleurs celui qui m'initia √† la populaire saga de Sid Meier et sa version CD a √©t√© mon h√¥te durant un nombre d'heure de jeu assez astronomiques (sans la culpabilit√© associ√©e au compteur Steam).
Les d√©fauts de cette quatri√®me it√©ration sont : une I.A. limit√©e (r√©curent dans la s√©rie), un temps de chargement lent en fin de partie m√™me avec une bonne config (idem), un syst√®me militaire qui se base trop sur l'empilement d'unit√© (rem√©di√© dans l'opus suivant)

author: {'steamid': '76561198133004621', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 14165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4328, 'last_played': 1662234735}
review:
Anyone unfamiliar with this series of games must have been living under a rock for the last 20 years.  Each new version is an improvement on an already good original, adding new refinements and fresh idea's to enhance the game play.  The diplomatic options have come on in leaps and bounds, eliminating one of the few flaws in the first version.  The variety of ways the game can be won, and the option to have a new map every time, ensures each game is different to the last.  The number of Nations that can be played is excellent, and each Nation and it's leaders bring their own skills to the table.  As a result, you can persue a victory based on your Nation's strengths if you wish, or just unleash your Army regardless and go for the hard kill.  A number of difficulty levels change the challenge to match your experience, and the huge customization available gives you the chance to make things as you wish for a specific play.  As an example, if you want a huge Navy select a world type based on islands with a world surface heavy on the water, select a Nation with a nautical skill or Special Unit and get it on.

I played the original back in the 90's, and loved it.  The modern version, with all the extra wonder's and so on, blows it's socks off and steals it's dinner money.  For those seeking a stratergy game, you just found a hard game to beat.

review:
I have played this game since Civilzation I. I've played every version of it along the way and it only gets better. All the older versions are still fun but each subsequent version is upgraded for the better in every way.

If you like strategy and/or turn based games. This one will keep you up into the wee hours of the morning.

review: I would have to say that this is the most boring game i have ever played. Never have i thought that sleep was more intersting than a game. In fact evern thinking about this game makes me feel sleepy. I spent four hours playing the game and I was still in the stone age. Plus the game makes no sense at all. Aparently you can build Stonehenge in Washingto D.C and Buddisim can be found by any country possible? Plus Ghandi's a B_TCH.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126984829', 'num_games_owned': 100, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3514, 'last_played': 1566095381}
review:
Sid Meier's Civilization IV.
Il mio primo videogioco strategico a turni,molto bello,lo sto amando alla follia,pagato 1 euro grazie all humble bundle piu le sue espansioni,che dire,gioco consigliatissimo a tutti gli amanti della saga e dei videogiochi strategici,molto piu facile da capire dei vari total war
Quindi dopo le mie 50 ore di gioco,vi consiglio moltissimo questo gioco
Vi divertirete molto!

review:
It's looks like many other people really enjoy this game.
Me not. :(

Civilization is not an Action RTS games like Age of Empires series or Command & Conquer series.
This is a TBS board game.

Since Civilization series get such high metascore, well i think i can say this is a good game, but.....
just not my bowl of noodles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087225635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 166, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1462086737}
review: Excellent game. Enormous replay value. Great online play. There is tons going on and tons of factors to consider... perhaps too many. The game has a good reference guide built in yet this guide is constantly lacking critical information. That being said; this is, quite literally, the best historic strategy game  I've ever played. Will keep you hooked for hours on end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042562757', 'num_games_owned': 1994, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 1096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1077, 'last_played': 1497405806}
review: This game will ruin your life. I play this for so long I forget to eat. It's the ultimate example of "Just one more turn..." mentality. That said, it's the best timekiller around, jsut beware when you play at 10 AM and you notice a few minutes later it is 10 PM.

review:
The music, in particular, is fairly epic in scope to match your efforts. The core is the same, lead your civilization from the beginning throughout history.

The expansions add a few new mechanics and civilizations, and each has their own scenarios you can choose to play through. You will need to have a certain version installed to have access to the scenarios designed for it.

And do not trust your allies for long they will betray you at a slight thing.

- Bloodwolf

author: {'steamid': '76561198104392527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 334, 'playtime_forever': 149, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1452825066}
review:
Downvotes are coming, I know. But I didn't really enjoy this game. I haven't played any of the Civilization games before but I was pretty excited to play this one as I'd heard so many good things over the years.

It turns out, the game just wasn't my thing. I thought it was much too slow... Granted, the game has so many features to it and it is decently complex. It is a well-made game, don't get me wrong. It just wasn't for me.

Do you like the clasic strategic game of pcs?
Buy this game now!
Hours of city administration, diplomacy reports, long wars, tactics on the map. Long hours here and you can pause and save it when you want. No more online full action. Totally 0% action, 100% tactics.
One of the bests games of strategy. You can choose reachs for your empire, where to build a city, how it grows, the expansion of your culture and territory.
And i must say too, IA isn't retarded, as so many others game.

review:
Civ IV ist definitiv ein Multiplayerspiel - ich muss sagen, ich habe es noch nie ernsthaft Singleplayer gespielt und w√ºrde das auch eher langweilig finden.
Au√üerdem braucht es Zeit - viel Zeit. Wahrscheinlich ist man hier selbst mit einem bespielbaren Szenario zu zweit mindestens einige Stunden unterwegs, und wenn man eine Runde von vorne bis hinten spielen will, w√ºrde ich schonmal zwanzig Stunden einplanen.
Wenn ihr abw√§gt, dieses Spiel zu kaufen, dann √ºberlegt am Besten, ob ihr a) Leute kennt, mit denen ihr es auch tats√§chlich spielen k√∂nnt (nat√ºrlich findet man immer neue Leute im Netz, aber es macht mit bestehenden Freunden am meisten Spa√ü) b) ihr geduldige Menschen seid, die Spa√ü an einer laaaangen rundenbasierten Spielpartie haben k√∂nnen c) ihr euch f√ºr die Idee begeistern k√∂nnt, die Entwicklung der Zivilisation nachzuspielen.
Davon ab ist die Civ-Reihe definitiv eine meiner Lieblingsspielreihen, wenn nicht sogar meine absolute Lieblingsreihe im Bereich von (Multiplayer-)Aufbauspielen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974037314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 94, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 86400}
review:
[i] Originally posted on September 16, 2007 [/i]

Civilization IV is a really fun game, based on a formula of expansion, growth, and conquest. However, it does have some flaws.

Graphics- The graphics on this game are, by all standards, nothing special, but a vast improvement over previous Civ titles. Besides, graphics in a strategy game aren't really the main focus.

Sound- The game has some great music tracks, which are era specific and usually appropriate. While the music does get a bit repetitive, I still haven't gotten tired of the opening title. The sound effects are pretty funny, which help contribute to the feeling that Civ4 is "just a game". A good thing, in my opinion. Also, Leonard Nimoy speaks to you every time you research a technology.

Gameplay- This is where Civ4 really shines. The game is really infinitely replayable, with infinite possibilities and completely ludicrous historical combinations to try! The city building and expanding mechanic is very solid, however combat needs A LOT of work. Battles are simplistic and very unbalanced at best, relying almost completely on numbers and tech level rather than strategy or practicality. I for one, feel that stone age spearmen should never be able to defeat attack helicopters. In addition to this, some of the civics and the entire religion mechanic are completely pointless, which is a shame, considering they could have been put to very good use. Ultimately though, the game is still very good, and very addictive. I give it an 8.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059630359', 'num_games_owned': 136, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 83, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1384523060}
review:
This is one of THE best PC games out there. Sid Meier's Civilization IV is a sequel to the famous Civilization series, having been going on ever since 1991. I had initally gotten Civilization V, and when I got the complete version of Civilization IV (Warlords, Beyond the Sword, and Colonization [a modification of Civ IV that is also a remake to Colonization], all of which are expansion packs) I could not stop playing Civilization IV: Beyond the Sword, until I got Brave New World for Civ V a few weeks ago. And I still play Civ IV BTS. BTS is $10, but Civ 4 Complete is $30, so I reccemond the complete edition.

Also, Baba Yetu is one of the best songs in gaming EVER. Baba Yetu has won a Grammy Award. The first, for a piece of music for a video game.

A+. SO many pros that each and every con is obliberated. GET THIS. NOW. IF YOU HAVE THE MONEY. IF YOU DON'T, THEN FIND A WAY TO GET $20 or $30, and YOU WILL NOT STOP PLAYING.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042118407', 'num_games_owned': 6189, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 211, 'last_played': 1385880303}
review:
Classic Civilization gameplay polished to a fine sheen. The music, in particular, is fairly epic in scope to match your efforts. The core is the same, lead your civilization from the beginning throughout history, and try not to smeg everything up too awful. As addictive as ever.

The expansions add a few new mechanics and civilizations, and each has their own scenarios you can choose to play through. You will need to have a certain version installed to have access to the scenarios designed for it, unfortunately. Each is tuned to the appropriate mechnics and everything is generally balanced quite well,

The AI can pose a real challenge to your eventual world domination whether in scenarios or in single player matches in the randomly generated worlds. There also has been a heavy modding community for Civ, so mods and extra scenarios are readily available. Civ 5 finally seems to be catching up with the polish of its predecessor, but either can be a great time with a bit of investment. 5/5

author: {'steamid': '76561198014206568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1013, 'last_played': 1394751565}

review: I recommend this game on the highest possible terms. I would recommend getting the complete edition, however. The mods included in beyond the sword are frankly stunning. author: {'steamid': '76561197972258172', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 230, 'playtime_forever': 1787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1787, 'last_played': 1376965504}
review: Awesome addition to the Civ franchise - perhaps the best to date. Very open-ended gameplay allowing you to achieve victory in a number of ways, be it through technological discovery, diplomatic clout or all-out war. The diplomacy and trade mechanics aren't quite as polished and intuitive as, say, Total War: Shogun 2, and the 1-unit vs1-unit combat can often be a little frustrating and unpredictable, but there's a sense of great accomplisment in watching your cities and friendships grow, denying a plea for peace from a rival empire that dared to once challenge your might, and renaming the conquered cities of your enemies 'Asstown' just to spite them. 9/10.

review:
which Civ game should you pick if you only want to buy one?
probably Civ V...or II.
BUT, co-op mode is broken in Civ V, so get this one if you want to have a game with your friends  against bots.

+ may come in second only to Civ V as the best, turn-based civ-developing game
+ co-op vs. bots works
- combat is less stratiegic in this version due to the mechanic of allowing an endless pile of military units to occupy the same hex

score = 4.5/5

author: {'steamid': '76561198067753796', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 2410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1294, 'last_played': 1455664876}
review:
Squirrel's seal of approval: Platinum

Why I play: I bought it on sale just bacause of a recommendation. I didn't like it at first, but I grew to love it.

Why you should play it: Arguably the best in the series, and my all time favorite strategy.

Recommended input device: Mouse/Keyboard

Pros
+Great soundtrack
+Historical playable characters
+In-depth strategy
+Good graphics
+Highly addicting
+In-depth strategy
+Good trading system
+Improved combat
+Great multiplayer

Cons
+Abysmal menu system
+Very hard to get used to without help of an experienced player

Verdict
While I love this game, there were problems with it's UI and playability. Luckily for you, I can be your experienced player to show you the ropes. I love strategy although I don't own much. This game was a great purchase.
9.9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198055789798', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 2614, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1704, 'last_played': 1457368241}
review: I think this is a pretty good improvement from 3 (i haven't played the others).  Easier automation tools (good for a resource/management game) and various things make a lot more sense, especially combat.  The addition of National Wonders and Religion lets you have more options without more troubles.  There are no more talking "advisors", having been completely replaced with screens and graphs.  It's slightly harder for new players to figure out what certain things mean compared to 3.  Multiplayer has some nice options if you want to make it easier for yourself and your casual friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998304056', 'num_games_owned': 1730, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1211, 'last_played': 1357372800}

Also, screw Gandhi. Backstabbing jerk.

review:
Civilization 4 is yet another great Sid Meier's game in the Civilization Series

in Civ 4, each Country have different Leaders to pick from and are not just stuck with having 1 leader to pick from

culture plays a big role in 4th of the games. since you can use it to overtake citys if your culture is greater then the city your trying to push borders with

certen leaders have certen bonuses that other leaders of the same country may not have..

and the bonus about the 4th is i'v never seen it crash even on low end systems. where i have seen systems crash with the sequal of this game the 5th in the line

in anycase i hope you'll enjoy it if you decide to buy it :D

author: {'steamid': '76561197963243012', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 86400}
review: Civ IV is a classic turn-based strategy game.  Nothing really beats taking over the world.  Or seeing the in-game messages: "Gandhi has acquired nukes" or "Lincoln adopts slavery."   It has a pretty intuitve interface and all the options are easily laid out.  The game shines in its pure randomness.  Every game is different, especially with real people (if you can find people to play with).  Civ IV has taught me a few things: Never trust Montezuma and always fool other players into trading their cities for bananas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021041474', 'num_games_owned': 677, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 906, 'last_played': 1369627583}
review: Civilization is a game about building a Civilization from 4000 B.C.E. to 2000 A.D.  you can choose from 18 different civilizations to play as.  Within each Civilization you choose a leader and start the game.  You start the game off with a settler to build a town and one warrior.  From there you claim rescources and build a civilization.  You can build farms for food, Cottages for money, mines for material production ect.  You also have to research technologies, these technologies allow you to build more structures within your cities which help them grow faster and build other units.  You also have to take in account other civilizations which you can befriend or turn into an enemy.  I could touch on more but steam Caps the amount of Characters that I can use.  Basically, buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018000980', 'num_games_owned': 974, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3098, 'last_played': 1379942562}
review:
When I was first introduced to this game I was quite sceptical having never experienced a strategy game like this before, and being more used to typical RTS games. I was left amazed at how in-depth and engaging the strategic elements are. One moment I was advancing through the ingame tutorial and the next I had sunk 10 consecutive hours into my first playthrough. With it nearing 2 A.M in the morning, I found myself mumbling 'one last turn, one last turn' only to continue playing for several more hours.

From the outset you're enticed into this turn-based world with a couple of units, stone-age technology; and then engrossed in the long climb from that to a world-spanning Empire which you helped develop both socially and technologically. It‚Äôs an epic unfolding before your eyes, one click at a time.

Civilization IV is by far one of the best strategy games to date, boasting an addictive and mentally stimulating form of gameplay that few games today can match.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970974530', 'num_games_owned': 1031, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1369033200}
review: Civ 4 is probably the most detailed and comprehensive of the series. Where as 5 is more accessible and 3 experimented with new ideas 4 refines these and creates a refined and coherent whole. A strategy game for the more experienced player as you not only go through diplomatic, military and scientific struggles but also try to balance these with religion, espionage and international corporations.

review:
It's a fair Civlization building game. I mean, to be fair, it's the main name in the genre. And it's good, don't get me wrong, but I enjoyed the Civilization games largely when I passed the current era and began moving into future eras with realistic possibilities. Lately Civilization seems to focus more on the past, which is kind of dissappointing.

To date, my favorite Civlizatoin game is Civilization: Call to Power, and this one doesn't quite rate up with that one. Still good though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992509968', 'num_games_owned': 1319, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1453268183}
review:
The magic of Civ happens somewhere between the discovery of the wheel, and the discovery of gunpowder. It‚Äôs there where you have to start figuring out your path to victory. Where are the AI. Where are the borders? What‚Äôs your preferred victory condition. How many continents are there? Do you have allies? Do you have cavalry? What resources do you have to hand. Can you trade for more? Can you fight for more? All these questions set off a cascade of decisions.

And then it‚Äôs 3am, and Ghandi is acting like a child over Uranium.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022681935', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 86400}
review:
An exquisite blend of strategy and creativity make Civilization an enduring and beloved franchise to many a nerd Civ4 is no exception. On occasion, putting down your chainsaw/machinegun down to create a nation, making it prosper and conquering all mankind by war or influence makes for a unique manner of satisfaction.

That said, Civ4 is amazing and boasts some great DLC that expands on an already amazing game with slick online matches that have the depth of chess coupled with the matter of tense negotiations on the verge ot total war. It's tense, it's exciting and it's the kind of thing you need to plan a weekend for because it will, not may, swallow your soul causing you to emerge from the computer days later to piece your life back together.

It's THAT good, but tread with caution, life Starcraft this will cause you to be hospitalized from too much play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968566119', 'num_games_owned': 713, 'num_reviews': 238, 'playtime_forever': 1750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1750, 'last_played': 86400}
review:
I hate this game. It was so repetitive it makes me sick. Although my brother loved this game enough to send a space ship to alpha centari, I refuse to play it more than those 29 hours that I did play it. Because of this I refuse to give any Civ game another chance, even though I own about 8(?) of them.  

I know Sid Meier has made other great games though, so I don't quite want to blame him. His "Pirate's" game was pretty dang fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992940444', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1549652168}
review: Simply THE BEST turn-based strategy game there is. I've played matches that have lasted for more than 12 hours! Buy it, now!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025731851', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 753, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 753, 'last_played': 86400}
review:
Drop all those "real-time" games for awhile, and exercise your brain with Civ 4!

You now no longer need lightning-quick refleses. Civilization is all about planning, and planning, and planning. Take your time, and build your civilization to be Earth's Number One civ!

Despite not being real-time, believe me: When you've learned enough how to play Civ 4, you'll spend an obscene amount of time playing this game.

Highly recommended!

author: {'steamid': '76561198011220599', 'num_games_owned': 837, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 911, 'last_played': 86400}
review:
Build your own civilization and dominate the world!  I have played Civ II, Civ III, and now Civ IV.  It gets better with every release.  As far as expansion packs go I would recommend against them unless you like the bundled scenarios.  Other than more scenarios they don't offer anything new.

This is one of those games you first start playing and by the time you look at the clock four hours have already passed.
